17.contentId:
Once, very long ago, lived the Crocodyls, one of the most dangerous peoples ever to exist in the World of Twelve. They would regularly go down and attack the villages, abducting the weakest inhabitants. Once back in their caves, they would immediately devour them.

Those who survived that dark era will not deny that the Crocodyls deserved their spot atop the food chain.

Yet despite their relative intelligence, they were still only animals. Mounting an ambush and conducting large-scale attacks were beyond them, which kept them from posing a risk to any but the smallest villages. Ancient stories claim that this wasn't always so, but they were considered to be fables intended to scare children.

One day Crocoburio was born, son of Grougalorasalar the Dark, a black dragon who had been charmed by the reptilian beauty of Crocabulia, Crocoburio's mother. This abomination, this violation of the natural order, made possible by his father's evil powers, had serious consequences for the pack.

While it normally takes three or four years for a Crocodyl to reach its adult size, Crocoburio, by the age of just a few weeks, had already killed all the males.

The first unexpected consequence of this massacre was that it brought an end to the slaughters in the surrounding villages. But the bards may have been too hasty in writing passionate odes to heroes who, it was thought, had given their lives to eliminate the threat, for the respite was to be short-lived.

Five years passed without a single worry about the Crocodyls. It was a peaceful and pleasant time, but like all such times, it was only the calm before the storm.

Crocoburio, now in his prime, seemed to have a plan... for Crocodyls, that was a first. The draconic blood running through his veins gave him incredible intelligence, strength, vitality, and a worrying amount of ambition. Over a period of a few months, Crocoburio mated with all the females, who then provided him with sons as cruel as their father, and ready to obey his every order.

However, Crocoburio knew that there was something missing that his powers were unable to give him. To the east, Amakna's heroes had terrifying weapons that were capable of blowing him and his sons to pieces. So he decided to pay his father, Grougalorasalar, a visit.

Dragons are notorious for being particularly unpleasant hosts, even to their own offspring. And had Crocoburio been in the den of any other dragon, he would most certainly have had a difficult time of it.

But Grougalorasalar was enticed by the spite he saw in his son's eyes, just like he had been enticed by the dark beauty of Crocabulia. They stayed in the cold, humid cave for a long time, scrutinising one another. They seemed to understand each other without saying a word. Even if none of the legends can reveal what Crocoburio promised his father, we know that it was on this day that his father gave him the legendary Crocobur sword.

This sword forged in the fires of a volcano was not only a true work of art; it was also a magical weapon with devastating powers. Grougalorasalar used the darkest sorcery to strengthen his powers; protection runes were engraved on the blade Crocobur, and a regenerative gem was embedded into the quillon to ensure its bearer unfailing longevity.

While we may not know exactly what happened that day, we know that after this meeting, the black dragon, the devilish destroyer of life and infernal scourge of the living, was transformed. He had grown fond and proud of his son and began watching his progress from a distance, intervening any time Crocoburio attacked anyone stronger than him, fell into a trap, or was betrayed.

This love, which grew stronger every day, was inexplicable in a black dragon with the darkest of dark hearts. It was likely Crocoburio's unique character and his all-consuming, unlimited hatred that his father liked so much. Once when Crocoburio ravaged and seized control of the "green lands", the black dragon accompanied his son, and spoke words of advice and encouragement from the shadows where he hid.

Crocoburio's territory had spread out as far as the borders of Amakna and many believed it would be the end of the civilised world.

None of the heroes that tried to oppose him were able to defeat this terrible warlord. He wiped out numerous villages, enslaved the villagers, and was about to march on Bonta, when fate decided to turn the tables on him.

An immense white dragon called Croulaklakoss had been watching Crocoburio for a while, and above all had been keeping a close watch on Grougalorasalar's dark deeds for the last several thousand years.

As a rule, dragons are not really concerned with other species or their fate; they find them about as noteworthy as Tofus. However, amongst the dragons themselves, black and white have feuded and envied each other's treasures since the dawn of time itself.

When Crocoburio and Grougalorasalar set off to attack the great Bonta, the shrewd and calculating Croulaklakoss descended on them and attacked the black dragon directly.

The battle between the two scaly monsters made the ground shake as if in fear, and many in the Crocodyls' ranks were massacred.

Thinking they were being helped by the white dragon, the knights and city defenders threw themselves into the battle, spelling the end of the reptilian army.

The Bontarian archers' arrows pierced Crocoburio's skin like a sieve. He fell, fatally wounded, killing dozens of enemies in the process.

Seeing his offspring struck down, Grougalorasalar was distracted for an instant. The white dragon took advantage of the momentary lapse to deliver him a final, fatal blow. Grougalorasalar fell with a crash, his enormous head landing next to his son's lifeless body.

To this day, the elders tell how they saw, for the first time in Amaknian history, an incredible thing which seemed all the more incredible for a creature with a soul as dark as a Bwork's foot: they saw a dragon cry as it died. That black dragon was named Grougalorasalar.

20.contentId:
A long time ago, in a region far, far away, long since forgotten by all, there was a tiny village.

The peaceful Feca peasants who lived there were getting ready to endure the most gruelling winter they had ever known. That year, the frost had arrived much earlier and more fiercely than in years past. The trees of the neighbouring forest had been layered with thick snow for some time.

If the cold, biting as it was, was to be their only challenge this winter, they should make it through unscathed. The Fecas in this region were farsighted and hard-working, so every year they would fill several barns to the brim with grain and supplies to ensure they would make it though the cold season without too much hardship. They were so well organised that, though the winter was particularly glacial, they never had anything to fear.

Unfortunately, the harvest had been particularly meagre that year. Yet there wasn't much panic; they had still gathered enough food and wood to keep themselves warm during the winter without starving, if only just.

Yet, as if the uncommonly meagre harvest were an ill omen, many had begun to worry.

How they would have loved to be wrong... but that night was a terrible one. Blood-curdling howls could be heard throughout the night. At first, they thought it was common wolves, as was often the case in the region, but the howls, interspersed with tortured screams, were so powerful, so like sinister laughs, that they all knew it could only be one thing. A Boowolf had come to the forest.

That night, all the inhabitants were gathered in the village hall. It was the most horrible night of their life. Fathers tried unconvincingly to soothe their wives and children but sheer terror was easy to read in everyone's eyes.

But the worst was yet to come. With the first light of dawn the screams stopped, and the bravest of the few hunters in the village went outside to discover a sight they would never be able to forget...

The lifeless, disembowelled corpses of dozens of wolves and other creatures littered the village square. It was a scene of pure horror, even for the most jaded of the hunters.

And yet, the worst was still to come... The barns containing the winter reserves had been sacked and burnt to the ground, all of them, without exception. Not even a single grain remained to feed the inhabitants through the winter.

Once the square had been cleaned up, the village regained some semblance of calm. A sinister calm...

A special, urgent meeting was held between the elders of the village and it was decided that a group with the best fighters of the village would depart as soon as possible to seek help in the nearest city. They were to hire mercenaries to come rescue the remaining villagers and take them far, far away to safety.

With luck, they might have succeeded. But luck was not with them. All of the hunters expected to have to fight the Boowolf, and none were surprised when it found them. What they did not expect, and what was a very unhappy surprise indeed, was that it was not alone. There were three gigantic Boowolves to contend with. The fight didn't last long at all. The three Boowolves brought down the poor Fecas with ease...

Only one man among the hunters survived his wounds. He was the youngest and his name has been forgotten with the passing of time. Many hours after the Boowolves had left the villagers dead or dying, the young hunter managed to get up again and, with the help of a simple stick, walked until night fell. Fate or blind luck led him to a small cabin that he had never seen before, deep in the middle of the forest. Tentatively, he knocked on the door with the end of his stick.

An old Enutrof, dressed all in white, opened the door. He immediately understood: the young Feca was dying. He brought the Feca water and healing ointments at once. The young man survived just long enough to tell his story before expiring in the Enutrof's arms.

The old hermit, who was known as Kwismas, buried the young Feca. That night, he had the hardest time sleeping, tossing and turning in bed. He knew that no one in the region would dare gather troops and bring supplies to the poor Fecas or even go to their rescue. And yet, he couldn't bring himself to do nothing and let so many women and children die.

In the morning, he got up and, strangely calm yet determined, filled his sled with supplies. He harnessed his two white Tabis, Reindear and Rudolf. He gathered enough supplies for a hundred people to live for a year. He took all he had gathered during his lifetime, and left nothing behind.

Not once did he look back. Not once did he look to see his cabin shrinking in the distance.

The Enutrof's sled arrived in the village square that evening.

The leader of the village, the wisest elder they had had for generations, approached the sled with extreme wariness.

She discovered an Enutrof dressed in blood-stained crimson robes. The brave Kwismas later died in her arms, explaining what he had brought with him. Witnessing his gift – the most beautiful one they had ever seen – everyone in the village cried for an entire week. And they survived, thanks to the supplies brought by the courageous Enutrof.

Come spring, the Boowolves had disappeared, and the villagers left to find a new village, one with fewer bad memories.

Everywhere they went, they would tell their story and of the sacrifice of the venerable Kwismas. Everywhere, people were moved to tears. And since then, at that exact time of year, every year, people celebrate the memory of that courageous Enutrof by giving gifts to the needy, relatives, and children.

And some say on that night, every year, a sled pulled by two white Tabis and driven by a man dressed all in red soars through the sky and that, in the morning, the young and the needy are covered with gifts.

21.contentId:
Once upon a time, there was an Eniripsa teenager named Kevin.



One beautiful Descendre night, a blinding light came up from the horizon and moved towards young Kevin. As it did, he suddenly began to recall the words of his dear, departed grandma, recounting an ancient legend:




"In the beginning, the Krosmoz was created. This has widely been regarded as a good move. Shortly after, the ancient gods entrusted the care of Amakna to two gods: Doodoo and Booboo. Unfortunately, Doodoo spent much of his time murmuring soft, incomprehensible words into his beard, despite many reprimands from an apoplectic Booboo, who spent his own time crying, without stop, "B-b-b-but this is impossible! How c-c-c-can one p-p-p-person be so dumb?!"

(Archivist's note: part of Cdrik's manuscript has been erased, so the following section relates the events narrated in the original text.)



The endless bickering of the two gods eventually separated the Earth from Sky. The Earth would henceforth to be ruled by Gallia, and the Sky by the five Fromskys. Betty, Babar, Noel, Quentin, and Sandra Fromsky all had fabulous magical powers. Yet, Noel stood out from the rest of his family. Indeed, he alone had the ability to bring things to life, which made his siblings quite envious of his power.

Noel used his gift to create nine beings: Dasher, Dancer, Prancer, Vixen, Comet, Cupid, Donner, Blitzen, and Rudolph. Filled with extreme jealousy, the Fromsky siblings transformed all nine into animals and exiled them to Earth, where they lived and were known as Rayndears. Noel discovered their treachery and decided to join the Rayndears in exile. The Rayndears had kept their ability to fly through the skies, and proudly pulled the sled belonging to their creator, Noel.

Legend says that Noel took up residence in a cave north of Amakna, hiding from his siblings who set off after him, and there he discovered eggs with strange powers: the Dofus.



(Archivist's note: the original manuscript continues faithfully from this page on.)

Strange things began happening: ten of the eggs began to move, and ten beings sprung from them, each possessing twenty or so unique magical powers. The progenitor of each of the races had been born. Noel named them Sadida, Osamodas, Enutrof, Sram, Xelor, Ecaflip, Eniripsa, Iop, Cra, and Feca. Xelor could bend and warp time at will; Eniripsa knew the most ancient of healing secrets; Osamodas had an incredible empathetic connection with other living beings; Cra could see perfectly at incredible distances...



Each of the ancients had their own unique powers. Noel then invented a machine which could create dozens of creatures in the image of the country's first inhabitants.

The remaining four great Fromskys still didn't know where Noel was hiding, but they caught wind of his discoveries and saw the country of Ankama fill up with these beings that were so small compared to them.



They then set about trying to create life themselves. It was not a total failure. They brought many beings to life, but their creations could not match the intelligent, social and developed creations Noel had made.



These creations loved the Earth, and some suffered so much that they became aggressive and shut themselves in caves, hid in forests, or secreted themselves away on islands.



One moonless night, some of the creatures, which would later become known as Wabbits, spied something strange and shiny while digging their den.

It was round, or rather, oval, and had coloured spots all around; it seemed fragile and just a little worse for wear.



The Fromskys, attracted by the fuss and chaos of this part of the land, quickly discovered the cause of this disruption and took the object in question. They had just acquired one of the rare Dofus of the land. They quickly understood the power it contained and decided to use it to create a being, as Noel had done so long ago. But they had neither his know-how nor his ever so unique power.



Nonetheless, a new creature was created. It easily surpassed all the things the Fromskys had created before. Intellectually, it was equal to Noel's beings, but its genetic code was troubled and unstable. Creatures in its image would come to be known as Sacriers.

Noel realised the gravity of the situation: such an event must imperatively be prevented from happening again. He tasked his flying Rayndears to travel the lands and gather all the Dofus they could find.



When all the Dofus had been collected and were in his possession, he had a brilliant idea! Indeed, the Dofus more and more urgently needed to be hidden, and so he thought of the only places in the land that the Fromskys would never think to search. He entrusted the Dofus to the Fromskys' most powerful and terrifying creatures: Dragon Pig, Wa Wabbit, Dark Vlad, and many more.



From that day on, the Sacriers learned to overcome their difficulties and control their power to make good use of it, and Noel has never stopped taking care of every being living in the lands of Amakna.

To commemorate Noel's affection for his creatures, Gallia, who governed the Earth, planted a giant tree, the Rif-Salguod that bore strange red spherical fruits all year round, and each each fruit reflected the life of one of Amakna's beings.



Noel placed a star that he had brought with him atop the tree, and decreed that he must visit each and every one of these creatures at least once a year. He chose the month of Descendre for this excursion to Amakna; meanwhile Noel's Rif-Salguod continued to grow, surrounded by thousands of smaller Rif-Salguods created by Gallia to keep the original hidden.



Every year, Noel travels the land, offering gifts to every creature. For example, it is said that Noel, after having given him a castle, gave Wa Wabbit powerful robots, called Wobots, to protect him..."

A strange event pulled Kevin from his thoughts: the bright light had gone out for a moment, and then stopped growing and, worse yet, began to fall! It fell a long time before coming to a stop with a dull thud. It lit up all the strange, pointed trees that grew each year around that time, the very same trees that local lumberjacks absolutely adored cutting down so that the locals could each decorate one with all sorts of shiny objects.



Was the tale true? If it was, had Noel himself fallen in the middle of the forest, or just his star? Intrigued by the scintillating light filling the forest, Kevin immediately headed out towards the mysterious object. After a long and exhausting trek, the light became difficult to bear, and for good reason: he was nearing the site of the impact.



When he arrived, he discovered a great man; Noel, his creator and father, was there in front of him!

Noel was stuck there because a leather part on his sleigh, without which flight was impossible, had been damaged.

Kevin, having some knowledge of leather-working, was able to repair the sleigh, and Noel left again, calling out: "Thanks, Kevin!" That year, Noel was able to continue his rounds, and to show his gratitude, he gave Kevin a gift that only Eniripsas can master: flight. Kevin could thus fly through the air.



It's said that anyone who visits the crash site will discover something marvellous, beyond their wildest hopes and dreams.


Unfortunately, the exact location has been forgotten by all, and no one, not even young Kevin, knows how to get there... What could possibly be there?

22.subTitleId: 3rd place in the Christmas Tales Competition 2004
22.contentId:
There are those who say that during Amakna's long winter, each delicate snowflake that nimbly comes to rest on the verdant ground of the prairies is, in fact, a frozen tear. A tear of our Creator who, realising that every living thing he created and gave all his love will one day die in war, can't keep from weeping.



The other divinities in the company of the Creator believed that in giving their disciples powers similar to theirs, they could bring a definitive end to the fighting. Such was not the case.



Call me Eowen. I am Cra's messenger, and so I wander the land, spreading this message to her disciples and to any others who would hear it.

So it was that one day I crossed a pretty young Iop girl. Her eyes sparkled with innocence and, obviously very frightened about something, threw herself into my arms. I asked her what had frightened her so.



She answered: "Wha- what is all this white stuff? Are we under attack?"


Evidently, she was experiencing her first winter.



I answered: I responded, "Don't be frightened, little girl; this white blanket which has come to rest upon everything we see is nothing but the materialization of the Creator's sadness as he realizes that all the creatures he created aren't able to live together peacefully."



The little girl, intrigued, answered: "But can we change the bad to good so the man up there will be less sad?"

"It's not that simple, little girl. But if everyone loved life, loved observing, and loved loving, as you do, we might be able to do something to dry the tears of he who created us, and fill his day with warmth in these cold times."



No sooner had these last words left my mouth that the young girl jumped from my arms and, running through the thick snow, went back to her home, sure to give each passer-by and each inhabitant of Amakna the biggest and warmest smile she could. The sun, hidden all day just untill now, was already setting.

That night, the grand clock in the living room sounded its usual 12 bells, and the wooden Tofu left its little nest the usual dozen times, announcing the very beginning of the new day. That night also, the little girl dreamed of warmth, and of lively, dancing lights; in a moment of near-wakefulness, she thought she might have seen a soft glow from the dining room but, still absorbed in her dreams, she fell deeply back asleep.



The next morning she woke up and shambled into the dining room where, to her enormous surprise, she beheld before her a huge fir tree, decorated with a thousand miniature undulating, glowing lights. At the end of every branch hung glass ornaments in the shapes of Tofus, Tiwabbits, and Bouftous! Each one beamed in her direction with big, warm smiles.


Luminous garlands were woven through the branches and changed color so subtly that they almost gave an appearance of life to the tree – the most beautiful tree she had ever seen in her life.

Slipping into her boots, her gloves, and a robe decorated with a beautiful and majestic cross, she hurried out the door to discover with wonder that the banks of snow had been replaced by a beautiful sun that gently warmed the cold Descendre air, and, just as gently, melted the snowmen built by the neighbourhood children the day before.



Everyone in the streets was laughing, singing and dancing. Everyone had a smile upon their lips and was brimming with life. The habitual tranquillity of the village had disappeared, replaced with the joy and vivacity that had descended upon the village.



When she finally made her way out of the village, she saw things no one had never seen before.

At the base of the Treechnids, groups of dandelions, roses, and sunflowers danced a lively waltz while the Treechesters giggled without stop as the snow still resting in their foliage began to melt and sent drops gliding all the way down their trunks, tickling them.



As for the male Tofus, they were trying to woo the females, having taken the wise precaution of using the ends of their beaks to fastidiously bring each individual feather to a shine.


The Larvae and the Arachnees rode gleefully on the backs of Boars, as the Moskitos were using their wings to help the Mushds, who for the first time in their lives found themselves able to leave the ground (according to later rumours, many of them became quite sick because of their 'air-baptism').

There were even races in the woods. Dark Vlad, riding the Dragon Pig, carried the day against two fearsome teams: the Boowolf (who had exceptionally left his cavern, wearing a strange chastity belt that gave the impression of something valuable hidden underneath) on the Savage Dragoturkey, and the Trool riding the prestigious Royal Gobball.



And as for the Scaraleafs? As the day was reaching its end, they prepared a beautiful firework by cutting off their own wings (their wings grow back quickly) and sending them into the sky, carried by Kwaks – who took their role quite seriously – to form a giant Tofu head.



The Jellies of all colors bent over backward to prepare a banquet for everyone that, while it may not have been terribly healthy, was definitely quite delicious.

Nature herself seemed to be having fun and joining in the party. A certain harmony had taken place between her and the inhabitants of Amakna, who laughed with hearts full of joy to see these normally feared creatures having so much fun.



And so, after all, the little girl succeeded: it didn't snow anymore as the sadness of the creator had disappeared with the snow that had been falling for weeks.



The young girl went back home, heart full of joy, laid down on her bed and gazed at the ceiling. All of a sudden a soft, light parchment floated through the window and landed on her knees.



It said simply: "Merry Christmas".

Since then, that young girl (who is no longer very young) continues to make sure that day, each year, is a day of celebration for all.



Her discovery so many years before helped Amakna to have a day of universal celebration where all of the living creatures of the kingdom, with smiles on their lips, share the same joy, hand in hand.

23.contentId:
The Discovery of the Treechnids: p. 3

The Treechnids' Powers: p. 5

The Soft Oak: p. 6

A long time ago, before evolved beings arrived and built a village to settle in, Amakna was a beautiful, wild area where plant and animal life flourished all year round.

When the first civilised creatures started arriving, mostly from the seas and mountains surrounding the area, they discovered forests that almost seemed to be alive themselves... alive and hostile.

After several disappearances, they started to realise that the forests were hiding a terrible secret. Living trees, which they called Treechnids, were discovered. Angry about the newcomers settling near their forests, they systematically attacked anyone who got too close to them.

The Treechnids drew their power from the heart of the forest. Their ability to summon Arachnees and regenerate themselves in the middle of combat made them terrifying opponents for anyone who couldn't see just how much of a threat they were. That being said, the civilised beings and their fire put a rapid end to the forest's rebellion.

From then on, every time the newcomers wanted to construct new buildings, their custom became to light fires and completely torch the territory they needed. The forest was no longer strong enough to take a stand, and the Treechnids gradually disappeared.

However, north-west of Amakna, one part of the forest remained intact. No matter how many fires were lit and how many axes were raised, this part of the forest could not be overcome.

Some people say that this part of the forest is home to the Soft Oak.

It is the ancestral guardian worshipped by all plant-like beings. If we're to believe the rumours, the Soft Oak is the forest's heart and its conscience.

Many adventurers have tried to learn more about this legendary tree, but most were driven by a desire for treasure rather than knowledge, and very few ever made it back to tell people what they had seen.

What's more, the survivors' statements varied so much that the authorities found it hard to believe that any of them were true.

And yet, when a large group of adventurers would disappear all at once, these disappearances were always followed by a rise in the Treechnid population.

Eventually people gave up trying to reduce this part of the ancient forest to ash, and so its mystery lives on to this day.

24.contentId:
The Mad Legend: pg. 3

Zakary Asp: pg. 4

Maly's Challenge: pg. 5.

Mount Stinkky: pg. 7.

The Witnesses: pg. 9

Molok Ark: pg. 13

The Kiss: pg. 14

The Whips of Love: pg. 16

There are numerous creatures in this world, but the creature this book talks about is certainly the strangest and the craziest of all.

Crazy is THE right word when talking about the Cruncher. Though his story is often compared to a fairy tale, even his fiercest detractors agree that all the witness accounts have an obvious thing in common... an anomaly which can't be explained by the most brilliant magicians, nor by the scholars of Bradacho, nor by the followers of Radama.

We believe that the story of the Cruncher, if he exists, is linked to the story of a young man called Zakary Asp, son of the renowned Zelote Asp.

That is why we are now going to examine what pushed Zakary to walk all the way to Mount Stinkky.

Zakary, who is probably considered to be the most empiricist of all the magicians of Amakna, is like the angel Baloisse who only believes what he sees. He had decided to prove to the world, once and for all, that the Cruncher was a pure fabrication, a tale for the gullible...

The reason for this surprising obsession came about in quite an informal way, in the doorway of Glow-Finger Tavern, an indecent bar where all encounters between magicians and witches were possible. Magicians looking for a good time generally met there...

But that wasn't why Zakary was there. Glow-Finger Tavern was the sanctuary of Maly the Bogeywoman and of the many young mages whose hearts she had stolen...

After a pretty boozy evening, tired of the young magus's statements, Maly the Bogeywoman promised her hand "and more" to Zak if he would give her the key to solving the enigma of the Cruncher – either proof of his existence, or of his nonexistence.

Women are often cruel to their suitors. And giving Zakary this challenge was about the same as asking him to stand still for several hours, on the head of a bucking Minotoror... though this is not a good example because a magician has already done that.

But the young and crazy Zak was delighted and found that it was worth the trouble to earn unlimited access to the Bogeywoman's favours.

This is why our young magus began his journey, with a bundle on his shoulder and romantic dreams in his head. He then headed for Mount Stinkky in order to meet the first witnesses to have been in contact with the Cruncher.

Anyway, it wasn't an easy thing to get to the place where those people lived... It was a long and dangerous journey... The only advantage was that all the humans who are said to have met the Cruncher were all gathered in that very place...

Zakary had to go there. And this fact alone, when you think about it, deserves to be told for everything he had to endure and the obstacles he had to face. However, this has nothing to do with the real purpose of this book.

This asylum was very hard to reach since they only brought nutcases and crackpots of the worst kind over there. If any of them escaped, you had to make sure that they wouldn't be able to get past the numerous traps.

They all had something in common... a thing that made those most resistant to the idea of the Cruncher's existence doubt their certainty... a lousy doubt that prevented them from closing the books.

All the witnesses had a liking for evil: lechers, perverts, Api eaters, nuddle burners... Each victim had a strong vice and some unhealthy deeds weighing on their conscience. However, they probably all ended up in this big asylum on Mount Stinkky either because they went mad after seeing the creature or because they deserved a reprimand for their deeds.

The only thing we need to know is that, when he arrived in this terrible building, our young Zak was still smiling, and he still had images of the Bogeywoman in his head, as if his love for the saucy girl had given him an iron and steadfast will, even in the most difficult of times...

Zak, who had barely taken the time to look after his wounds, went and questioned Damog the Loony, a famous brewer who mixed his beer with Tofu blood. The hatred he had of these little animals had brought about the downfall of numerous families of breeders and, to crown it all, had turned his beer into one of the most famous in Amakna. Of course, this was before the consumers realised what they were drinking. Some bars still serve it, but Damog was confined to a mental hospital. The specialists considered him mad and dangerous.

But to Zak's great displeasure, Damog wasn't paying attention to his visitor. He kept saying these words "More in me... More in me..." Zak was all the more troubled since all the other people who could have given him some information behaved exactly the same way... Whether it was Jango the Ripper or Farde the Frivolous, they all kept saying the same words, with the same intonation...

All but one.

Just when he had lost hope, Zak went to see the last witness. Probably the most terrible. A tall, bald-headed man with weird eyes... big and protruding, frightening and penetrating eyes as if they were reading the soul of their interlocutor. Zak wasn't really scared, because he hadn't made this trip and survived all those adventures to be frightened by two big eyes... Oh no, it would take more than that for him to forget Maly the Bogeywoman's charms...

His name was Molok Ark and, unlike his "roommates", he wasn't repeating this sentence over and over... He was surprisingly quiet. And, believe it or not, this quietness was terrible.

When he spoke, it was with a surprisingly guttural voice, a voice that didn't sound human at all. Zak would have certainly turned tail and ran, but the thought of winning Maly's favours was enough to keep him to task. But this simple "hello" would certainly have frozen the blood of even the god Iop himself.

Zakary spoke up, with a slightly quivering voice, and asked his interlocutor about a thousand questions. Zak was looking for a detail, a hint that would prove that the legend was ridiculous.

Zak the empiricist didn't care much whether the monster existed or not, his desire was now too strong for him to waste anymore time around here. Every second he was wasting here was a precious second wasted far from his muse.

When, suddenly, Molok started speaking. His voice had changed, it sounded younger, softer... "Kiss me, Zakary, kiss me and I'll give you the proof you seek; kiss me and your quest will be over." That is what he said.

Zak, who couldn't believe it, pondered for a moment... He had never believed this nonsense story, and what was wrong with kissing a mad man if it enabled him to have the woman of his dreams and earn himself a good reputation in the academy to boot.

This poor chained bugger couldn't possibly harm him. He walked slowly towards him, with a grin, took Molok's head in his hands and heartily kissed this terrible person, renowned as one of the most terrible gangsters and murderers in Amakna.

The guards opened their eyes again several hours later. They explained that when Zak's lips touched Molok's, a terrible flash of light lit up the room. When they awoke, Zakary Asp had disappeared, and Molok, hunched up in a corner, kept saying "More in me... More in me..."

Collective hallucination? Whatever it was, we still have not managed to prove that the Cruncher exists...

Yet, a few days later, Maly the Bogeywoman disappeared as well. Some people said they had seen her, long after, in the middle of the forest, whipping a man who was laughing with pleasure...

Whether the Cruncher exists or not, we know love can make you behave unwisely... or worse, drive you mad!

Note About Runes: p. 11

The Quadramental Breeze, as the magical wind that brings elemental magic to Amakna is called, is such a complete mystery it would take several encyclopaedic volumes to fully explore it.

But that is not the goal of this book; I shall instead, quickly and simply, relay my theory regarding the appearance of this wind. Why would a wind carrying such powerful magic suddenly begin to blow? Why precisely at that time? Why? The only logical explanation in such an illogical context must involve one of the other great non sequiturs of our world: the Dofus.

In short, in order to explain this mystery, I've no recourse save to press into service another mystery. It would seem to me that someone assembled the four elemental Dofus. Their interaction at that moment created a whirlpool of pure elemental magic that propagated throughout the land – and the breeze began to blow.

Let us now move on to the topic at hand: the creation of magical items.

Elemental magic, carried on the Quadramental Breeze, can be isolated, stockpiled, and manipulated. With suitable tools, one may even impregnate certain items. But this manipulation is difficult, and most assuredly not without risk.

Let us examine, step by step, the transformation of an item by elemental magic.

First of all, we will see how to harvest and work the elemental magic such that it is suited for the task of impregnating an item.

Then, we shall see, in detail, the process of fusing the mundane with the magical.

It is important to know that elemental magic is usable in multiple forms.

The easiest is the concentrated form contained in a sphere, which I call a Metaria.

In appearance, a Metaria is a homogeneous liquid with magical properties, contained within a sphere made out of a membrane through which magic cannot pass, which prevents the magic from dissipating in the air as it normally would.

There are four distinct types of Metaria, each corresponding to a specific element:

– Yellow Metaria: Earth

– Green Metaria: Air

– Blue Metaria: Water

– Red Metaria: Fire

There are also three degrees of magic concentration (percentages given are in comparison with a sample of pure magic):

– Simple Metaria: 50%

– Triam Metaria: 65%

– Mage Metaria: 80%

You may find pure Metaria in the entrails of certain monsters, in particular those monsters with some level of elemental potential.

You can also craft them. To do so, it is necessary to press and compress several magic-containing resources in one of the "Munster Mashers" that I've created. You must then collect the resulting magic liquid in a "Munster Magic-Catching" bowl.

Here is the list of current resources that give good results:

Metaria:

4 × Kwak feathers + 1 × Kwak beak + 1 × Metaria sphere

Triam Metaria:

4 × Scaraleaf antennae + 1 × Scaraleaf wings + 1 × Metaria sphere

Mage Metaria:

4 × Dreggon shells + 1 × Dreggon egg + 1 × Metaria sphere

But how exactly do we use Metaria to impregnate an object? We can't – at least not directly.

You must work the magic contained in the sphere, mix it, and fuse it with inter-ether liquids in order to give it stability in our physical world (I shan't trouble you with the details – suffice it to say that only alchemists can fully understand this process).

Take your Metaria to an alchemist to be transformed into potions. And now nothing remains to be done save to impregnate your metal with magic!

Fusing metals and weapons is straightforward:

A single elemental potion will suffice for each weapon.

Place your weapon on the specially-constructed anvil, heat it to a temperature at which metal may fuse, and once the weapon glows red, plunge it quickly into the elemental liquid. Repeat several times. Tada!

Please note:

The fragility of your weapon during this process is directly proportional to the level of magic already in the weapon.

Thus, a Twiggy Sword will be rather easy to transform, while a Raziel may be impossible.

Please do note that your seniority gives you an approximate success rate compared to an average weapon.

Note also:

The quality of your results will depend strongly on the quality of potion.

Using potions corresponding to lower-concentration Metaria will cause a proportional decrease (50%, 65% and 80%) in the quality of the finished product.

In order to avoid mishaps, please be sure to use potions suited to each specific weapon! For example, you might use a potion transforming Neutral into Fire on a weapon inflicting Neutral damage.

Strictly speaking, it is not within the realm of this book, but I'd like to take the opportunity to inform you that improving a weapon by means of a magical rune follows many of the same rules that I shall summarise below:

– Difficulty is proportional to the efficacy/magic of the weapon.

– Success rate is relative to an average weapon.

– Failure may result in a decrease in weapon bonuses.

On the other hand, weapon does not matter in the rune procedure, and a rune may be integrated into any weapon, regardless of magic level or other characteristics.

It would also seem that you crushers work on minor runes and can fuse them together.

The following document is a faithful transcription of various documents about guild creation.

It contains the Summoning of the Ancients used during the first ceremonies in Amakna, as well as instructions, and advice for novices – upon which I, your humble servant, will comment.

First of all, I would like to thank Sir Harry Stottel for his precious help in putting together this epitome.

O, son of long ago and father of the centuries to come!

It falls to you to place the Guildalogem in its eternal resting case!

It falls to you to unearth the names of your forebears in this ancestral place!

It falls to you to place the Guildalogem in its eternal resting case!

It falls to you to proudly lead your brave fellows, for the glory of our peers!

It falls to you to harvest part of the gifts of the earth and of the trading cities!

And finally, it falls to you to protect those who swear allegiance to you!

But remember this!

The Guild Stone shines only for trained souls who have proved their courage in battle. Its eternal light cannot truly dazzle until you have gathered at least nine followers around you.

Uniting at least nine companions

Shame on those who stay alone and on those who fall below ten in number!

Glory to those who number ten today and even more tomorrow, who will illuminate the lands of Amakna with their presence!

From their shared experience, the Guild's true power and experience shall be born!"

"Novices will be able to find Guildalogems in the entrails of monsters they have defeated."

These stones are, in fact, crystallised organic waste. Therefore they are quite easy to find around Amakna... if you're not scared to get your hands dirty by cutting up dead meat, as the Grand Manchour says.

Finding a Guildalogem in the entrails of a monster

"With this stone, a novice will be able to enter the ceremony room. The novice will then place it in the provided receptacle.

According to the Amaknian ritual, the novice will then be able to engrave the names of their ancestors on the coat of arms they have forged themself."

And not "on the coat he has worn himself", as my eminent colleague Barnaby Dadrunkair mistranslated.

"In order to exercise their new powers as a Guild leader, the novice will need to gather at least nine companions and cleverly exercise their power."

The Guild leader will assign a role to each member and fix the amount of experience they will have to give back to the Guild.

"The new leader will be clear-sighted and will always hear the voice of reason."

This last instruction has been overlooked somewhat since Moloudor The Mad, blind and deaf, became a Guild leader.

The leader will be clear-sighted at all times

"The Guild leader will watch over the number of members in the guild."

It is obvious that recruiting new members will be one of the major tasks of a great leader. The bigger the Guild is, the more powerful it becomes, the more experience it will gain, and the more Perceptors it will be able to place.

"Everyone's experience for everyone's benefit."

The Guild's powers and skills can be strengthened with experience: to do so, all members should give some of their experience.

"To collect their share of gifts from the earth and the trading cities, novices will call on the Perceptors."

Perceptors are a greedy lot, all cut from the same evil donkey hide.

At least, that's what Oktavion de Streun said, and he was one of the richest merchants Amakna ever saw. (This hatred can be accounted for, to a great extent, by the amount the quadrupeds took from his profits.)

Novices can call upon Perceptors for help

On the other hand, Huilius de Kowpats, one of the greatest farmers Amakna ever knew, never ever complained. I feel obliged to add that the Perceptors got a bonus on his harvest, which made relationships and trade between Huilius and the Guilds easier.

"Just like the delicate Freyesque Orchid, the Perceptor is the target of villainous men's desire."

This sentence, uttered by Onirik Hatful, highlights a major aspect of the Guilds' wealth. Items and kamas collected by your Perceptors should be picked up by the leader or members he has chosen for the task before greedy thieves come and rob them. That's why leaders have to appoint Guild members to protect the Perceptors. And why one shouldn't forget to give the Perceptors the means to defend themselves.

"Perceptors are like doors that you must be able to open and close."

This is another quotation from the ever-inspired Onirik, and it reveals the necessity of wisely distributing points to the Perceptors so they can harvest resources, earn experience and defend themselves against the attacks that they are sure to endure.

Preface

Unfortunately, as happens every year, a new type of Black Plague ravaged Amakna. But the one that struck in Aperirel of 463 was quite surprising: the plague did not affect people but rather their pets.

The symptoms were terrible. It would first manifest as a bodily imbalance. Some pets would grow huge but their skin would burn. Others became quick as the wind yet extremely sensitive to cold... But they all inevitably died.

Silouate, the guardian of Aperirel, attempted to cast a spell to save the poor beasts. Any pet stricken with the disease, no matter the severity, experienced a sort of rebirth. It was the only way to stop the plague, which had been killing them off one by one.

But Silouate didn't stop there. To prevent a similar catastrophe from happening in the future, he decided to partially link these small creatures' disease resistance to that of the people of Amakna, which was much higher and more resilient.

What Silouate didn't foresee was that his spell would strengthen the bonds between pets and people. Within two weeks, pets had become completely dependent on their owners...

That is why, to this day, pets have little chance of surviving if they don't receive the special care described in this book.

Introduction

First and foremost, to take good care of your pet, you must love it, otherwise your pet will not love you.

This book doesn't provide any tips or advice on how to love your pet, however, as that cannot be learned. Instead, we're going to look at the second most important condition: proper feeding.

This book will first explain the importance of the Bwak feeding cycle. It will then cover the resources that make up its diet.

Feeding Your Pet

A well-fed pet is a regularly-fed pet!

It takes Bwaks a minimum of 12 hours to digest food. Forcing one to ingest something before it has finished digesting will make it obese and slowly damage its health. The best way to feed one is to follow a fixed daily schedule.

For example, at 8 a.m. and 8 p.m.

But remember that 12 hours is its minimum digestion period. Once a Bwak has finished digesting its food, it can easily go about 10 hours before being hungry again.

That's why scheduled feedings every 24 hours would be quite appropriate for a Bwak.

For example, at 9 a.m. every day.

Generally, Bwaks can fast for about 36 hours.

After that, your Bwak's health will begin to decline rapidly.

If you follow this diet to the letter, your Bwak will thrive. Statistically, you will notice visible improvement approximately every 3 meals.

If you don't feed your Bwak enough, it will become weak and skinny.

If you feed it too much, it will become obese.

Therefore, you must be very careful.

Treating Malnutrition

If your pet becomes obese, you can treat it by following the proper feeding schedule. Alternatively, you could deprive it of food until it returns to its normal state, but be careful as this last method could make your pet suffer and fall ill.

If your pet gets skinny, you can ignore normal meal times until it recovers its strength.

Treating Injuries

When injured, your pet will need to follow a special diet of Eniripsa Powder, which can be used to heal pets. You can purchase this powder from the Bow Kennel.

If your pet is injured, you can also bring it to the Bow Kennel to keep its condition from worsening until you can get Eniripsa Powder for it.

Your Bwak's Diet

Bwaks can eat many kinds of resources. Some will provide the vitamins needed to improve resistance, while others will have different effects.

Please find a non-exhaustive list of these foods below:

Most seeds will reinforce its basic characteristics.

Nuts will strengthen its resistance.

Acorns will reinforce its stamina.

Using Your Pet in Combat

Your pet will typically help you in combat by defending you or helping to make your attacks more effective.

Be sure to keep a close eye on your pet, though, because it will be injured every time you lose a fight against a creature.

If you don't heal it after each loss, it will eventually die, and you'll have to find a way to revive your pet.

In general, the only way to heal a pet after losing a battle is to feed it Eniripsa Powder.

Customarily, when adventurers fight one another, pets are never targeted and therefore cannot be injured, even in the event of defeat.

If you want to be sure your pet doesn't get injured, simply keep it in your inventory rather than having it by your side during combat.

About the Bow Kennel

The Bow Kennel is a place generally reserved for raising pets.

You can leave your pet there so it's safe and well-fed while you are away. However, your pet will not improve while in the Bow Kennel, as it is away from its master.

You typically have to pay a fee to drop off your pet, and then another fee when you pick it up later.

The amount you have to pay will depend on how long you're gone for. The longer your pet stays in the Bow Kennel, the steeper the fee.

The Bow Kennel is also where you can buy Eniripsa Powder to heal your pet.

The most well-known Bow Kennel is usually marked on adventurers' maps. It can be found next to Sufokia Gate.

In conclusion, we must point out a physical limit to your Bwak's constitution.

Once its growth is complete, its capacities will have reached their maximum and it will be difficult to improve it further.

But be advised: if you stop caring for your Bwak properly once it has reached this state, its health will suffer greatly.

Good luck to you and your pet!

Tips N' Tricks: p.7

Cool sea breeze blowing on your face, the smell of salt tickling your nostrils, the call of Cig'Hulls, the soothing undulations distorting a mirror of water, and the gentle croaking of froodles. that is the daily life of fishermen.



And if, on top of that, they actually manage to catch a fish or two for dinner, all the better.

There's nothing too difficult about fishing. You just need a good rod and, most of all, a lot of patience.




Choosing a Fishing Rod



Choosing a good rod is essential for a fisherman. Here are some things to take into account:



- Range


- Effectiveness on certain species of fish



A short-range rod won't let you fish very far from the bank. But the shorter the line, the easier the rod is to use. Short-range rods are therefore recommended for beginners.

Some rods have special shapes, lures, or some other clever device that lets you catch certain types of fish more easily.


For example, cubic fishing rods greatly increase your chances of catching Breaded Fish, even in places where many other species can be found.



These rods are generally more expensive than average rods and can only be used by experienced fishermen.

Good Fishing Spots



There are generally two main types of fishing locations: fresh water spots such as streams, rivers and lakes, and the sea. Of course, fish are very different depending on where they live.



Whether they live in fresh water or in the sea, fish often gather into dense shoals according to their size. You can guess the size of a fish only by watching the shadows on the surface of the water. From these observations, good fishermen will be able to decide the best course of action. Big fish are, logically, reserved for experienced fishermen.

A few fishing tips:



Depending on the time you go fishing, the activity of the fish will be different.


For instance, no fish will bite while sleeping, and too much noise outside will scare them away. It's up to you to figure out what time is best for fishing!



How easy fishing is depends on both divine willpower and the guardian of the World. Some days, or even some weeks, will be more favourable than others.

49.subTitleId: How to become a good hunter
49.contentId:
Foreword: p. 3

Definition of a Good Hunter: p. 4

Weapons: p. 5

Types of Meat: p. 6

Meat Preservation: p. 7

Equipped with a simple knife or sharp lance, hunters are fearsome predators. Some are even more ferocious than the ferocious beasts they hunt. A primary and essential occupation in Amaknian society, hunters are respected for the meat they provide, and feared for how they get it.

Being a good hunter is mostly knowing how to fight, combined with a few subtleties unique to the trade.

Good hunters know where to find prey and how to bring down monsters without damaging the meat. They also know how to use very powerful weapons.

To collect specific pieces of meat, hunters must kill and carve beasts in very specific ways. To facilitate this, special weapons have been created for hunters. Once properly equipped, hunters increase their chances of getting the desired meat.

Special hunting weapons are not always easy to handle. While most hunters can master the classic hunting knife, very few are able to efficiently use the deadly hunting hammer.

It's always possible to break a hunting weapon in order to recover a hunting rune, which can later be placed on a standard weapon by a smithmagus. A hunter can then use that weapon as a hunting weapon.

Different types of meat can be collected:

- larva flesh

- insect flesh

- bird meat

- Gobball leg

- pork loin

- Wabbit leg

- snout

- dragomeat

Please note they have been listed more or less according to scarcity, and there are rumours that even rarer meats exist.

There are several levels of quality for each type of meat. The higher quality the meat, the better its taste and nutritional content when cooked.

Before selling or preparing fresh meat, you should, and indeed must, treat it to ensure its preservation.

Special products, such as Blop or Jelly blubber, temporal powder, and infected blood, to name but a few, let you do this quickly and effectively.

You used to be able to find these items fairly easily in shops, but since the great crisis of 649, they have become impossible to find. Nowadays, hunters would rather collect these items directly from the source or ask others to make them.

90.contentId:
"There's nothing here." For a long, long time, this was indeed the only thing to be said about the corner of the universe dealt with by this book. But oh, honourable, admirable reader, have you felt it too? Undoubtedly so, otherwise you wouldn't find yourself reading these lines... Intrepid, audacious reader, you've guessed it, you know: history is on the move! A world is about to flourish right here before your eyes! But be careful nonetheless: this will be an unusual birth! And those who expect a bedtime story, the kind you tell to good children, had better close this book. Because here, they'll find no wish-o-matic fairies, no Firetwerk temptresses, no superbly sculpted leather-clad archers, let alone gallant, testosterone-riddled paladins... Sorry, I'm getting carried away... The following pages describe the origins of a world soon to be plunged into total darkness.

Torn by bloody wars. Thrown to the brutes! To the louts! To the barbarians! This is the story of the world that drew its splendour from half a dozen eggs, and which was thrown into chaos because of them...

But, revered, noble reader, allow me to introduce myself: Acidrik Gutsplitter, Master of Divination and Soothsayers. Simply put, I read the past and future in the entrails of everything that moves on this world. I also read in beer foam – provided it's Amaknian – and in pork loins (but only A-grade). In the following pages, you'll find everything I had a chance to see on the creation of the world: you'll wander the battlefields and get close to the gods and goddesses. Oh well! Reader, you will understand that the world described in these lines is far from one void of history.

Preface

As a prologue to this story, you should know that a single god is not enough to create a world worthy of the name. However, the world in question owes much to Osamodas, a moody god who prefers the company of animals to that of the other gods. Some say he specialised in animal Summons to keep himself company... which benefits his followers: Osamodas's disciples can summon the most beautiful representatives of Amaknian fauna – from Tofus, the slender birds with yellow feathers, and Gobballs, the gracious herbivores with white wool, to Prespics, the blubbery beasts whose stings make even the toughest people cry out in pain.

During one of his lonesome strolls, the god Osamodas came face to face with a strange sign. From this find, and thanks to the god's dragons, a new world was born.

"There's nothing here." Written in fiery letters on a platinum sign, the words flash in turn; they seem to float in the middle of nowhere. Around the panel, a cold, bleak star gravitates, thrown across the vacuum of space like so many others. Moreover, reading this sign is the only thing to do there – yet it's still necessary to be a god, a god called Osamodas.

Treading the vacuum of space with his divine feet, nevertheless swollen by the long walk he'd just undertaken, Osamodas admired the void surrounding him. It's so different from the other voids he knows! A void that's so pure, so limitless, is not to be found every day, neither amongst those around him, nor even in the god Iop's head. This flash of humour enchanted an Osamodas full of self-satisfaction. In his eyes, the god Iop was the most fiery, impetuous being, but also the most brutal of the Universe.

It's sure and proven that Iop – who juggles with still-beating hearts for breakfast, who breaks dragons' backs as if they were twigs – regularly makes the god Osamodas grind his teeth, sharp as they may be (Iop admittedly does have a rather personal sense of humour). They previously left each other a few fragments of millennial dust on these words:

"Osamodas, tell me... Is it true that your divine self is naked under those rags?"

In actual fact, Osamodas and his disciples are dressed in authentic training clothing cut from the hides of their enemies... And there's not an ounce of funny stuff about that, at least in the eyes of the gods. It was enough to stifle a long sigh.

It was therefore a first-rate vacuum of space, the likes of which are come across once during a cosmic existence, that stretched out before Osamodas's eyes. The void. A sign. A star gravitating around the sign in a corner of the universe that was completely unknown to him.

That's hardly surprising: he'd had to walk for a long time to dispel the god Iop's humour. As usual, he'd set off alone, surrounded by his three dragons. But this time, he could feel that an unusual elation accompanied him and his beasts. He was experiencing the omen of events that were to remain etched into cosmic history. He was right!

Helioboros, his white dragon, and Ouronigride, his black dragon, were both in an impulsive mood, and flying through space in pursuit of one another, quite a terrifying spectacle for anyone who wasn't accustomed to it. Spiritia, the multicoloured dragon, stayed on his shoulder, whistling through his thick lips a melody well known amongst multicoloured dragons. If the surroundings hadn't been so black and darkened, and so unsuitable for a game of hide and seek between dragons, the spectacle Osamodas and his creatures gave would have looked almost perky.

Contemplative, Osamodas leaned on the sign and inspected the fiery letters with a wary eye. He was waiting for the scraps of the future that he'd just seen to crystallise in the present. The round rock revolved around him.

Suddenly, Ouronigride the Black snapped his jaws shut and a spray of dark lightning spread out into space: he'd narrowly missed the brilliant feather adorning Helioboros's tail... Still, a few strands of immaculate white sparked in the black dragon's mouth. He chuckled. His only eye, wrinkled with malice, grew wide with surprise: Helioboros, furious, tried to spur his left side! To dodge, he performed a sort of caper – moreover, he was surprised that he was capable of such a preposterous but lifesaving jolt – then pirouetted with a growl. The immaculate lightning sprung from Helioboros's nostrils heated his ribs: in other words, he came close! While the white dragon was getting ready to charge once more, Ouronigride escaped towards Osamodas.

The black dragon started whirling around the rock at his master's feet, closely followed by Helioboros.

Both dragons now traced out increasingly tighter circles, contracting their bodies, space, and time.

The first tried to shake off the second. They were zooming past with dizzying speed. The rock was glowing, and a muffled whistling rose from it as it warmed. It was now just incandescent magma. The molten crust was pierced, and a now-piercing whistle rose from it...

It was just then that Osamodas gave Spiritia a flick. The multicoloured dragon understood and immediately rushed towards the rock, wrapping himself around it to protect it. An explosion of light and shadow spread throughout the universe.

Osamodas raised an eyebrow. A new world was born. He heard the other gods come running to see it... The peace was over... He stifled another sigh.

92.subTitleId: The Martial Art of the Pandawas
92.contentId:
In the olden days, it was hardly rare for the Pandawa elders to offer generous libations to their goddess, the aptly-named Pandawa. Moreover, some intellectuals in Amakna maintain that Pandawa was a divinity invented by the elders in order to excuse their excessive drinking.

What is absolutely certain is that at the end of the ceremonies, some Pandawas entered into a sort of trance due to the heady vapours of fermented bamboo... then they collapsed with all their weight.

In a fraternal rush, their drinking companions... the faithful... did not hesitate to carry the most stumbling of them to their humble dwellings.

This is where history meets legend: we do not really know if they were assaulted but drunken hallucinations or by evil creatures from the surroundings, but the Pandawas always gave battle on the way home.

Wild gesticulations and smacks thrown blindly are thus at the very heart of Pandawas' self-defence techniques. Based on using axes and shields as pavises, these techniques developed over the course of time thanks to the constant devotion of the inhabitants of Pandala. Those who practised these techniques, called Pandawushukas, trained under the guidance of a master in Dojos specially designed for this purpose.

In addition to the original Pandawushu, four styles of Pandawushu were born. Each of these four styles was influenced by the Quadramental Breeze. The Pandawushukas each cultivated the predominance of one element at the root of their art, which influenced their resistances and the type of injuries they inflict... This also means that they can choose their element of preference, unlike other fighters...

The Masters

The Master of Air sits in Aerdala Village.

The Master of Earth sits in Terrdala Village.

The Master of Water sits in Akwadala Village.

The Master of Fire sits in Feudala Village.

The Ranks

Each school uses the traditional system of ranks.

Ikwa: 1st degree

Nikwa: 2nd degree

Sankwa: 3rd degree

Yonkwa: 4th degree

Gokwa: 5th degree

Rokwa: 6th degree

Ranks may be presented to the Pandala Dojo Master every Saturday.
