Ten gods gathered around Osamodas. Ten well-known gods who had all heard the song of the new world. As is custom amongst the gods, each of the ten gods was about to give him a gift.

If only you'd seen the two dragons Ouronigride and Helioboros taking centre stage on either side of the world like shining pillars, one black and the other white!

If only you'd seen the blueish curls winding slowly around this new world, and Spiritia gently clasping it between his rings!!!

If only you'd seen it... If only you were a god. If only! You'd need to be a god likely to get near Osamodas: his aura is so powerful that it repels all beings of small stature, which keeps Osamodas safe from annoyances. "All those minor gods who dream of climbing the ladder of the pantheon... deserve to be slowly torn to pieces by Tofus!" This remark, proclaimed by the god to anyone who wanted to hear it, repelled any lingering nuisances.

Nine gods have been able to approach Osamodas and his dragons thus far. For now, four of them surrounded him: Sram, hooded in the thick, dark curls of his cape, whose teeth alone gleamed like pale crescent moons. Sadida, stuck in a sacrificial pose, shreds of light hanging from his painted mask. Enutrof, the dragon of flames and gold who never stops burning or melting. Lastly, Xelor: his strikes have hammered many a skull and sounded many the death knell in the past; the same would be so in the future.

Suddenly, a sort of gurgling, half organic, half metallic, could be heard... "What's that sound? Could it be the swinging of Xelor's Clock rumbling again?!" Iop said as he arrived.

With his muscles protruding, Iop cast a disparaging look at Xelor.

"Your armour seems rusty, splendid warrior!" replied Xelor with detachment. "Is the metal of your armour crumpled, or one of your muscles, maybe?" he added.

"Heads it's Iop, tails it's Xelor" interrupted Ecaflip to prevent the discussion from taking an angry turn. The feline god who reigns over luck and chance took a coin from his pocket and smiled through his whiskers.

"All you need to do is tell your followers to pray to you better!" exclaimed Eniripsa, the goddess of healing and remedies. And the protector goddess Feca went one step further: "Most off all, you should tell them that 'please squash that Crackrock-head, oh please god Iop' and 'quickly mummify the god Xelor, I beg you' aren't prayers inspired by true devotion!"

"That's enough, my friends!" said the goddess of archers, the beautiful, impressive Cra. "This world has just been born; it deserves our attention... at least the same attention as our companions are giving it."

Osamodas, Sram, Sadida, Enutrof and Xelor were all looking at the world, their eyes full of cupidity.

"Does this world even have a consciousness?" asked Eniripsa.

"The consciousness of a newborn; it's just been created..." replied Osamodas. "I was waiting... for us to all be together. Botching the task that awaits us is out of the question!"

Eniripsa didn't expect this sort of comeback. She finds the situation strange to say the least: since when do the gods of black magic create worlds? They're better at destroying things!

She looked fixedly at Osamodas, with Sram and Xelor at his side. From what she can tell, Sram was smiling at her amicably, all of his teeth showing.

As for Xelor, it was bust-up bustling in the bandages! He may well hide the fact he's a mummy, he vanishes into dust at the slightest movement. Even worse: he gets it everywhere! A truly powdery scourge, full to the brim with enough mushrooms to give you a lifelong allergy (that's Eniripsa's opinion, in any case).

Osamodas remained silent. He was thinking: "Creating many varied species, winged ones, ones with feet, ones with feathers, thrown together any old how... only to see them wiped out in a cataclysm several thousand years later, all because of a careless mistake by the god-who-picks-his-teeth-with-his-dagger-while-receiving-an-offering! Anything but that! Not like last time!!! Not a chance! This time, it'll be order and method!"

"God Iop! Your blasé attitude has cost us a great deal in the past... Last time we created a world, you abandoned it to the mercy of the hazards of the universe. And a meteorite crashed into it. Obliterated! Annihilated! Did you even think of the souls? You know how I worry about souls, don't you, god Iop!?"

Iop raised an eyebrow. What was up with old Osamodas? Given his mood, it'd best not to argue too much... but still! The meteorite story last time wasn't really his fault. And it was at the other end of the universe, a small nothing of a blue world. It's true that he let a whole load of roughly reptilian creatures get roasted there – that's small fry! What's more, as far as he knew, the world in question was much better off without them. In reality, Osamodas was jealous. But of what, for good heavens? Iop had already been asking himself that question for a while. He drummed the sheath of his sword somewhat phlegmatically, a sign that he was a tad irritated.

A discomforted silence fell over the assembly of the gods! Enutrof was throwing small circles of flame vacantly and Sadida was ensuring they were sufficiently far away from his leafy headdress. Sram was still smiling (well, showing his teeth). Xelor was trying to hold back a nascent bout of coughing, while Eniripsa wasn't relaxing her watchfulness: the mummy god's stench reaching her nose was out of the question.

The goddess Feca was polishing her shield to the bzoing-bzoing sounds the goddess Cra was making with the string of her bow. Feca had arrived last, all ruffled. Ecaflip had gotten close to Iop unnoticed, and was rolling a coin between his fingers. From there, he could separate Osamodas and Iop if need be...

"There you are, I'm finally ready... So, shall we form this circle?" exclaimed the goddess Feca. With a smile on her lips and admiring her shield, she hadn't been paying attention to anything that had just happened.

"Let's come together and let the circle be!" said the goddess Cra, seizing the opportunity to lighten the mood... And the circle of the ten gods was formed.

"Through our presence, our breath and our voice, we give fire, earth, air and water to this world. Every creature that lives there shall be subject to the law of these four elements: we shall decide on the strengths and weaknesses of every one...

May those who serve black magic stand by Ouronigride the Black!

May those who serve white magic stand by Helioboros the White!

May Spiritia the Sparkling unite our wishes into a single will!"

Eniripsa stepped forward and said:

"My disciples of Eniripsa shall be beings of keen intellect, and the flame of the white fire shall burn in their spirits. May mountains burst through the earthly crust, and may their slopes be bathed in light and warmth. Eniripsas shall live there and gather flowers, plants and rocks necessary for their healing mixtures and concoctions..."

"Intelligence!? May the disciples of Xelor with their sharp minds be equally endowed! May they kindle the black fire and may the black fire kindle them in return... I give them the arid deserts, they shall bask in the dryness and shall play with time."

"I want as much for my Feca disciples, who shall be just as intelligent! They shall be the protectors of the white fire; the white fire shall be their guide and the animals shall place their trust in them. May sun-filled meadows be created, and may they be given to them!"

"For two disciples of the white fire, two disciples of the black fire! Disciples of Osamodas, you shall be like me! Your intellect shall be formidable, your resistance stupefying! You shall live near volcanoes and inside sulphur mines! You shall be respected by dragons, and creatures shall come running to your call!"

Iop burst out laughing, a booming laugh, and roared:

"Disciples of Iop, your blood shall run red! You shall draw your power from the fire, the earth or the air, whichever, provided they be white... May a thousand mountains be born! They shall resonate to your warrior chants, they shall welcome you to rest..."

"I like that idea! May it also be so for the disciples of Cra! They shall follow the law of the air, but also that of the earth and the white fire. Their sight shall be piercing, may they live in the treetops, the mountain peaks, or the treetops on mountain peaks!"

"I, Sadida, place my disciples under the protection of the black fire; may they serve it in return! And may they serve the black air as much! They shall feed off the water and earth, and shall live in the forests. Intelligent Sadidas, you shall create obedient creatures that are loyal and deadly. To this nascent world, I bequeath a compendium of trees, mosses and plants..."

Satisfied, Sadida snickered... And Ecaflip called out:

"Ecaflips! Your spells, straight from the white earth, shall equal your strength! May mountains and forests spring up, may they be a home for you, a shelter, a battlefield commensurate with your claws!"

With a hoarse voice, Enutrof said:

"They shall use the black magic... my adventurous Enutrofs... They shall have phenomenal luck... siphoned from the abysses and depths... and over their hearts I shall blow! As distant as they may be in the belly of the earth, distant from all life, they shall never break... never!"

Finally, Sram murmured:

"Robbers, pilferers, shoplifters, purse snatchers, plunderers and cheaters! Srams, my disciples, I bequeath you agility and strength. I make you fast like the black air and lovers of the black earth. Its plant adornments shall conceal you, its rocky trappings shall hide you... you shall be invisible to all eyes... except mine!"

Osamodas clapped:

"It's time to name this world!" he exclaimed light-heartedly.

"Have you thought of something?" asked Iop.

"Indeed! I found this world, which will be called 'Osamodia'!"

"Found? Does that mean you didn't create it?" asked Eniripsa, taken aback.

"And by what right would it bear your name?" thundered the god Iop.

"It would be an immense privilege to grant you that! Why not 'Xelor's World' in that case?"

"Xelor would appreciate such a gesture, god Iop, and I'd forever be grateful to you!" proclaimed Xelor.

"I'll think about it again in a hundred thousand billion years, god Xelor," muttered Iop.

"'Sexifocsee' is a name that I think suits nicely," said Sram.

"What the...?" choked the goddess Feca.

"The initials of each of the ten gods are brought together!" he replied proudly.

"I might remind you this divine assembly that we already reign over other worlds... named Esscofixee and Secoxisfee..." replied Enutrof.

"And the music of these names hurts my eardrums, god Sram," the goddess Cra retorted.

"And why not the 'World of Ten'?"

"..."

Unanimously, the gods repeated "World of Ten". And the world was born. It now had a name, was populated with beings and creatures, and aroused the interest of the most powerful gods in the universe, promising an epic, heroic destiny – far from unremarkable, anyway.

103.contentId:
Osamodas's three dragons breathed magic into the World. The black dragon inspired dark magic, the white dragon bright magic. Three black dragons and three white dragons were conceived and incarnated in the world; they formed the origin of all of Amakna's dragons.

As for the multicoloured dragon, he filled the air, earth, water and fire with magical powers. Four elemental dragons had been created.

World of Ten... This world needed magic worthy of the name, draconic magic. Ouronigride the Black and Helioboros the White filled their lungs, and their husky song suddenly rang out. Imbued with the black fire and the white fire, it swept through the world like thunder.

Their breath carried along great old souls, those of three black dragons and three white dragons. They descended on the world, six tapered, glistening plumes formed a circle that seemed to dissolve almost immediately. Once they had arrived at the tops of the highest mountains in the world, each soul set off in a different direction, their strident wakes forming a six-pointed star.

One of the souls was submerged in the rays of the first morning light, the purest of the dawning day. It became opalescent and trembled: the dragon soul had already abandoned its celestial envelope by descending into the material world; it now abandoned its second skin, wreathed with starlight. It shook itself to make the last shreds of ether clinging to it disappear. Flesh and muscle appeared at last. For the ninth time in his celestial existence, Dardondakal, the one who would go on to be known as the Wise, was incarnated!

He answered Helioboros, the lord of his race. The two other white souls shed their skins in turn. They set off skimming the land, taking in a gulp of air here and there; they flew over the sea, the foam streaming over their soon-to-be-scaly skin. These dragons were famous, known by the names of Croulaklakoss and Gresgaoulian. The World of Ten now had three white dragons.

"A piece of night for me, a piece of underground depths for you. That leaves a piece of abyss for you..." The shadowy colossus growled: a thick darkness seeped from his barely formed mouth. His flesh thickened slowly, and he tensed the muscles in his back to tear apart the now-slimy envelope – the remainder of his divine existence – that was hindering his movements. The two other dragon souls agreed to the division proposed by the one who would later be known as Grougalorasalar the Ashen.

One of the souls shrieked and dived into the depths of the earth. But the other one, which had to sink into the black waters, disobeyed. It glided along the surface of the land and water, voracious... and it set off to find the only thing that attracted it on earth. Because this dragon soul, more than anything else, was hungry; it dreamt of devouring a living being's spirit...

The white and black dragons were thus incarnated. The whole time that Ouronigride and Helioboros were singing, Spiritia joined them, pointed his mouth towards the world, breathing colour into it.

It started pulsating, and the water, the fire, the earth and the air were no longer black or white; they each took on a colour. The water became blue, the same blue as Aguabrial, its guardian; the fire glowed red in the image of Ignemikhal, the scarlet dragon; the earth was draped in green, for such are the emerald scales of Terrakourial; and the air became transparent, like the crystalline body of Aerafal.

Each of these four dragons, young but already powerful, is the guardian of one of the four elements.

104.contentId:
Time passed, and mortal generations followed on, one after another. The gods wondered: dragons had been incarnated in the World of Ten, but no Primordial Dofus had appeared. Sram and Enutrof decided to give fate a helping hand, calling on the most useful talents of the demiurge Sadida.

"What a lovely scene!" marvelled Sram, gazing at the white and black dragons' flight. He picked up some stellar matter, rolling it into a ball to make a kind of cosmic cushion. He sprawled on it nonchalantly, scratched his chin and said to himself: "If only I could grow out this beard, I would look truly classy..." Then his thoughts turned to recent events and their repercussions on the Krosmoz. He was bound to be there for a while.

As always happened when he was thinking, his head started to itch, but on the inside. Yet there were no ideas bouncing around trying to get free, nor sudden strokes of genius. Make no mistake: Sram was a master strategist... when the time was right. Right now, though, he wasn't on top form. There were only two possible explanations. Either an black astral larva had slithered inside his skull, or else his conscience had sprung to life for some niggling reason... Just then, a voice echoed inside his cranial cavity. To tell the truth, it could barely be described as a voice: it was a murmur, or a whisper, or just a light breeze that was tickling him...

"Do you know if there are any?"

"What are you talking about?"

"Don't play dumb! The hearts of the world! The living symbols of peace and harmony! Without them, nothing could exist... They exceed even the powers of the gods!"

"There will be! I swear by my daggers, there will be..."

"Who are you talking to, Sram?"

It was Enutrof, the dragon-god with a bright, scaly body. He had come up behind Sram and was now settling down with his wings spread out in a large semi-circle.

"It's nice of you to come and offer your wisdom here, Enutrof, but I don't need your help!"

Enutrof paid no attention to this declaration by the bony god.

"You know, I think I know what you're talking about... Guess what. Down there, right down at ground level, I saw a fire dragon and a water dragon fighting, each casting spells of its own element... I'll bet you anything that an earth dragon and an air dragon are nearby... Now, you know as well as I do that if elemental dragons choose to live in this world, it is highly likely that, soon enough, it will be home to Dofus! It would be for the best, too. Without Dofus, the world will slip into chaos...

"What do you want? The rest of us gods are at the mercy of these dragons and their good will... With all due respect, Enutrof..."

"Indeed! Such are the laws of the Krosmoz... But before that, we need these dragons' hearts to beat with ardent love... And as far as I know, black dragons are not known for being flirtatious! They'd rather pick fights and rip one another to shreds than court or look for love. As for elemental dragons, all they want is to have fun! White dragons... Ah, I know white dragons. They're full of lofty sentiments, nobility, purity and the like, but they do not know passion... All we need is an ounce of sensuality, a single droplet of indulgence – that would do it! Without it, we could be waiting for eons for one of these dragons to give us a Dofus! And we've already waited long enough."

Sram rested his chin on his long, slender fingers. He glanced listlessly into space, and his gaze fell upon Sadida, who was leading a horde of tiny creatures in a merry dance, hips swaying, arms swinging...

"I see one of us isn't preoccupied with the fate of the world!" said Enutrof huffily.

"But his skills might just help us, you know..." said Sram. "Follow me!"

Sram and Enutrof sidled up to Sadida. The masked god continued to dance whilst watching them from the corner of his eye.

"Do you have a minute, Sadida?"

"I'm right in the middle of a summoning ritual! I can't stop now! It's like asking the rain to stop falling!"

"I summon things all the time and I can stop whenever I like..." Enutrof murmured to Sram.

"Yeah, but you pay no heed to nature and its cycles," hissed Sram in reply, before addressing Sadida out loud once again.

"O Sadida, do you want to know what we need? We need you to bewitch the dragons of the World of Ten... You must know a good enchantment to breathe some life into those bags of scales!"

"Why would I do that?" frowned Sadida as he danced.

"If you don't, this world might suffer the same fate as the last one... You know, the meteorite? The blue world that Osamodas was talking about?"

"You mean the one that wasn't protected by any Dofus? Do you suppose the same thing could happen with the World of Ten? Troublesome. Troublesome indeed." This time, Sadida stopped dancing.

"But we could give the dragons a push in the right direction," said Enutrof. "Not boasting, but I know quite a lot about draconic psychology. If you can get them to feel the noblest emotion of all, that of love, then we'll have shedloads of Dofus on our hands!"

Enutrof remained quiet for a few moments to let Sadida reflect on these words, then added:

"Maybe you could create some dolls in their image..."

"Bewitch them to feel love..." the leafy god murmured. "And maybe even make a creature capable of charming dragons and bring it to life? That sounds feasible."

"That's what I like to hear, Sadida!" Sram exclaimed.

It didn't take long for Sadida's nimble fingers to create ten dolls with various appearances. Sadida's creatures proved to be true weapons of seduction... The god clothed each one in a tight outfit of Kralove fabric, and carefully equipped them with love rods, which had already proved highly effective on male Kraloves, who fell head over heels in love the moment they smelt their fragrance. With a little luck, Sadida told himself, the rods would have the same effect on dragons...

But more than that, the dolls acted as mirrors of love... When the first dragon caught sight of a doll, it paid no attention whatsoever to the iridescent Kralove skin and the love rod. Instead, it fell for the reflections of its own heart, as though the doll standing before it were none other than part of its own soul. For a creature as narcissistic as a dragon, it was a dream come true! This magical love was so strong and so pure that it was able to condense in the form of an egg.

Of the ten dragons, six were seduced: one by one, they fell head over heels in love. Thus the six Primordial Dofus came into being...

105.contentId:
The Divine Clock created by Xelor is set on the heartbeats of the Dofus. But Rushu, the Lord of the Demons, somehow feels he got a raw deal...

They all agree, Xelor will be the one to put into action the breakdown of time. He lifts up a tail of his cloak and draws his portable sandglass he always carries with him. This instrument enables him to freeze time. It can be very useful to fix the hitches of the time frame when dates are fraying to end up being devoured by Timemites and chronologies curl like the antennas of an old Tempousfouguite. When all this happens, the Time Silkworms, especially tamed by Xelor himself, spin the precious time thread which will be used to mend the rips.

Xelor decrees a truce of a couple thousands grains of sidereal dust which start dropping through the narrow neck of his sandglass. The swift passage of the Krosmoz stops for a brief moment, and there is the sound of a big croaking before disappearing.

Silence will calm down the cosmic and divine fluctuations going through the Universe. (We must say that Iop and Osamodas, and even all the gods of the World of Ten have completely opposite principles. However, there must be a celestial harmony, and a perfect divine understanding so that time passes by serenely).

If Xelor had a gong he would have rung it. But he has to accept the fact he's in the middle of nowhere and he won't ever find any gong around here. After having a look around the assembly of the gods, he fixes his attention on the stellar vault. He's absorbed by something that only he can see. And suddenly, he raises his arms up in the air in a flight of wrappings and luminous dust, which always makes the goddesses let out small cries of terror. This part of the ritual is totally useless but it makes the whole difference...

He pinches the inert matter of the surrounding space. Then, he makes his forefinger twirl as if he were spooling an invisible thread. He undoes a cocoon of stellar matter from it. The latter immediately becomes a myriad of tiny eggs as soon changed into a cloud of golden mayflies.

Mayflies, gathered side by side, are designing the body of a Clock which seemed made of a living bronze matter. In a gesture, Xelor points to the inside of the Clock and four transparent butterflies rush inside it. The magic butterflies are hitched up to the clock mechanism. After a couple flaps of wings, they go up into the air and the mechanism starts. There is a ticking sound. To make sure the Tempousfouguite butterflies are motivated and concentrate on their task, Xelor appoints a Time devourer frog as their assistant. Of course, there are some hiccups, and the devourer got more than one indigestion... but after a few adjustments, Xelor finally sets the Clock according to the pace of the heartbeats of the Dofus. It now marks out perfect seconds.

It's now time for Xelor to seal the body of the Clock covering it with eleven purple gems. From now on, time passes. The hitching up of butterflies teased by the frog that keeps on pestering them is a great advantage. Indeed, there's no need to wind up the Clock. Of course, from time to time, a butterfly will have to be replaced but Tempousfouguites aren't lacking.

The outstanding fact is that within the bowels of the Divine Clock is written every single thing happening in the world. Anything. Anywhere. Any time. Indeed, the Clock is made of divine mayflies. And each of these insects is born and dies in an instant. Then they are reborn like miniature phoenixes. This spontaneous combustion engraves each event in the heart of the Clock itself.

Like a bulimic archive, the Clock records all the actions of everyone, from the first cry to the last breath. And when souls come out of their physical body to pay tribute to their god, a light tinkle sound can be heard...

Quite happy that his Clock gives hours, minutes and seconds, Xelor decides to divide the dial into eleven months and four seasons. Summer was created to excite the blazing divinities Iop, Ecaflip and Cra; Falls to shower praise upon the goddess Feca and god Xelor; Winter to magnify the intuition of the gods Sram, Enutrof and Osamodas; and finally Spring to celebrate the serenity shown by both Eniripsa and Sadida.

Xelor's Clock is set on the regular heartbeats of the six Dofus scattered throughout the world. Each of the six eggs beats like a sleeping heart and the echo of the heartbeats is reverberating everywhere... All gods are admiring the Clock. All but one!

Tactlessness or will of the ten, Rushu, the Lord of the demons didn't get his share of time... Mad with rage, He took the Clock and scratched the gems with his claws. He scratched them so much that a twelfth month could be added. It will become Descendre, the month of the demons. Through the cracks of the stones, he put black slimy larvae so that they'd slow down the butterflies during the evil month.

To make it fair, the gods accepted the month of Descendre. Xelor, the great spirit who created the Clock, was appointed Great Warden of Past and Present Times. He then appointed a protector for each month of the year.

Rushu argued that only one of his people could prevent the larvas from rotting inside the Clock. He imposed Djaul, the great splashing boy, as the protector of the month of Descendre. The only task this demon has to do is to make dark Descendre days the longest of the year.

And the Clock recorded the following list of the protectors appointed by the gods:

Solar, human hero, master of cuttings, protector of Flovor.

Silvosse, human hero, master of cuttings, protector of Flovor.

Menalt, centaur warrior of the Order of the Valiant Heart, protector of Martalo.

Silouate, the Minotoror, protector of Aperirel.

Rosal, master of flowers, protector of Maysial.

Sumens, devotee of god Enutrof, protector of Junssidor.

Hecate, female minor demon, protector of Jullier.

Pouchecotthe fruitcake, protector of Frauguctor.

Ravalthe terrible, protector of Septangel.

Maïmanethe stabilizer, protector of Octolliard.

Brumaire, the Dark Bleeder, protector of Novamaire.

Djaul, demon, follower of Rushu, protector of Descendre.

106.contentId:
Among all lore and legends, one deserves to be mentioned here: the misadventure of Aguabrial. This is the story of how the water dragon was almost trapped by Djaul, a tale which would have far-reaching and long-lasting repercussions on the destiny of the entire world.

Ten years had slipped by since guardians were chosen to assist Xelor. They all carried out their duties with nothing less than zeal. Only one among them was consumed with venom and envy: Djaul, the demon appointed by Rushu. He was an aggressive sort, and although the other protectors tolerated his presence, they never showed him any mark of respect. Indeed, some even thought him a usurper. Only Brumaire seemed not to despise him. As for Maimane and what he had said about temperance, it rankled the demon to no end! The protector of Descendre thus wandered the World of Ten alone. Each second passed under the watch of another protector only stoked the coals of his hatred. In his wanderings, he came to know the habits of each and every one of the world's creatures.

Quite fond of souls and the secrets they lock within, he was at ease spying on the lives and deeds of each. And at the end of the tenth year, he had seen many things, and had heard a great deal more.

One dark Octolliard night thick with shadows, he crept into the lair of the water dragon, Aguabrial. His master, Rushu, had instructed him on which paths to follow in order to reach the dragon's hideout. For as well as he knew the world, he had yet to discover a single one of the famous Dofus his master had told him about.

On this particular night, the autumn rains were even heavier than usual. Djaul had dashed halfway across the country to get to Aguabrial's grotto, sploshing through the cascading downpour. He entered the dragon's lair and waited for many hours, immobile in the shadows, hiding among stalagmites and blue-hued toads. The demon greedily eyed the hillock of gold in the middle of the lair while surveying the comings and goings of the dragon. After much time, he formulated a scheme: he would start by bewitching the rains falling around the grotto.

A very voluptuous water nymph emerged from the waters; the demon had made her incredibly beautiful. In the blink of an eye (and a few bats of the eyelashes), she had seduced the blue dragon. But would the dragon offer her a sacred egg as a token of his affection, as Djaul hoped?

Some weeks later, the demon's patience seemed about to be rewarded. A turquoise allure emanated from an oblong form poised at the peak of Aguabrial's hill of treasure. Could it be a Dofus? Djaul was much too far to say with certainty. Making full use of the shadows, the demon crawled slowly closer, and closer still, until... it WAS a Dofus! A turquoise Dofus! It certainly wasn't a black or a white Dofus, but Djaul was elated all the same. Rushu would be satisfied...

For an entire month, Djaul watched, through his proxy the water sprite, as the magic of the egg grew. She asked the dragon to ensure that the egg was constantly warmed by his magic breath, and the egg's powers continued to grow stronger and stronger. As for Aguabrial, he only saw stars.

Djaul's deception would have been perfect if only Ereziah Melkewel, an alchemist and friend of the dragon (as well as an excellent exorcist), hadn't poked his nose in...

Ereziah had come to ask the dragon's advice about an aqueous unbewitchment that was proving more difficult than expected. At the sight of the water sprite, he immediately suspected some demonic trickery. The sprite was a classic beauty: her brown tresses framed a finely-featured face with skin as pale as moonlight. Her blue eyes, her mischievous nose, her pearly lips... a linen tunic which clung tightly to the skin outlining her generous curves. What's more, she was a great cook... By Osamodas' three dragons, it was all much too good to be true! But Ereziah wasn't easy to disturb. He pretended to fall under the magic creature's charms, and promised to offer her jewellery that "only your beauty can equal in splendour". He also swore to his friend to return to see the precious Dofus and bestow on it a magical power.

"Why not?" Djaul thought. "The combination of dragon magic and alchemical magic couldn't hurt it. Quite the opposite! This Dofus would be one of the most powerful ever."

Ereziah came back the following day with a mysterious package. Under the curious eyes of Aguabrial, the water sprite, and Djaul, he unwrapped a strange sculpture: four heads with very large jaws attached to each other. He called them "Trip Trap Shackles", and explained that they were a very ancient magical mechanism, worthy of Xelor himself, created through the combined efforts of a goldsmith and a jeweller. The water sprite, having become a bit cheeky after a month of existence, got impatient and demanded to know where her magic present was.

"To be worthy of this present, you must make yourself more beautiful than you've ever been!" Ereziah told her.

Eager to obey, the sprite, with a crystal laugh, draped herself in blueish steam.

"You shall have your reward, beautiful sprite," Ereziah said silkily. "Place your hands in the magic jaws, and they'll wrap your wrists with the most beautiful bracelets that have ever existed." The innocent girl obeyed. The jaws closed upon her delicate wrists and adorned them with... manacles and chains!

"The thing about these magic bracelets," explained Ereziah, "is that they prevent you from drawing the energy you need to live. Tell me, dear heart, what is it, or rather, who is it, that you need to live?" Fallen to her knees, the sprite opened her mouth to answer, but couldn't find the strength. Aguabrial had started to object when Djaul, seeing his ruse was discovered, came out of the shadows. He rushed to the centre of the lair, but Ereziah blocked his way. In one quick motion, he unsheathed his scimitar and attacked. He'd have opened the exorcist's throat had Aguabrial not intervened. Djaul's blade instead gashed Ereziah's thigh. The dragon reared up to his full, frightening height before Djaul. The demon, seeing that all was lost, abandoned the Dofus and fled.

Djaul's enchantment was broken and Ereziah was hurt. Aguabrial, furious at having been deceived by a demon, shed a tear of rage, which fell upon Djaul's creature. The beautiful water sprite was revealed to in fact be a succubus in agony... Aguabrial finished the pitiful creature off by carrying her into a violent stream of water. Then he prepared to destroy the Dofus – in his eyes, a reminder of his folly. While Ereziah pleaded with him not to destroy it, the Dofus hatched. The shell flew away in pieces, and a jet of cerulean vapour appeared. Bolgrot was born, a birth brought on by Djaul's tricks and greediness.

Meanwhile, the actual Turquoise Dofus, which was part of the six primordial Dofus, was buried beneath the dragon's mountain of gold. The egg trembled. Its pulse became irregular. Nevermore would the Dofus beat in rhythm, and harmony no longer reigned over the world.

107.contentId:
According to the scholar Hel Munster, a simple flap of a moskito's wings can bring about a tempest on the other side of the world. When a demon tries to steal a Dofus, the first wave of darkness spreads across the world... But sometimes light is born of darkness! This is the story of how a new goddess entered the pantheon.

Djaul was running like the wind, through flooded fields and muddy forests. It turns out that trying to fool a blue dragon is rather dangerous. He had failed, and the results had been disastrous: the whole area was flooded under pouring rain. All this water had soon grown into torrents, rivers warning Aguabrial of his every move. How long had it been since he tried to fool the dragon? Impossible to tell... Isolated in the Aguabrial's den, Djaul had lost track of time. And the rain pouring down since Octolliard was flooding the landscape and erasing the course of the seasons. It was then that it occurred to Djaul to use his privilege as a protector and consult the Divine Clock.

It appeared at his request, each of its twelve purple gems glowing brightly. The demon turned to face it. As he squinted to read the date, he felt anger bubbling up inside. He could see now why the Novamaire rains seemed to have been going on so long...! Brumaire had cut into Descendre by sixteen days! Straight away, Djaul unleashed Descendre's icy chill upon the world. At least it would calm the waters for a time... For two weeks, the demon stayed in the darkness of the southern forests, ruminating on his failure until the end of Descendre, burying the land in snow and ice. By the last day of Descendre, he was ready to take his revenge.

That day, just like every year, Solar made for the heights of Amakna. He was about to proclaim the start of Javian and the beginning of a new year. Djaul was waiting for him, hidden in the shadows. On the eleventh stroke of midnight, the demon leapt forth and let his rage and fury explode. Solar was caught off guard by the attack but he fought like a warrior. The fight between the two protectors was so violent that traces can still be seen in the stones and rocks all around.

Solar collapsed, beaten to death. Victorious, Djaul hurled the corpse of the protector of Javian down the mountains of Amakna. This Descendre was to be one of the longest and harshest that the inhabitants of the World of Ten had ever known.

Famines, epidemics and pillaging devastated the land, And the inhabitants struggled to cope with the situation. Only the goddesses seemed to be paying attention to their disciples. Fecas and Cras could use white fire to stave off the cold. Eniripsas could count on their healing arts to keep themselves alive. As for the others, they were growing weaker and weaker every day. Adventurers who once stood tall and proud, glorious warriors, were now found on the roadside, dead from cold and exhaustion and covered up with ice.

One day, at last, a prophet came. He said he used to be a lumberjack, and that he was now spreading the good word of the goddess Sacrier. A new goddess? "Yes!", the prophet replied. "The needy are swearing their loyalty to her, giving her their suffering. And the goddess is helping them recover their strength and vigour..."

All over the world, people prayed for the torment to stop. But their prayers were no longer addressed to seemingly uncaring gods. Now they were for the goddess Sacrier, who seemed to be a goddess of compassion. Before, she had only had a hundred or so disciples, but now followers were flooding in. The strength that the goddess had given to her believers made up for the pain caused by the cold.

The faithful Sacriers walked from the Cania Plains to Amakna Harbour to convert those who were lost and in need. Later on, the prophet pronounced the following verses:

"We were five hundred, but with swift support

Grew to three thousand as we reached the port,

So that seeing us marching to that stage,

Those most terrified found new courage!"

(These lines became so famous they travelled far and wide and were adopted by a certain scribbler, much later and in another world... but that is another story!) Djaul, meanwhile, had followed the advent of the goddess with great interest. He was wondering how he could take advantage of the situation. Perched high up in the branches of a beech tree, he was observing the Sacriers' movements one day when he felt a hand grab him and pull him back violently.

Taken by surprise, Djaul tumbled downward, unable to catch hold of a branch. Dazed and winded by his fall, he saw Silvosse, protector of Flovor, standing in front of him, with his fists clenched on the handle of a huge hammer.

"Demon, my trees are freezing! And all because of you!! And you, Djaul the Flounderer, you think you can come and put your claws in the bark of my cherished trees? That's not how it works, I'm afraid! You see this one?” He pointed to the tree. "Well, it can no longer stand your presence in its branches... and neither can I!"

Djaul dodged Silvosse's mighty blow by the skin of his teeth. As the steel head of the hammer slammed into the ground, the snow all around it melted instantly.

108.contentId:
"Give way, Djaul! The month of Flovor starts right here, right now! Get out of my way and don't ever try to hinder Flovor! I really don't want to mix your blood together with the sap of my trees..." said Silvosse in a husky voice. Djaul stood up and headed south, still staggering.



At that moment, the gods were assembled to welcome the goddess Sacrier. "What did she do to deserve her place!?" Rushu shouted angrily. "You know perfectly well, Rushu. She simply has dedicated disciples who have faith in her," the god Iop answered quietly, before adding, "And they are growing in number every day."


"I demand evidence! She's not worthy! I know it!" Rushu screamed, pointing at the goddess, who remained impassive.


"No need for evidence," the god Iop replied, and before he could say another word, the goddess Sacrier took the Divine Clock in her hands.

She was holding it as if it were an oracle. Each second that passed was whispering the life of the world... She and the other gods heard the suffering and the terror of the inhabitants of Amakna. They were prey to the most terrible fears, and within the chorus of rising and falling moans and whimpers, the gods could sense something soft and serious, something close to solace. Full of sympathy, a tear rolled down the goddess's cheek and fell onto the Divine Clock. It seeped into the mechanism and slid over the time frog who croaked in surprise... The Clock seemed to come to life. It gave a sudden jolt, and space and time, past and present seemed to crumple...



At that very moment, Xelor predicted that Bonta and Brakmar, the rivals, would be destroyed during the war of the cities and that, thanks to the goddess's tear, they would be reborn from the chaos that History had thrown them into. Just this once, Xelor would not change this chronological anomaly: it was a second chance given to the two cities.

After a few moments of stunned silence, a satisfied grin spread over Rushu's face, and he strode out of the assembly hall. The World of Ten had just become the World of Eleven.

109.subTitleId: Little Treatise on the use of the Mystics.
109.contentId:
On the Gods and Their Origins

Where do gods come from? For the Eleven are not unique. They are not the only ones – far from it! Truth be told, they are swarming all around us, often completely ignored by mere mortals.

In one of his famous booklets, the Diis Ignotis, Hel Munster estimated their number at one thousand eight hundred and twenty-four. The famous theorist of the Quadramental Breeze maintains that the plethora of gods drift across the universe on this magical zephyr to the World of Ten. Naturally, just like all the other philosophers that specialise in deities, he has never been able to prove it.

His list of gods and goddesses includes loads of zany characters: the god of edible mushrooms, the god of putting Moskitos to sleep on summer nights, and the god of exciting dances for marsh worms (exciting for fish, that is), as well as gods who seem essential, such as the one who goes against all odds to magnify the strength of a hit or the effect of a spell tenfold, the one who can make trees grow faster, and the one who uses monsters' remains to make useful implements, beautiful trinkets and items which will make the lives of adventurers everywhere that little bit easier.

In short, we live alongside a multitude of gods, always on the watch, ready to fly into the arms of the first living being to give them the slightest hint of attention (it's all they need at first). The goal behind such an unnecessary show of affection, of course, is to change the aforementioned hint of attention into genuine FAITH. Indeed, a god's debut is quite modest. As badly as they want to find fame as awesome, all-powerful divinities, when it comes to making mortals spare them a prayer, the only means they really have at their disposal are intuitions, signs and disembodied voices. And lots of mortals don't even believe in those things! Clearly, becoming a famous god is hard work.

Take the goddess Sacrier for instance. She wasn't born yesterday... She managed to work her way into the tight circle of really useful gods...

When she first started her rise to power, one thing was crystal clear: the World of Ten was a world of suffering. A whole range of suffering, at that: pain, devastation, torment, torture and so on (in fact, it's really weird that none of the others gods had noticed). When gods are looking for believers, the idea is simple: to make a name for yourself, you've got to find a gap in the market. And the goddess Sacrier understood that better than anyone!

She chose an apprentice lumberjack. With an axe in his hands, he was like lightning: he never hit the same spot twice. He was so clumsy that he had sliced the tops off three of his fingers in his first week. Every day, the goddess would come next to him, teeny-tiny and invisible. She waited patiently for him to reach the end of his tether and scream with pain or anger. This moment finally came. While he was holding his head with his bleeding hands and hitting it against a trunk, she whispered in his ear:

If before you struck the wood

You hit yourself as hard as you could,

Through your veins would course

adrenaline – a hefty dose!

Just imagine what good,

Such a dose would do!

You'd climb the greatest hills with ease,

With iron lungs and sturdy knees

And split those mighty, towering trees. Clean in two!

The apprentice lumberjack followed the voice's advice. His axe fell. His fingers were suddenly healed, and the log split in half from top to bottom. He then heard the voice inside his head:

Call yourself a victim no longer,

What doesn't kill you makes you stronger,

It's the only way to inspire!

Sacred are your cries, Sacrier!

As the voice he heard was a female voice, the Lumberjack started to believe in a goddess called Sacrier. Every day, he rained down blows on his fingers, head and arms, and his strength increased beyond all belief. He started to chant prayers of his own creation: "Joy of receiving, pleasure of giving," or "Offer one's right cheek, hit with a straight left." At this point, the goddess Sacrier knew he was ready to become a prophet...

All through the terrible winter brought about by Solar's death, the lumberjack went to preach in the countryside. The peasants had suffered so much that they listened eagerly to the stranger, who promised to replace their suffering with a new strength.

His prayers spread faster than whooping cough. Very soon, his believers were legion. The goddess was added to the Pantheon. From now on, the World of Ten would be called the World of Eleven...

110.subTitleId: I am Mystic and I'm loving it
110.contentId:
Prophets



If we could listen to what's going through the Prophets' minds, we would hear many, many messages rushing in. They have passed the stage of intuition. They're addicted to signs. They open a book of magic spells at random and find an answer to their questions. Sometimes it's a Bow Wow that shows you the way. Wishes suddenly granted? Pure coincidence? Any philosopher will tell you there's no such thing as coincidence. A prophet never thanks emptiness. And god grows. When the prophet lights up a holy candle or burns an incense stick, he feeds his god. If he makes an offering, or adds another rock to a cairn, the god then pulls out all the stops! Voices echo in the prophet's head – it's party time! Though the prophet preaches like mad and often becomes a martyr, he's passed on his faith at least a hundred times. That's enough.


When he starts, the god clings to his new converts like glue. He listens to their prayers and quickly grants their wishes. With time, he becomes powerful...

The World, the Gods



The books of the ancestors are probably right: as soon as this World was created, the ten gods each blessed it with a kind deed. I don't see why it should be any different anyway. Trust an old erudite man, the gods were better off doing it. Even if the gods usually get along reasonably well, they don't hesitate to fight over attracting new souls that will be faithful and devoted to them! By the way, a World recently created is a very attractive place for a soul. Quite often, very old souls decide to incarnate themselves there, keeping full conscience of their past lives. That's why our World, in spite of its young age, counts skilled and expert warriors, as well as alchemists, smithmagi who have perfectly mastered their art, and exceptional beings that the old legends still talk about.

Cults and Faiths



At the World's beginning, cults were a lot more numerous than today. Devotion to one unique god even circulated among some magi and priests.


I shall allow myself to digress a little here, as I'd like to talk about the physiognomy of the beings of our World. Oh! If you've read this far then it's probably because you're wondering why Cras have pointy ears, why Osamodas have forked tails, and why Sadidas have bushy heads. Why are Innkeepers so fat and why don't they have the features of a Sram or a Xelor? Well, regarding the overweight innkeeper, an excess of beer probably has something to do with it. But another thousand questions are yet to be asked.


One thing is certain: down here (and the rules are the same throughout the entire Universe), faith conditions physical appearance. Indeed, the faith given by a soul to a divinity has an influence on its mortal coil. The former tends to take up the features (both physical and behavioural) of the venerated divinity.

What about blood ties, you may wonder? Easy. If followers from different cults got married, they wouldn't have children in the biological sense. Their children would be akin to spiritual sons and daughters. A soul that felt an affinity with the values of its "parents" could decide to become their son or daughter. You must understand that an incarnated soul can choose to be a disciple of a god OR wait a while and reflect on its real faith. In this second case, it would incarnate with a humanoid appearance and a child would be born! It would now be free to become a disciple or to remain an atheist. In the latter case, it would keep its humanoid appearance. A soul that decided to incarnate within a long lineage of Iops would embrace the Iop faith and would most certainly look like a young Iop.

Whereas a soul that decided to incarnate itself within a long lineage of innkeepers would have all its teenage years to decide to which cult it wanted to devote its terrestrial life to. This decision-making period ends at puberty. Once the stream of spiritual hormones has gone, you can no longer embrace a cult – save a miraculous conversion recognised by the god himself.


Many a time I have heard this question: Herdegrize, where are we born? I always answer that it depends on the choice of the soul... It may decide to incarnate itself in an egg that will then hatch, be it in a Prespic's nest, or as an Evil Rose, how could I possibly know? What really matters is that beings come to life!

Praying to Your God



Followers who want to pay homage to their god would be well advised to go to the city of Astrub. There, they can leave their offerings at their god's feet. They can do the same in one of the temples of Amakna. No need for luxurious gifts! To please your god, just think about the gift they gave to the world a long time ago. You shall then offer your god something that exists as a result of this gift. It's only fair!

112.contentId:
I. Who Are We?: p.3

II. Calling on a Serian: p. 4

III. Joining the Clan: p. 7

IV. Clan Ethics: p. 12

V. Clan History: p. 16

WHO ARE WE?

The Serian-Kerm Clan is a group of mercenaries devoted to public service.

We bring together adventurers from all guilds and faiths, with the shared passion for mercenary life.

Ethically neutral, we consider all contract offerings without preconceived notions about the person seeking our services.

Within our clan, we learn to combine wisdom and power through specific training in order to best embody our values.

We make our home in the city of Astrub, north of the city Zaap. Our lair is hidden between the two large cities of Bonta and Brakmar.

CALLING ON A SERIAN

Feel free to call on us, whoever you are. We'll be glad to help you on an adventure, find a rare item or resource, spy on an enemy, defeat a Perceptor, or even eliminate your greatest opponent... For the right price, of course.

Attacking Someone:

100 K per power circle of the person attacked, plus 50 K per power circle of the Serian.

If two Serians are hired to attack the person, the fee is cumulative.

The Serian must ask the hiring party if he or she wishes to send a message or remain anonymous.

Attacking a Perceptor:

1,000 K per power circle of the Perceptor attacked, plus 50 K per power circle of the Serain or Serains.

The Serian must ask the hiring party if he or she wishes to send a message or remain anonymous.

Guide Services:

100 K per power circle of the Serian, per hour. Billed in 10-minute increments.

The guide service consists of the Serian participating in combat to help the client, either in training or to seek treasure. The Serian keeps all items he or she finds.

If the client wishes to keep the items found by the Serian, the Serian may decide (or not) to sell the items to the client. This may be discussed in advance, during the contract negotiations.

Finding Items:

If a Serian is hired to find one or more items or resources, the Serian may set his or her own fee. The fee must be based on the average price of the desired item(s) or resource(s) plus wages for the labour involved (approximately 20% of the price of the item(s) and/or resource(s)).

Dungeons:

Fee structure the same as for guide services. To be negotiated based on the dungeon.

Other:

To be determined based on the request... It is difficult to set fees for spying, for example. It is up to the Serian to decide.

Of course, these prices are merely indicative, and may change at any time depending on the Serian hired or for any other reason.

All our contracts are executed by our members who have reached the rank of Serian or Grand Serian.

In rare cases, Master Serians may also intervene.

To hire us, you may place an order directly with one of our clan, or ask a Master Serian, who will find you a mercenary suited to your needs.

JOINING THE CLAN

To join the clan, you will need to be interviewed by one of the Master Serians, who will question you about the clan and your reasons for applying. You will need to convince the Master to grant you our training.

You will also need to make a donation. It goes without saying that the donation must be valuable and must be best suited to you. It is up to you to figure out who you are...

Arm yourself with patience, as it will be your greatest ally. Joining the clan and moving up its ranks cannot be done in just seven days.

Neophyte

Once hired, you'll begin your training as a Neophyte.

You will then be trained by Masters, who will send you on a quest. You will need to complete twenty or so trials successfully if you hope to move up in rank.

Once you have completed this training, you'll take a final test to become an Apprentice.

Apprentice

At this rank, a Serian will come to you and take you under his or her wing. You will be his or her disciple for a time. This Serian will teach you about your duty as a mercenary, and you will need to accompany him or her on their missions. You will need to prove yourself to be exemplary and do your very best to help your tutor fulfil his or her contracts.

Once you've accompanied your tutor at least 20 times, and your tutor feels you have completed your training, you will be tested by the Masters, who will either grant you the rank of Serian or not.

Serian

As a Serian, you will become a real mercenary. You will fulfil contracts for clients.

You will need to find your own contracts, or take on those waiting for you in our offices, collected by the Masters.

You will also take on your own apprentice in turn and teach him or her everything you've learnt.

To rise in rank, you will need to have had at least two apprentices who succeed in becoming Serians like you. This means that you will necessarily have completed a minimum of 40 missions, which is mandatory to reach the rank of Grand Serian.

Grand Serian

Grand Serians are experienced mercenaries, the heroes of our ranks. They have proven their value by completing a large number of contracts.

As Grand Serian, you will continue to execute contracts. If you like, you may demand a little more from our clients. If you wish to do so, you may take on one or more apprentices, but this is not mandatory to move up in the ranks.

The next rank is that of Master Serian. To reach this rank, you will need patience, you will have to have become a Grand Serian of the highest reputation, and you will need to have acquired the wisdom of the masters.

If you are deserving, the Masters will summon you to a trial that will allow you to join them as their equal.

Master Serian

Masters are the leaders of the clan. They take care of recruiting members, and assigning all quests to Neophytes. They test apprentices, Serians and Grand Serians who wish to move up in the ranks.

Their duties do not include executing contracts, except in rare cases.

However, they may take care of collecting contracts and registering them with our offices, where a Serian can handle them.

There is one rank above that of Master: Grand Master Serian...

Grand Master Serian

Grand Masters have exactly the same role as Masters.

The only difference is that their superior rank gives them greater influence over important decisions.

Grand Masters are supposed to be examples for us all to follow. They have achieved wisdom and power, the keys to Serian teachings. They are therefore role models.

The Masters meet to name a new Grand Master when they have a favourite candidate, then decide...

CLAN ETHICS

The clan's teaching is a combination of philosophy and combat training, based on the union of wisdom and power.

The clan does not take sides in the black and white conflict in our world. Good and evil are both entities that cannot exist without the other. We therefore promote harmony among beings and beliefs, and take care to avoid upsetting this balance. That said, it takes quite a lot to upset such a balance... Thus, we have no qualms about intervening for or against either side.

All beings are on equal footing... All lives have the same value... As mere mortals, we are not judge or jury, but rather simple mercenaries at their service.

- Know how to chase all tiredness from your body, all missteps from your mind, and all failings from your soul.

- Make it a point of honour to have only yourself as your servant.

- Do not allow others to sit judgement on your actions.

- In all circumstances, whatever they may be, remain an island in the midst of waves, a mountain in the midst of clouds.

- Once every month, make a donation to one of our kind. Learn from it.

- Be impartial: any mission accepted must be executed. But learn to not let yourself be manipulated.

- Remain neutral when it comes to the events of this world, regarding all beings, and in all circumstances.

Failure to comply with the following rules will result in a warning, which can very rapidly lead to banning:

- It is forbidden to attack any person without a valid reason outside of the execution of contracts.

That is to say, without being forced to do so. We are neither vigilantes nor assassins.

- It is forbidden to attack a conquest zone.

Example: The Dopple Village, or similar. We have no business getting involved in this conflict.

- It is forbidden to insult others.

Clan members are supposed to learn wisdom, and must be respectful of others. Self-control is therefore very important for Serians.

- It is forbidden to use one's rank to take advantage of someone of a lower rank.

It is forbidden to give improper orders. Any person giving orders for personal reasons will be banished immediately.

- It is forbidden to disobey hierarchy, that is one's superiors.

There is a hierarchy in place; it is there to be followed.

- It is forbidden for any Serian to pay another Serian to execute a contract.

CLAN HISTORY

Serian-Kerm was a direct servant of Iop.

He was, in god-speak, a "proxy".

He was given the most important missions and served Iop as no one had ever done before.

He gave Iop the horns of a Minotoror killed barehandedly.

He fought a horde of mountain Boowolves from Essiogna single-handedly.

He strangled the chief of the Wethead Trool tribe.

In short, his exploits went without saying, and Iop knew that Serian-Kerm was by far his best representative.

In the war raging among the gods at that time, Iop remained neutral.

Indeed, he, the god of power and bravado, enjoyed admiring

the divine bickering... As he felt himself to be above all that, it amused him greatly.

That said, little by little, some of the gods began to call on him.

They would ask him to intervene in the conflict in diverse and varied ways.

Iop rarely refused to be of help, which was yet another way of showing his superiority.

But, seeing him help anyone and everyone, the gods came to view Iop as a sneaky opportunist...

That is when Serian-Kerm had an idea.

He suggested that Iop offer his services to the gods, in exchange for various treasures.

Iop liked this idea very much and immediately made it known to his peers that, from that day forward, he would rent out the talents of his proxy to anyone who could pay the price.

Serian-Kerm, Mercenary to the Gods, was born.

A long period in which Serian performed mission after mission then began.

His renown continued to grow, so much so that the gods were ready to pay fortunes

to have him on their side.

Serian-Kerm would work for the goddess Feca one day and fighter her the next.

He served and fought all the gods over and over, many, many times.

Until one day, near the end of the divine war, Serian angered Sram once too often.

Sram decided to kill Iop's proxy.

Serian, despite his uncommon power for a mortal, was not a god.

He fought Sram relentlessly, and even managed to injure him severely...

But Sram was too powerful, and Serian-Kerm's head fell.

A few centuries later, in the Province of Amakna, conflicts broke out between the inhabitants of Bonta and Brakmar. The war spread and soon reached Moon Island, along with the port city of Sufokia, and even small peaceful villages in the province.

On seeing all this, Iop recalled the past...

He listened to the desperate prayers of one of his faithful flock, who had lost trust in him, and spoke to him.

Kawet... I have a mission for you...

Tomorrow, you will rise and you will begin to form a troop of mercenaries.

You shall serve those who pay enough to earn that right.

You shall select and train those with whom you shall form the Serian-Kerm clan.

Here is the Clint hat of Serian, for your looks.

And here is your weapon! For power...

Iop continued to explain what he wanted of Kawet for an hour.

The next day, Kawet rose and began building the clan...

113.contentId:
The Dofus emitted heartbeats, diffusing their harmony throughout the world. Little gods, minor and virtually powerless gods, gods of nothing: all experienced renewed interest in the World of Ten. The demons heard the news too. Among them was Rushu... a force to be reckoned with.

The ten gods had followed the evolution of the world with great interest. Chubby clouds were swaying in the sky. The two celestial light sources were alternating in their slow shifts, one for the day, the other for the night. The world was covered with mountains, forests, plains, rivers, and seas. Here and there, smoking geysers burst the earth open, sending water springing up from jagged openings. Life blossomed in all four corners of the world. Grass laughed under the hot, humid wind of the plains. The first shoots grew in a thousand ways. The faithful peoples built civilisations. The dragon eggs were beating in unison, and their aura was spreading harmony.

The three dragons of Osamodas made it possible to influence this world with magic, be it white or black. A multitude of small gods grew incessantly: gods without believers, prepubescent gods, uneducated gods... One chose to live on the leaves of an Ash Tree; another lay down with its feet dipped into a droplet of dew... Little by little, they filled the world with their tiny, enchanting presence.

Legions of demons were eyeing the world as well... Though nobody knows for sure, it is said that they were created by Osamodas, a god who could almost be mistaken for a demon himself! Mighty major demons and scrawny minor demons alike scurried around this planet full of life. Naturally, they could not cross the threshold. All the demons knew that. A pact had been sealed between the worldly gods and the otherworldly demons; a pact forbidding demons to invade the World of Ten...

Do not feel sorry for them, dear reader! Anyone who knows demons knows there are very good reasons for locking them up in an infernal plane made of sulphur and stone, where the roads are probably paved with good intentions, but are also hot, burning hot, suffocatingly unbearably hot.

So they gathered in front of this invisible border. The smallest demons were the noisiest: the dung demon, the mouldy demon, the demons of yellow pus, green pus, of carcasses and maggots, even the lowly demon of warts and boils; the whole evil rabble was assembled there, as curious and restless as rats on holiday.

Presently, cries and protests rose from the hubbub. Rushu, the most powerful demon in the Krosmoz, had arrived. He split the crowd open with his whip. Pieces of horn, tufts of burning hair, shattered teeth and even the odd lump of eye or ear flew through the air. He elbowed his way to the front and peered down to see what was happening in the World of Ten. Then he shouted out to the gods:

"Brothers! What is happening on this world for you to give it your greatest attention?"

"You have not been invited to join us, Rushu!" roared the god Iop. We already have five gods of black magic and five gods of white magic. It guarantees balance, that rare thing!"

Rushu narrowed his eyes. He ran his molten tongue over his sharp teeth, which in a mouth other than Rushu's would surely have monstrous and terrifying consequences. A piercing whistle sounded from nowhere.

"Very well, lord Iop... I shall respect the pact," mocked Rushu, "and when I say I, I mean I and all my demons." As he spoke, Rushu tapped on the head of a little scarlet demon, whose skin sizzled a little at each touch. Almost imperceptibly, the goddess Feca drew her shield a little closer.

"And what about the Dofus? Are there sacred eggs in this new world?" asked Rushu in a deceitfully naive tone.

"Possibly," replied the goddess Cra. She felt her bow vibrating in her hand, as though it were urging her to tread carefully. Innocently, the demon added: "After all, there are dragons in this world, are there not?"

"There are indeed dragons," conceded the goddess.

"We shall know whether there are Dofus here when, if ever, they start beating. And to do so, to pick up and count their heartbeats, we need a clock - a divine clock!" reasoned Iop.

Preface

Unfortunately, as happens every year, a new type of Black Plague ravaged Amakna. But the one that struck in Aperirel of 463 was quite surprising: the plague did not affect people but rather their pets.

The symptoms were terrible. It would first manifest as a bodily imbalance. Some pets would grow huge but their skin would burn. Others became quick as the wind yet extremely sensitive to cold... But they all inevitably died.

Silouate, the guardian of Aperirel, attempted to cast a spell to save the poor beasts. Any pet stricken with the disease, no matter the severity, experienced a sort of rebirth. It was the only way to stop the plague, which had been killing them off one by one.

But Silouate didn't stop there. To prevent a similar catastrophe from happening in the future, he decided to partially link these small creatures' disease resistance to that of the people of Amakna, which was much higher and more resilient.

What Silouate didn't foresee was that his spell would strengthen the bonds between pets and people. Within two weeks, pets had become completely dependent on their owners...

That is why, to this day, pets have little chance of surviving if they don't receive the special care described in this book.

Introduction

First and foremost, to take good care of your pet, you must love it, otherwise your pet will not love you.

This book doesn't provide any tips or advice on how to love your pet, however, as that cannot be learned. Instead, we're going to look at the second most important condition: proper feeding.

This book will first explain the importance of the Ghast feeding cycle. It will then cover the resources that make up its diet.

Feeding Your Pet

A well-fed pet is a regularly-fed pet!

It takes Ghasts a minimum of 5 hours to digest food. Forcing one to ingest something before it has finished digesting will make it obese and slowly damage its health.

Ghasts can, however, go 72 hours at most without eating. Beyond that, your pet will begin to lose weight and its health will decline rapidly.

If you follow this diet to the letter, your Ghast will thrive. Statistically, you will notice visible improvement approximately every 3 meals.

If you don't feed your Ghast enough, it will become weak and skinny.

If you feed it too much, it will become obese.

Therefore, you must be very careful.

Treating Malnutrition

If your pet becomes obese, you can treat it by following the proper feeding schedule. Alternatively, you could deprive it of food until it returns to its normal state, but be careful as this last method could make your pet suffer and fall ill.

If your pet gets skinny, you can ignore normal meal times until it recovers its strength.

Treating Injuries

When injured, your Ghast will need to follow a special diet of Eniripsa Powder, which can be used to heal pets. You can purchase this powder from the Bow Kennel.

If your pet is injured, you can also bring it to the Bow Kennel to keep its condition from worsening until you can get Eniripsa Powder for it.

Your Ghast's Diet

The Ghast's diet consists essentially of bones.

This diet enables it to be more resistant.

Here are a few examples of the resources you can feed it:

Wabbit tooth

Chafer bone

Gobball horn

Gobball War Chief tooth

Feel free to try other bones as well – Ghasts love many other kinds of teeth, horns and bones.

Using Your Pet in Combat

Your pet will typically help you in combat by defending you or helping to make your attacks more effective.

Be sure to keep a close eye on your pet, though, because it will be injured every time you lose a fight against a creature.

If you don't heal it after each loss, it will eventually die, and you'll have to find a way to revive your pet.

In general, the only way to heal a pet after losing a battle is to feed it Eniripsa Powder.

Customarily, when adventurers fight one another, pets are never targeted and therefore cannot be injured, even in the event of defeat.

If you want to be sure your pet doesn't get injured, simply keep it in your inventory rather than having it by your side during combat.

About the Bow Kennel

The Bow Kennel is a place generally reserved for raising pets.

You can leave your pet there so it's safe and well-fed while you are away. However, your pet will not improve while in the Bow Kennel, as it is away from its master.

You typically have to pay a fee to drop off your pet, and then another fee when you pick it up later.

The amount you have to pay will depend on how long you're gone for. The longer your pet stays in the Bow Kennel, the steeper the fee.

The Bow Kennel is also where you can buy Eniripsa Powder to heal your pet.

The most well-known Bow Kennel is usually marked on adventurers' maps. It can be found next to Sufokia Gate.

In conclusion, we must point out a physical limit to your Ghast's constitution.

Once its growth is complete, its capacities will have reached their maximum and it will be difficult to improve it further.

But be advised: if you stop caring for your Ghast properly once it has reached this state, its health will suffer greatly. You therefore need to continue to feed it regularly.

Good luck to you and your pet!
