118.subTitleId: How to breed and mount them
118.contentId:
Preface: p. 3


General Information: p. 4


Capturing: p. 6


Breeding: p. 8


Reproduction: p. 13


Crossbreeding: p. 17


Feeding: p. 19


Riding Mounts: p. 20


Fighting: p. 22

Preface




Dragoturkey breeding is my greatest passion.


I have spent my life studying Dragoturkeys, tracking them, observing them, trying to tame them, ride them, and – most of all – love them.


Despite many years of hard work and many beautiful discoveries, I still believe that Dragoturkeys' potential as mounts has not yet been completely exploited.


In this book, I have written all my impressions and recommendations, in the hopes that Dragoturkey breeding remains a popular pastime and future generations enjoy their mounts for many long years.

General Information




Dragoturkeys are fast creatures that can usually be found in mountainous areas.


They eat plants and seeds.


Generally speaking, they aren't very bright. But beware! They're not as stupid as Iops! They are sociable creatures and when they live in groups, they help and protect each other. They are even capable of thinking before they act, which makes them more intelligent than most modern-day adventurers.


During my peregrinations, I have only ever come across three species of wild Dragoturkey: the Ginger Dragoturkey, the Almond Dragoturkey, and the rarest and most dangerous of all, the Golden Dragoturkey.

Here is an interesting fact about wild Dragoturkeys: they can live together no matter their colour, but when it comes to mating, they categorically refuse to mate with Dragoturkeys of another colour when in the wild.

Capturing




Capturing Dragoturkeys tends to be a delicate mission since they are naturally aggressive.


Most of the time, you have to go through a hunting phase to weaken them before you can hope to capture them.


However, wild Dragoturkeys have evolved over the generations to became extremely quick and agile... so much so that it's almost impossible to capture them.


Nowadays, you must be equipped with a good net if you want any chance of catching a wild Dragoturkey. It is equally important to hypnotise it or distract its attention for a while in order to catch and tame it.

The only way to mesmerise a wild Dragoturkey and calm it down for a moment, giving you a chance to capture it, is to cast a special spell at the right moment.


Only a few breeders know this spell and they usually only teach it to their most faithful and deserving disciples.


However, there is an old hunter lost in the mountains who will pass on his knowledge and teach the spell to worthy adventurers. It's thanks to him that I managed to capture my first Dragoturkeys.


Once you've learned this spell, you must cast it on the Dragoturkey you want to capture and quickly weaken it with a few well-placed attacks. Then just swish your net and hope for the best! Easy peasy, right?

Breeding




Once you've captured your wild Dragoturkey, you can breed it by having it mate with another Dragoturkey.


Before all that, you need to find a paddock.


Even poor adventurers can breed Dragoturkeys thanks to the public paddocks in cities and villages that specialise in breeding. Careful though, as despite their affordability, public paddocks are renowned for their insalubrity and overpopulation, which often lead to problems or slow down the rate at which the mounts there progress.

Wealthy breeders generally prefer to invest in building their own paddocks. That way they are in charge of which Dragoturkeys are allowed to come into contact with their own, and they can organise the paddock to suit their own specific needs and purposes.


Breeders with their own paddocks like to install various appliances which automatically carry out the arduous and repetitive tasks required for Dragoturkey breeding.


These machines allow breeders to develop their Dragoturkeys' aggressiveness, maturity, energy and serenity even when they (the breeders) are not there.

These items are usually made by experienced handymen, who can knock together surprising machines out of a variety of resources.


Wealthy breeders buy the machines made of the rarest resources, as they are usually much more solid and efficient than those built with cheap resources or salvaged materials.


You must take good care of your Dragoturkey if you want it to grow quickly. Careful breeders take some time off to go and visit their Dragoturkeys and interact with them to make them happy. Dragoturkeys are very attached to their masters and if they aren't given enough attention and affection they will become stunted and ill.

A Dragoturkey must be healthy to grow, and to be healthy, the delicate balance between its aggressiveness, serenity, stamina and love must be maintained.


Bear in mind that Dragoturkeys are vicious animals when out in the wild, and even when tamed they retain strong primal instincts. If you want them to be healthy, don't try to domesticate them completely.


That's why a good breeder will pay close attention to his Dragoturkey's statistics, balancing its stamina and aggressiveness while keeping it serene and in love, so it stays sociable.

Dragoturkeys whose aggressiveness is in balance with their serenity are healthy and can grow properly.


Some famous Dragoturkey breeders declare that an overly aggressive mount can't fall in love but can improve its stamina.


Similarly, it is said that a mount that is too serene can't increase its stamina, but can fall in love.


The healthiest mounts are therefore those whose aggressiveness and serenity are balanced. These mounts usually grow quickly, remain in love, have plenty of stamina and mate easily, which is important for breeders who want to succeed.

Reproduction




Any breeder worth their salt will try to mate their Dragoturkey in order to earn money or to improve their Dragoturkeys through selective crossbreeding.


Dragoturkeys can only mate when they are fully mature and when they have become fertile, which happens when they have experienced life.


Dragoturkeys can be considered mature when their owners are able to mount them, though this does not mean that they are fertile.


For that to happen, their owners must spend lots of time with them to help them develop. Good breeders will "just know" when their mounts are fertile, but such subtleties are beyond the reach of this book.

Should you desire further information on Dragoturkey fertility, a flick through the pages of the following reference book will tell you all you need to know: Fertile Dragoturkey: My Daily Fight. However, the book seems to be the victim of its own success and is sold out.


A word of warning: although the wild Dragoturkeys you capture are generally all mature and fertile (which comes in quite handy), you must remember that they are wild animals which can't stand to be kept in captivity for too long.


That's why wild Dragoturkeys tend to escape once they've mated in captivity for the first time.


Put yourself in their shoes: mating in captivity can't hold a candle to mating in the great outdoors, where they can be in harmony with nature, surrounded by orchids, streams and singing Piwis.

Before mating, all Dragoturkeys must be in love. It's important to stimulate your Dragoturkey plenty, so it's loved up enough to mate.


Mating is generally an intense and emotional part of a Dragoturkey's life. They are passionate creatures and mating is one of the only means they have of expressing their unbounded love.


For the mating to be successful, both Dragoturkeys must have a lot of stamina, or else the encounter runs the risk of falling flat on its face. A good reproductive Dragoturkey is a Dragoturkey with stamina.


Once mating is over, the Dragoturkey couple is very tired, if not completely exhausted. Before they can mate again, they will need to get plenty of rest to recover their strength.

Only old, experimented breeders know the exact length of the gestation period.


The period can be quite hard to predict, but it seems to depend on the type of Dragoturkey that has been impregnated.


Some breeders say that Dragoturkeys are able to lay more than one egg after a single mating session, but this claim remains to be proved.


As a general rule, as soon as the egg is laid, a young Dragoturkey hatches from it.


Please note that pregnant Dragoturkeys will refuse to give birth in a paddock. They must be placed in a stable so they feel safe and calm.

Crossbreeding




One of the most exciting elements of breeding is discovering new types of Dragoturkey through selective pairing.


Dragoturkeys undergo mutations regularly. You will find new types of Dragoturkey in almost every new generation.


Careful breeders take great care when choosing the Dragoturkeys that will mate with theirs. They act like parents who are about to marry off their children.


Dragoturkeys differ from each other by their appearance, character and efficiency.


That's why breeders keep on crossbreeding different types of Dragoturkeys. If they're lucky, they'll eventually get extremely rare Dragoturkeys with the most unexpected assets.

A Dragoturkey will inherit the physical features of its blood parents and ancestors.


That means you have to go back several generations in the family tree to determine which physical features will be inherited.


Only by studying the family tree and trying various crossbreeds will a breeder be able to determine (more or less precisely) the type of Dragoturkey that will result from a particular pairing.


One thing is certain in this murky matter of genetics: the blood parents of a Dragoturkey are more likely to pass on their own physical features than more distant ancestors.

Feeding




Dragoturkeys are neither greedy nor difficult to feed, but you should still make sure you know what is good for them.


A Dragoturkey that is used for running around, fighting or carrying heavy loads will lose its energy little by little, until eventually it is too tired to be of any use at all.


When this happens, you will need to take it to a public paddock, where it will be fed and given time to rest. You can also feed it yourself if you have the means.


Dragoturkeys eat everything: they like meat and fish, but will be happy with seeds and plants too. Some are pickier than others, of course, so learn what yours likes!

Riding Mounts




A Dragoturkey can be ridden only when it is fully grown and mature.


Each time you try to mount it, your Dragoturkey will get a little more tired.


Dragoturkeys are creatures with a lot of stamina but they'll still get tired if you don't let them get enough rest.


You can feed your Dragoturkeys to help replenish their energy, although the best course of action is to let them have a proper rest, either in a public stable or in a private paddock.

Over time, Dragoturkeys build up more and more stamina, which enables them to move faster and travel longer distances. Be careful, though: an exhausted Dragoturkey won't let you ride it and will move at a snail's pace.

Fighting




Once tamed, Dragoturkeys are reckless, loyal creatures.


They won't fight with their masters, but they'll do everything they can to protect them, them him escape or bring them closer to the enemy to attack.


The more time a Dragoturkey spends helping its master fight, the more efficient it will become.

119.contentId:
You who are preparing to read this story, beware! Hit the head, gird your loins, and put the Bow Meow out before you start reading, 'cause once you start, you won't be able to stop! Speaking of girding your loins, you could always go for underoos instead, because no one'll hear you yell!!



One last piece of advice: try to avoid soiling those underoos because you might attract Mama Bworks, or worse, the bone of an amorous Chafer!

Don't turn this page until you're sure you're ready!

This story happened a long, long time ago, when everything seemed peaceful enough. Amaknian farmers and shepherds only had to be wary of Boowolves or maybe Prespics – natural predators, who would steal a Gobball or two, and occasionally ravage their fields...



The local Feca shepherds, weary of the beasts' misdeeds, formed small armed parties. Lukryh Leuk was one of these Fecas. There was no match for the young and intrepid Lukryh when it came to hunting Miliboowolves. "A Miliboowolf for a Tofu, and a Boowolf for a Gobball!" was his motto. But the peaceful lands of the world were soon invaded by creatures even more terrifying than Boowolves. Indeed, many a peasant's foot was held to the fire in these days – some tried to reverse their position around the fire, laying headfirst, but frankly, this caused even more pain, and the smell of burnt hair.

Never before in Amakna had there been such terrifying creatures, and the peasants thoroughly soiled their briefs. Djaul, Rushu's servant and guardian of the month of Descendre, was one of these creatures. He prowled about the World, and some nights skulked through Amakna Village. From his appearance, it was obvious he wasn't on his way to help the needy: horns thrusting from his skull, sanguine eyes, cloven hooves, and a breath that would give a Bwork fits.



Numerous erections – temples I mean: tall, thin, and rigid – were soon produced and chants of pious desperation echoed throughout the nights. All the gods' faithful wanted to counterbalance Djaul's growing power. The World had to be under the guidance of the gods, no matter what Djaul and Rushu might try! But the spiritual power of the temples was insufficient...

The fear-filled hours slipping thusly by were wretched, and Xelor knew it! The god designated Menalt the centaur as the leader of a new knightly order. The order was put under the protection of one of Osamodas' dragons, Helioboros the White. The dragon christened them the "Order of the Valiant Heart" and blessed Menalt with the ability to wield white thunder. The knights were in charge of surveilling temples, roads and trails.


The Order counted among its number dozens of young knights, all proud and loyal. Not just anyone could become a knight of the order – Commander Menalt decreed that only an act of bravery would merit induction into the order.

In the meantime, Lukryh Leuk, the young Feca shepherd, had become a famous hunter, celebrated throughout Amakna for his abilities. He was known to hunt the most powerful monsters there were. He'd decided to go and join the order, and no one doubted he'd be able to get in. His attempt would have serious consequences, however. Lukryh, as a testament to his bravery, had promised to bring Menalt a truly exceptional trophy. He plunged deep into the forests, and was never seen again.*



* Everyone thought the young man – who would have made a truly remarkable knight – had fallen victim to one of Djaul's creatures, but no one could actually prove it. The search went on for months. The knights penetrated far into the lands to the south. And it was during one of their expeditions that the knights found the city of Brakmar, and they knew right away that this city reeked of demonic influence.

To counter Brakmar, Jiva, Pouchecot and Menalt pushed the loyal disciples to build Bonta, which would serve as a fortified defence against the demons. The Order of the Valiant Heart, now the militant factor of Bonta, protected the city from Brakmarian harassment with zeal and vigour. Right up until that autumn day known as the Crimson Dawn...



And now, you, having read this far, know enough about Lukryh Leuk.

What follows is a vision that appeared to me after I finished writing this book... There can be no doubt but that I wrote it under the influence of a spirit – perhaps it was even the soul of Hyrkul who wrote these lines, and not me... One day someone will be able to verify that this isn't just some story, not just the fruit of my imagination, but the real and very true story of Lukryh...



I will therefore let the one I shall henceforth call the spirit of Lukryh tell his story.

An evil presence had made itself felt not long ago in Amakna. The Feca shepherds were worried. Each morning, they found dozens of beasts, sometimes entire herds, passive, their eyes void of any emotion. However, the nights were quiet, and without even the slightest sign of agitation. The knights of the Order, heavily armed and ever-vigilant, stepped up their patrols.



That morning, I made my round of the pens, as usual. When I got near my flock, I saw my Gobballs all facing the same way, heads toward the forest. Stiff and motionless. I felt rage bubbling up inside me. A fresh trail led to the forest. It was the first time "the thing" had left tracks. I smiled: its mistake would cost "the thing" dearly.

I followed the trail for some time before reaching the edge of the Treechnid Forest. I took the main path. The grass was withered and the deeper I went, the more the air was filled with the heady scent of humus. Bushes snagged my clothes often, as if trying to keep me from advancing. At a bend in the path, I saw a clearing in the trees. I left the path to go and take a closer look. With each step, it seemed to me that the clearing moved further and further away from me.

I was exhausted. I was getting bogged down in mud. Vermin were swarming around, and worms were coiling around my ankles when suddenly, night fell. That's when a sepulchral voice echoed through the darkness.



"I've been expecting you, Hyrkul..."



Hyrkul? What name was that? I was completely worn out. I saw a tattered silhouette rising before me. It was a ghost, a winged soul that looked like a black dragon. Panting, it continued: "I'm going... to make you more powerful... than you can possibly imagine... You shall be... a warlord! But in exchange... I'll be with you... day... and... night..." The words swirled in my head, and I fainted.



Lukryh was dead.



Hyrkul lived.

Preface

Unfortunately, as happens every year, a new type of Black Plague ravaged Amakna. But the one that struck in Aperirel of 463 was quite surprising: the plague did not affect people but rather their pets.

The symptoms were terrible. It would first manifest as a bodily imbalance. Some pets would grow huge but their skin would burn. Others became quick as the wind yet extremely sensitive to cold... But they all inevitably died.

Silouate, the guardian of Aperirel, attempted to cast a spell to save the poor beasts. Any pet stricken with the disease, no matter the severity, experienced a sort of rebirth. It was the only way to stop the plague, which had been killing them off one by one.

But Silouate didn't stop there. To prevent a similar catastrophe from happening in the future, he decided to partially link these small creatures' disease resistance to that of the people of Amakna, which was much higher and more resilient.

What Silouate didn't foresee was that his spell would strengthen the bonds between pets and people. Within two weeks, pets had become completely dependent on their owners...

That is why, to this day, pets have little chance of surviving if they don't receive the special care described in this book.

Introduction

First and foremost, to take good care of your pet, you must love it, otherwise your pet will not love you.

This book doesn't provide any tips or advice on how to love your pet, however, as that cannot be learned. Instead, we're going to look at the second most important condition: proper feeding.

This book will first explain the importance of the Mini Wa feeding cycle. It will then cover the resources that make up its diet.

Feeding Your Pet

A well-fed pet is a regularly-fed pet!

It takes Mini Was a minimum of 5 hours to digest food. Forcing one to ingest something before it has finished digesting will make it obese and slowly damage its health.

Mini Was can, however, go 72 hours at most without eating. Beyond that, your pet will begin to lose weight and its health will decline rapidly.

If you follow this diet to the letter, your Mini Wa will thrive. Statistically, you will notice visible improvement approximately every 3 meals.

If you don't feed your Mini Wa enough, it will become weak and skinny.

If you feed it too much, it will become obese.

Therefore, you must be very careful.

Treating Malnutrition

If your pet becomes obese, you can treat it by following the proper feeding schedule. Alternatively, you could deprive it of food until it returns to its normal state, but be careful as this last method could make your pet suffer and fall ill.

If your pet gets skinny, you can ignore normal meal times until it recovers its strength.

Treating Injuries

When injured, your Mini Wa will need to follow a special diet of Eniripsa Powder, which can be used to heal pets. You can purchase this powder from the Bow Kennel.

If your pet is injured, you can also bring it to the Bow Kennel to keep its condition from worsening until you can get Eniripsa Powder for it.

Your Mini Wa's Diet

The Mini Wa's diet generally determines how it will evolve.

Here are a few examples of the foods you can feed it:

Fish: will make it more intelligent.

Meat: will make it stronger.

Seeds: will make it more agile.

Oils: will make it luckier.

Using Your Pet in Combat

Your pet will typically help you in combat by defending you or helping to make your attacks more effective.

Be sure to keep a close eye on your pet, though, because it will be injured every time you lose a fight against a creature.

If you don't heal it after each loss, it will eventually die, and you'll have to find a way to revive your pet.

In general, the only way to heal a pet after losing a battle is to feed it Eniripsa Powder.

Customarily, when adventurers fight one another, pets are never targeted and therefore cannot be injured, even in the event of defeat.

If you want to be sure your pet doesn't get injured, simply keep it in your inventory rather than having it by your side during combat.

About the Bow Kennel

The Bow Kennel is a place generally reserved for raising pets.

You can leave your pet there so it's safe and well-fed while you are away. However, your pet will not improve while in the Bow Kennel, as it is away from its master.

You typically have to pay a fee to drop off your pet, and then another fee when you pick it up later.

The amount you have to pay will depend on how long you're gone for. The longer your pet stays in the Bow Kennel, the steeper the fee.

The Bow Kennel is also where you can buy Eniripsa Powder to heal your pet.

The most well-known Bow Kennel is usually marked on adventurers' maps. It can be found next to Sufokia Gate.

In conclusion, we must point out a physical limit to your Mini Wa's constitution.

Once its growth is complete, its capacities will have reached their maximum and it will be difficult to improve it further.

But be advised: if you stop caring for your Mini Wa properly once it has reached this state, its health will suffer greatly. You therefore need to continue to feed it regularly.

Good luck to you and your pet!

124.titleId: How to Make Friends and Keep Them
124.contentId:
First Things First: p. 3

Speaking Clearly: p. 4

About the Interface: p. 5

Roleplay (RP): p. 6

What Would the Character Say?: p. 8

Behaviours to Avoid: p. 14

First Things First

Before you find yourself a real, authentic friend, you'll have to walk a great many kamameters through moors and underground passages full of wild creatures, talk to people who could stand to be a bit more sociable, and sometimes even fight for the best and worst, until life finishes you off!

I'll say it straight away, it's essential to talk to players and make friends because creatures are easier to defeat when you're in a group (called a party), and you'll also gain experience faster.

Also, it's helpful to have the enlightened opinions of a few experienced players when you're negotiating prices on goods you want to buy.

This book describes the notions you must know if you want to make friends and become a popular hero!

Speaking Clearly

Being understood when you speak is important! Whether it's in the game or on the forums, there are a few rules to follow in order to avoid having Demonic Roses sicced on you.

Write clearly, and watch out for grammar mistakes and typos!

Players know from experience that people who don't pay attention to their messages generally do not pay attention to what they say and think. Interacting with people who don't pay attention to what you say isn't really interesting, and players prefer to do other things with their time and help other people.

Therefore it is important to always express yourself clearly. If you don't even take the time to do that, the other players won't take the time to respond to it. Work on your language! This doesn't mean that it needs to be rigid or formal (take a look at the Roleplay section for more info).

About the Interface

The plus icon allows you to expand the chat box. The minus icon will bring it back down to its normal size. The star icon summarises the major commands that allow you to speak directly (and specifically) to your group, your alignment, your guild... By typing the command /help, all the commands will be displayed in the chat window.

The coloured icons let you select which messages you receive.

The smiley and emote icon lets you display the list of possible smileys and animations. Certain emotes can be won by completing quests. For example, you can go see Wally Elconom in the Amakna library or Grizmine in the Amakna tavern for more info.

The Friends icon lets you open your list of friends. To make a friend, click on the player's character, then on Add to my friends. The Guild icon lets you open a window displaying your guild's info – if you have one, that is!

Roleplay

RP is an abbreviation of Roleplay, which literally means to play a part or role, i.e. pretend to be someone else. When you roleplay, you breathe life into your character, everything from a backstory to a personality or a particular style, etc. Roleplaying is a bit like acting in a theatre production whose script is written by all the actors, little bit by little bit.

To clarify all that, while roleplaying you embody a character, but the character is not yourself. Like an actor, you interpret the role of a fictitious character in a world that's more or less different from the "real world".

The character you play may not look like you, and may not have the same personality or attitudes, or the same strengths and faults, ambitions, and definitely won't have the same life as you.

It's up to you to determine all that, and do everything you can to let their personality shine through in ways that make your character interesting and unique. Your character can be radically different than you, or it can be more or less a copy of your "real life" self, adapted to the Universe in which your character lives.

What Would the Character Say?

Your character has their own spirit and way of speaking. So, try to stick to their moods and personality when making them talk. It's suggested you try to make your words as colourful as possible, and use old-fashioned expressions to help give a "medieval" feel, as DOFUS is largely a medieval-fantasy game (but it's not obligatory – we're not asking you to speak like Shakespeare).

Here are a few simple examples of ways you could say "Hi!" while roleplaying.

(To a man): Greetings my Lord XXX. *bowing*

(To a woman): Good afternoon to you, my fair lady. *kissing her hand*

(To a group): Greetings, knaves! *spits on the ground*

(A Brakmarian coming across another): *in a cold tone* Bad evening to you, follower of Rushu.

There are a nearly infinite number of ways to say "Hello", and of course, even for such simple things, your character's personality should enter into it. The second example is fairly typical of a "Hello" from a character who tends to have a kind and friendly nature (this would be defined by a good alignment). The last two Hellos would be from meaner characters (with a "bad" alignment), and the others are more neutral.

Note that it's generally more fun, in the context of roleplaying, to receive an original Hello, rather than a Hello using only emotes; ideally you should try to link the gesture and the words.

Another example: How to leave a conversation.

(To a man): I regret to inform you, my Lord, that I must leave you now. *nods*

(To a woman): My dear Damsel, I'm sad to say that I have to stop contemplating your lovely eyes, but duty calls. *kissing her hand*

(To an enemy): *ironic laugh* I'll see you soon... in your grave! *leaves*

(To a group of enemies): I've no more time to waste with you swine! *turns on heels and walks away*

Leaving a roleplaying conversation is generally pretty simple – no need to ramble or over-complicate things. However if you must disconnect, it's generally a good idea to try and have your character leave the scene first.

It's more interesting for the others to read "Excuse me, I've urgent business to attend to! *leaves the room*" than "Sry gotta go ttfn".

You may have noticed in the preceding examples that players frequently use '>6asterisks (*)

to symbolise actions their character is performing that they are unable to perform in game:

While roleplaying, it may be unavoidably necessary to insert some non-roleplaying comments, i.e. if you need to speak player to player and not character to character. Generally, role-players indicate non-roleplaying elements by surrounding them with parentheses. "Greetings plebes! *shakes fist* (does anyone know where the Moowolf is?)".

A Few Tips

It's strongly recommended to start your sentences with capital letters, as well as following other capitalisation and grammar rules. Even if you're not a literary artist, make an effort to spell correctly and avoid abbreviations and SMS-language.

While roleplaying, try to avoid anachronisms, and in general watch out for things which have no place in the world of DOFUS. Your character doesn't have a television, a cell phone, or a PC, and the history of DOFUS (the background) doesn't include Napoleon or Cleopatra, for example. If you're roleplaying and you want to talk about that sort of thing, put it in parentheses.

Also watch out for game inconsistencies. Bowing to a character who is, in fact, on the other side of a wall will probably make your character look like a fool (although, absolutely nothing is stopping you from playing the role of a fool if you so wish).

Behaviours to Avoid

Insults and personal attacks, whether disguised by roleplay or not, are not tolerated. This applies to individual players, groups of players, individual GMs or Mods, and groups of GMs and Mods. If your roleplaying character is an insulting character, try to be sure that you only insult people who know your character and are ok with it (that is to say, your friends). Note as well that there are many different ways to offer roleplaying insults without resorting to vulgarity and rudeness.

If you're the victim of this sort of thing, please take screenshots as proof and contact DOFUS Support.

Dear reader, I have written this book because I, Wally Elconom, proclaim myself to be a learned geographer and one of the most knowledgeable men in the World, if not THE most knowledgeable.

In these pages, you will find material that will not only enable you to travel easily, but will also make you think about the vast world we call our own!

This will be all I will write on the subject, but please be assured that you will always be able to find me in Amakna Library if you require more information. Furthermore, it would be very much in your interest to do so!

Astrub, the City of Mercenaries

For a long time, Astrub was an inaccessible place, sheltered by steep, rocky foothills. A group of mercenaries made good use of its advantageous geographical position by meeting to devise their plans, leave for expeditions or hide an outlaw from the eyes of justice. They were called the Band of Brutas. In time, the camp became a village, then a well-populated city... all this despite its still uninviting name of Astrub, an anagram of Brutas!

The original population of Astrub was composed predominantly of mercenaries who, after a life full of plundering and guerrilla warfare, decided to settle down to a calmer life and start a family. They retrained as crafters and, naturally, got along well with the mercenaries passing through, who joined groups looking for adventure and kamas. These visitors regularly consulted the wanted notices distributed by the local authorities – a custom that is still in vogue today. There's no better way to earn yourself a little pocket money!

This geographical situation was perfect, not just for the mercenaries, but also for the Crackrocks. These creatures, which could and still can be seen roaming around the neighbourhood, soon started infecting the inhabitants' imaginations... even though they didn't infect much else.

The strangest rumours went round Astrub. For example, one particularly tenacious legend claimed that the Astrub Crackrocks delivered the newborn children in Astrub right to their parents' doorsteps.

The reality, however, is quite different because, if the legend were true, they would soon have been serving Crackrock style gruel in the taverns of Astrub.

In truth, nowhere else in the world will you find so many divine statues in one place, and for good reason! It is said the souls who come to incarnate in the world do so at the foot of the statue of their god. The giant stones offer themselves up to the sun and to the veneration of their followers in the sunny squares of Astrub, and watch as fresh incarnates emerge, sometimes speaking in a flowery language and behaving with unsightly mannerisms.

It is, therefore, at the heart of the city of Astrub that young adventurers fight their first battles. It is also useful to go round and meet the inhabitants of Astrub: each disciple will find someone of his own class there to talk to who will also give him his first mission.

The marketplaces are diverse and prosperous, even if the resources on sale aren't always of the highest quality!!

What's more, the marketplaces and workshops create a very particular odour in the town, which is the result of the combined stenches emanating from abattoirs, food and smoke, accented with a hint of humus and decay. A persistent rumour claims that these sickening smells come from Astrub's caves and that anyone who is exposed to them will fall ill...

It is also necessary to add that Astrub's Enutrofs travelled the town's underground galleries to exploit the gold mines. It's possible that the excavations upset some of the evil creatures or that they pierced a pocket of infectious gas, or an antediluvian septic tank... In any case, it's not safe to visit Astrub's underground tunnels and I strongly advise you not to take any tours down there, not even guided ones.

Tainela

Also known by the name of the Cradle, Tainela is the remains of a very ancient village, much older than Astrub. The Elders will tell you that souls used to incarnate at Tainela, not Astrub, but are they right? Can you really trust the senile imaginings that have come straight from the softened medullas of a wise man? Nobody will ever know for sure, since time, true to its nature, has destroyed all traces of this distant past.

Nowadays, Tainela is populated by Gobballs and Tofus who find relative safety in these places. Indeed, young disciples cut their teeth on these creatures, which, let's face it, aren't really very dangerous at all.

Maybe you'll be lucky enough to meet one of the more experienced adventurers who come to pilfer skins and feathers, pick plants and make potions, unless they're looking for the legendary Royal Gobball. Feel free to ask them any questions. With a bit of luck one of them won't have his ears stuffed with Gobball Wool and will listen to you, and maybe even reply.

Amakna Village

Amakna is such a well-known village that certain adventurers refer to the whole province, and even the world itself, by the same name. It's a forgivable error when you know that the destiny of the whole world is played out in Amakna!

Amakna is a peaceful village compared to the densely populated Astrub. All the same, the marketplace is very busy, and many disciples are regular visitors to the beautiful local temples.

The absence of markets just goes to show that Allister, the King of Amakna, has always favoured artisanal products. Many traders offer their services at the heart of the village. Furthermore, the quality of the equipment made here is much better than that at Astrub.

Both in memory of his own previous exploits and in the interests of educating young adventurers in the art of warfare, King Allister built the Kanojedo. This is where you can test your fighting abilities and try out your favourite techniques against an inanimate target.

To the east, you'll find Madrestam Harbour, where you can sing, dance, eat, drink and drink some more, even if nowadays people tend to prefer fishing on the quay or taking a boat to the famous Wabbit Island!

Amakna Castle

Allister lives there as a recluse, alongside his court. The old King is very distrustful of the world outside, and it has been said that his confrontation with Esra'Ruoy'Dnim, Lord Rushu's demon liege, didn't leave him unscathed. It's also said that he has a dark secret that he prefers to keep locked away, deep inside himself...

To distract himself from his dark moods, the King had the Royal Stud Farms built. They welcome mount breeders to Amakna, and bring a smile to many an adventurer's face.

Amakna Cemetery

Situated on a small island to the south of Amakna Village, the Cemetery opens its rusty doors to adventurers, whether they be intrepid, reckless, crazy or all three.

After having crossed a rickety bridge, you will find yourself right in the middle of the most unwelcoming monsters you will ever meet. Indeed, the cemetery's inhabitants really hate being disturbed, which is why they took the trouble to surround themselves with Kwoans, Evil Tofus and Chafers, who will make you think twice about coming back.

You might also come across some well-built young men down there, with an odd enough appearance to make even the bravest warriors turn a whiter shade of pale. Black hood on their heads, dark cape over their shoulders, they're known as Rogues. If this does happen to you, they will be dying to make you sign a very, very long lease of one the magnificent crypts with a view of the Antinau Sea.

Sufokia

Sufokia is a magnificent city whose wooden walkways extend far into the Antinau Sea. The panoramic view delights crowds of fishermen who smell of the sea and Grawns.

It has been said that this city is, in fact, only the emerging part of an immense city built in the past by a civilisation that has long since disappeared...

It is also said that Sufokia was built by the shrewd Buzinessemanh so the Bontarian and Brakmarian warriors could take a break from their perpetual quarrelling, treat each other to a holiday and spend their kamas. Unfortunately for him, this proposal was the last he would ever utter. Buzinessemanh was never seen again... dead or alive.

The Trool Fair

The only place like it on the Cania Plains, the Trool Fair provides entertainment for exhausted travellers in search of a bit of fun!

Games of skill and memory, the tombola, Quaquack fishing: great fun and laughs galore, the Trool Fair is ideal for a weekend away with your friends!

The thrill-seekers among you will not be disappointed, as the horror museum and the arena are both open to the public.

Those lucky devils who can walk in Trool Dung with their left foot one Friday thirteenth and find a five-leaf clover the very same day will be able to claim to have hit inestimable jackpots, while others might see their purses lightened by a few kamas.

Snacks to eat in or take away

Open 24/7

Closure due to world maintenance

Pandala Island

Even though the Pandawa people have been living on the island since the world began, it was not officially linked to the continent until 636. This late addition explains why we don't really know much about Pandala Island and the Pandawas who live on it.

Known for its bamboo-based fermented drinks, Pandala can be divided into 6 large zones: at the centre, Pandala Village, populated by kind souls and drunken locals, and the 4 villages of Aerdala, Akwadala, Terrdala and Feudala, surrounding it. These villages boast exceptional resources and are coveted by Bontarian and Brakmarian warriors who treat the land like a tug of war.

The last area, the Nolifis peninsula, lies to the far north-east of Pandala. This peninsula was deserted by the Pandawas themselves: they call Nolifis the land of their ancestors and believe that the ghosts of Pandawas who died in battle haunt the island. They're not wrong either: you will need a lot of experience, courage and friends to dare to venture there.

My geographic research shows that the five villages co-existed in harmony until the council, directed by Grandapan, decided to open up the island to the rest of the world...

Grandapan's decision would put an end to an era of peace and harmony: the Aerdala and Feudala Pandawas rose against the council's decision, so adventurers are welcomed there, but with varying degrees of warmth. As for the Pandikazes, the independent freedom fighters, they're just plain hostile towards adventurers!

A minority of Lenalds, cousins of those from Wabbit Island, also live on Pandala.

Resistance is the Pandawas' speciality: the effectiveness of their shields has been proven beyond all doubt and their understanding of the elements is world renowned.

The Imp Village

The Imps are the masters of the air, and the only thing more formidable than their gift for mechanics is their foul temper. Their flying naves, steerable balloons and other aerostats will delight warriors from guilds of all sizes. Indeed, the alliances are constantly arguing over who has control of the village so they can benefit from its advantages... If you have been dubbed Newtroll Knight, take a hike, you won't be able to use the famous Imp Carriers!

The Dopple Village

The Dopples are creatures who have retreated to the western lands, but their destiny was to conquer the world!

Their origins remain shrouded in mystery. It would appear the Dopples used to be followers who had rejected their own gods to venerate Rushu, the Demon Lord. Rushu planned to use the Dopples to raise an army and launch a powerful attack... But the result wasn't as good as expected! Noisy and disorganised, the wave of Dopples broke against the resistance of the inhabitants of Amakna. Rushu, who wanted to create his disciples in his image, found himself landed with Dopples: quite unpleasant, slightly demonic creatures who have never quite forgotten their allegiance to their original gods.

As a form of penitence, the Dopples are regularly captured and locked in temples to try to reconvert them by force. Pious adventurers can take their anger out on a Dopple between prayers... It's actually considered a good form of training!

Some of the stones they have in their possession are indispensable for making valuable weapons and equipment!

City of Bonta

The north-west of the Cania Plains prides itself on housing one of the most beautiful cities in the world: Bonta, city of Good and Justice. Built by the protectors Jiva, Pouchecot and Menalt to counter Rushu's growing power, Bonta has never yielded to Brakmar, its great rival.

However, those in power in Bonta seem to have renounced the ideals that they were supposed to defend! And, nowadays, Bontarians are torn between their quest for good, the defence of the oppressed and the thirst for power...

If, one day, you decide to serve the city of Bonta, be inspired and think hard about the commitment you're making. You might believe that you're spilling the enemy's blood for Good and Justice, but you might only be serving the designs of some war- and power-hungry fanatics!

Bonta's armed groups are split into different rival militias and guilds, which only unite to fight against Brakmar the Dark.

Either way, Bonta is a splendid city, an architectural delight of stones and light. If you do decide you want to become one of the city's soldiers, a series of quests awaits you. You will be introduced to Bontarian principles and ideology, and you might even become a White Winged warrior!

The Cania Plains

These vast plains stretch as far as the eye can see south and east of Bonta. A few small farms are evidence of the crops that they attempt to grow there.

On the other hand, Cania is a real paradise for petty thieves, who will find Blops, Kanigers and Plisskens there in abundance. It's almost as if a curse has increased the libido of these creatures, just like the one that affected the Jellies in the past.

Although the road is paved and easy to walk on, even without boots on, it is not very safe. Old tales tell of Eratz the Protester, Nomekop Wodly ad Edasse the Killjoy, bandits who would have a field day with adventurers passing through with their plump purses. As for the rest, they're likely to pass from life to death, trembling with fear, which isn't very glorious, I must admit.

Cania Massif is the home of the Plain Cracklers, the distant, less sophisticated cousins of the Cracklers. In other words, they're not really the sort of creatures one associates with.

At the north of Cania, almost next to Bonta, Lord Crow regularly opens his home to adventurers. Known for his inhospitality, Lord Crow will receive you however he likes, thank you very much. It's the early bird that catches the worm, and Lord Crow gets up each morning at the crack of dawn, so you'd better have your wits about you if you want to defeat him.

Cania Forest is found to the east, and is home to the Plain Boars. It seems the plains don't agree with the boars, because they are even more scowling than their forest-dwelling cousins.

To the north, you'll find Bonta Cemetery. Tombs, crypts and vaults in the purest Bontarian style are home to a whole family of Chafers: Chafer Archers, Chafer Lancers and Elite Chafers clink their bones together with an eerie musicality while telling stories that will make the hairs on your head stand on end (which is saying a lot, since the Chafer family is bald).

City of Brakmar

Situated to the south-west of the Sidimote Moors, which are themselves south of the Cania Plains, Brakmar has a very distinctive sulphuric smell.

Hyrkul, Djaul's favourite demon, built this city with the aim of imposing Rushu the Demon Lord's sovereignty.

A short while afterwards, Jiva, Menalt and Pouchecot, the protectors of the months of Javian, Martalo and Frauguctor, founded Bonta in order to counter Rushu's growing power. A terrible battle broke out between the defenders of the two rival cities: the Crimson Dawn. This battle cemented the hatred between the two camps, which still exists today.

Policy-wise, the Brakmarian code of honour is the same as the one followed by supporters of Bonta. Of course, you'll feel more at home if you like the black forces, darkness and all the assorted sets (horns, yellow eyes, fangs, scary laugh and Bwork breath).

As Bonta's rival, Brakmar recruits new warriors by the dozen to go and pluck the feathers off those White Wings. Training is reasonably long, though: only the strongest and most able recruits will be able to earn the Red Wings worn by the Brakmarian Warriors.

The Sidimote Moors

The light struggles to shine through the noxious clouds that overshadow the Sidimote Moors. It must be this lack of light that gives that deathly pallor to the Scurvion and the indigenous wolves we call Whitish Fangs. Once you're there, you won't get any paler. Now green, on the other hand...

In the Cemetery of the Tortured you might hit a snag, or worry yourself sick! Ghosts, vampires and Chafers all frolic about there in the hope that they will find some adventurers who will want to live out the rest of their days and beyond in their company.

Further to the north-east lies Gisgoul, the Devastated Village. Bworks, Goblins and Karne Riders live in the ruins of this recently very sought-after village. It makes you wonder why? The area could become quite popular again. Indeed, Rushu's cult is celebrated in the high tower of Gisgoul, the Demon Lord's followers are growing every day and the Rogues are flooding in.

The Treechnid Forest

This is a very strange forest whose trees exude perfumed fragrances, whilst the Treechnids bombard the amateur ramblers with Arachnees. Located to the north of Amakna Village, it's the zone marked out in red on most adventurers' maps. As for the local wildlife, you can imagine the scene: Dark Treechnids fight for territory with (not so dark) Treechnids and there's no doubt that they'll whip you with their leafy branches if you poke your nose into their family affairs. This fight amongst species also affects the insects. The Common Arachnee, previously a common species in our country, can now only be found in a few secluded parts of the forest. There are Major Arachnees (Arakneus Majoris for the Scrabblus enthusiasts among you) all over the place.

There's a rumour that an evil heart beats deep within the forest. And that those who've been there also suffer from his curse!

The Evil Forest

Legend has it that a labyrinth was made in this forest by the Kwismas Minotoball on his way back from his annual outing. He'd drunk a little more than usual and thought it would be funny to break down the forest the way other people break match sticks.

This legend has completely confused the academics: that would mean that the labyrinth, which is situated in southern Amakna, would have been made by Minotoball on his way back from Brakmar? Yet, it's very well-known that Brakmarian children are anything but good! Well? The mystery remains unsolved!

But let's return to the labyrinth. As its name indicates, it's labyrinthine. The creatures that haunt it are aggressive and will attack you shamelessly if you don't show them a great deal of respect. Marvellous popular wisdom translates this as: In the maze, he who expels noxious gases will end up breaking far more than wind...

But, most importantly, this is one of the few places where lumberjacks can harvest the rare ebony wood. It would seem that one of the Dofus guardians chose to live there, that same place that Crail, the famous Feca master and Arty's grandfather, fought in the prime of his youth.

130.titleId: How to Become a Bontarian Inductee
130.contentId:
Alignment Advantages: p. 3

Shields: p. 6

Choosing Your Side: p. 7

Ranks and Honour Points: p. 8

Disgrace Points: p. 9

Disabling PvP Mode: p. 10

Territory Conquests: p. 11

Alignment Advantages

When you start your adventure, your character is neutral. That means that neutral territories like Astrub and Amakna will be havens of peace for you, as a neutral guard will defend you if you happen to be attacked by an aligned Brakmarian or Bontarian.

An aligned player is a player who has sworn allegiance to one side or the other. To do this, he completed the quests that were offered to him in one of the two cities. Such a player will have either white wings (Bonta) or red wings (Brakmar) displayed on top of his character.

You'll see that the alignment system gets really interesting when in PvP (Player vs Player).

As once you're aligned, you can attack players of the enemy alignment or even neutral players (although this will earn you Disgrace Points, which apply penalties).

An aligned person has everything to lose by attacking a neutral person.

Being aligned allows you to access certain territories and use shields made by the Pandawas. The ranks of aligned players also grant them access to certain resources, the use of certain features, and the right to cheaper in-game taxes.

To access the alignment interface, open your characteristics window and click on the top left icon next to your character's name.

Shields

Shields enable you to protect yourself from the damage another player can cause you, but they're useless against monsters' attacks. Shields are very resistant to attacks from players of the enemy alignment.

Wearing a shield is not restricted by character level but by PvP rank. This means that a level-20 character who masters PvP perfectly and has a PvP rank of 10 can wear one of the most powerful shields in the game, whereas a level-100 character with a PvP rank of 1 will only be able to use basic shields that are a lot less powerful.

Choosing Your Side

There are two sides in constant competition: Bonta and Brakmar. If you don't know which of the two you would like to join, note that there are no technical differences between them.

Both alignments offer a similar path and similar benefits. The only noticeable difference is that Bonta serves Good and upholds high ideals, whilst Brakmar represents Evil and is preoccupied with its own interests. So which one sounds more like you?

The White Wings represent alignment to Bonta and the Red Wings are the symbol of Brakmarians.

Ranks and Honour Points

Once you're aligned, you can earn Honour Points and work your way up the ranks by attacking players or groups from the other side. Each time you rise in rank, your wings (which represent your alignment) will grow a little bigger.

For fights that take place between several players of different alignments, the Honour Points awarded are calculated for the whole team. Then the points are distributed in proportion to the PvP ranks of each team member.

The total points awarded are calculated using the difference in overall team rank (the sum of all the players' PvP ranks) between the winners and the losers. The lower the team rank of the winning team is compared to that of the losing team, the more Honour Points the winners will reap – and the more the losers will lose.

Disgrace points

If ever you attack a neutral player (who, as a neutral character, plays no part in the conflict opposing Bonta and Brakmar), you will get a Disgrace Point (and look like a jerk).

This point prevents you from accruing Honour Points until you redeem yourself by earning a point in an honourable fight.

Disgrace Points prevent you from accessing banks, markets, Zaaps and merchants.

As an aligned player, you have everything to lose when you attack a neutral player.

Disabling PvP Mode

PvP mode can be deactivated through the alignment interface. When you're not in PvP mode, your wings are hidden and you are considered a neutral player by others.

If you're attacked by an aligned player, your attacker will earn neither Disgrace Points nor Honour Points. As for you, you won't lose any Honour Points but, in the case of defeat, the attacker might lose Honour Points.

If you don't want to take part in the PvP system, deactivate this mode. This will discourage players from attacking you.

Territory Conquests

Territory conquests enable aligned Bontarians and Brakmarians to launch attacks to control areas like the Dopple Village, the Imp Village or even one of the four elemental villages of Pandala. You can attack a territory only after defeating its guards first. A group of eight players maximum must destroy the prism, the last obstacle before they can claim a complete victory. Although the prism can only be destroyed by up to eight players, you can bring in a whole army of players to help you conquer a territory!

Indeed, once the guards have been defeated, the main door opens up, enabling the attackers to invade the territory.

For the villages of Pandala, the front door remains open for 20 minutes; for the Dopple Village, it's 15 minutes; and for the Imp Village, 10 minutes.

Once the time is up, the prism room becomes inaccessible.

If the prism has been destroyed during that time, the territory changes alignment and, naturally, so does the guard.

Defending territories is simple since all aligned players are warned when their territories are being attacked. Aligned players can quickly come to a territory's aid using the free Zaaps available in each one.

You can also use City Potions, which transport you directly to your city's Zaap from anywhere in the world. That way, you can get straight to the heart of the action by using a potion and then taking a free Zaap. Invaders of your territory, be warned!

Conquerable territories:

- The Dopple Village

- The Imp Village

- The Aerdala Village

- The Feudala Village

- The Akwadala Village

- The Terrdala Village

133.subTitleId: Start your Game the Right Way
133.contentId:
Introduction: p. 3

Character Classes: p. 4

Fighting: p. 11

Points Used in Combat: p. 13

Victory and Defeat: p. 17

Elements and Characteristics: p. 19

Spells: p. 20

Bonuses and Damage Reduction: p. 21

Critical Hits and Critical Failures: p. 22

Equipment: p. 23

Welcome to the World of Twelve!

Before you can own a real, genuine Dofus, you're going to have to walk many kilokametres through moors and forests full of sinister-looking creatures, talk to shady individuals, and – shock, horror – even win a few fights!

Sounds hard, right? Well, it should raise your spirits to learn that hunting monsters will earn you a ton of experience (XP), all sorts of items, and a pocketful of kamas (k) – the currency of the World of Twelve!

This book presents all the concepts you'll need to master if you want to live a long life, become famous, and maybe even become a hero!

Character Classes

Each class has a specific field of action but they are all complementary. Pick the one you believe will best match your gameplay. No class is intrinsically better or worse than the others, but some are easier to start with (Iop, Cra, Osamodas, Sadida) than others (Pandawa, Eniripsa, Enutrof, Sacrier, Sram).

Tip:

Select an easy class at first. You can always make a new character belonging to a harder class later on, when you know more about the game and have some of your own equipment. (For example, starting over with a character equipped with an Adventurer Set or a Boon Set will be a lot easier!)

Here is a description of the different classes to give you an overview.

CRA disciples are well-balanced archers. Their attack power can be high although somewhat uncertain, or average and stable, depending on the character's skills.

Cras are real sharpshooters who can shoot from a distance or from up close... and their shots don't half sting! Their range is obviously very large.

Any Cra worthy of their good name can weaken enemies from a distance, repel enemies, and take some of their enemies' Action Points away.

ECAFLIP disciples are damage dealers who love taking chances. Their attack power is very high when in close combat but uncertain from a distance. Ecaflips can make hidden things appear, which can be very useful when there are traps concealed on the battlefield.

To beginners, Ecaflips may seem hard to play, but, as their power increases with experience, they can eventually become every bit as fearsome as Iops.

ENIRIPSA disciples are healers. Their attack power is therefore weak, as is their range.

Healing allies and giving them Action Points is what Eniripsas do best!

Eniripsas are valued in groups for their abilities, but are easy targets when they're alone!

ENUTROF disciples decrease the abilities of other fighters. Their attack power is relatively weak, so they're more effective in a team than they are fighting alone. Enutrofs are not easy characters to begin with, but are a very interesting choice for more experienced players!

FECA disciples are born protectors. Although their attack power is average and quite uncertain, they can provide powerful protection for their allies, as well as for themselves. Fecas can withstand a lot more damage than any other class, but in return, they are weak attackers.

IOP disciples are mighty fighters. Subtlety is most definitely NOT their middle name; they're here to do damage, and they do it well! Their range is low but their attack power is very high when in close combat.

Their skills also include increasing their allies' damage and taking Movement Points away from their enemies.

OSAMODAS disciples can summon creatures. Their attack power and range are both medium, but they can summon creatures to wear enemies down, remove some of their Action Points, or push them away. Born for summoning, their fighting style is based around these creatures.

SACRIER disciples master their pain to make themselves stronger. When in close combat, their power is high... provided they take the first hit! Their range is average, but they can pull adversaries towards them to defeat them in close combat. Sacriers are quite a hard class for novices to master.

SADIDA disciples are mages who influence movement and immobility. Their attack power is quite high but uncertain, at least at the beginning of their training. They have medium range. Their Summons include creatures that explode, block the way, or remove Action Points; and they have various ruses to prevent adversaries from moving around.

SRAM disciples are just like their god: sly master strategists. Their attack power is extremely high in close combat and medium from a distance.

Srams can make allies invisible, push enemies back and make the invisible visible.

Thanks to their versatility and strategic skills, they can get out of most any situation!

XELOR disciples are time masters. Their attack power is average but their range is high. Disciples of this class are quite efficient on their own and extremely fearsome when in groups. They know just how to take Action Points away from their enemies and give some to their allies.

PANDAWA disciples have no trouble playing around with gravity. They can lift enemies clean off their feet and send them soaring through the air. Their attack power is high but their range is quite low. They are much appreciated in groups for their lifting and throwing abilities.

Members of the ROGUE clan are demolition experts. They place bombs all over the battlefield, leading to explosions with devastating effects – especially when more than one bomb goes off at once! Rogues can also support their allies. Their range is medium, and their gameplay is tactical, so they could be complicated for beginners.

MASQUERAIDERS use their magic masks to switch roles depending on the situation. Their range and attack power vary depending on whether they're playing the Coward or the Psychopath. With their third mask on, they can prevent enemies from fleeing. This versatility makes Masqueraiders quite hard for beginners to master.

FOGGERNAUTS are tacticians and experts at technomagic. They place turrets to arrange the battlefield to their advantage. Foggernauts can take on several roles, but they have to choose one to be effective when fighting. Their war machines can affect allies as well as enemies, so the key to success is being able to control the field.

Fighting

Fighting relies on a turn-based system, which means that, each turn, players play one after the other within a limited amount of time (30 seconds each). Place your character at the beginning of the fight, move, hit, cast spells... It's up to you to build your own strategy!

Choosing a good starting spot for your character can give you a significant advantage. Once you've played, or once you've placed your character, don't forget to end your turn by clicking on the arrow under your portrait.

Tip:

When you start a fight, you can decide to exclude other players. You can also call for help from other adventurers. Up to seven other players can join the fight before it's actually started. Just click on the icons to the right of your screen when a fight is launched.

You can also forbid other players from watching a fight that you have started. This function is especially useful when you're in PvP mode, as it stops other players from analysing your tactics.

Points Used in Combat

HP – Health Points

Your character's Health Points decrease when he or she receives damage (when hit by an enemy attack, for example). They increase when your character is healed (by a spell, an ally or an item). If your character's HP drop to zero, they're dead!

AP – Action Points

The number of Action Points your fighter has determines how many actions they can perform in a turn. Your different spells and attacks all have a cost in Action Points: attacking with a weapon, for example, often costs 5 AP. Once your character's AP drop to 0, they can't do anything else that turn. Fighters start out with 6 AP, but this total can be increased or reduced by spells and/or equipment.

MP – Movement Points

Your character's Movement Points determine their potential to move around within a fight. Moving a fighter removes Movement Points from their total MPs. Fighters start out with 3 MP, but this total can be increased or reduced by spells and/or equipment. Each time you move, it costs you 1 or more MP, depending on the number of cells you move.

Special Case: When a fighter is on one of the four squares adjacent to a monster or another fighter, the fighter is said to be in a lock zone (also called a control zone). Escaping a lock zone can result in the loss of a varying amount of AP and MP, depending on the fighters' Agility: the higher the Dodge characteristic of the character who wants to escape the zone (in comparison with the enemy's Lock characteristic), the less they'll be penalised and the further they'll be able to run.

Tip:

Some monsters have more than 3 MP and 6 AP! Certain rare items of equipment can grant you extra AP and MP!

Other points to take into account when fighting:

RA – Range

Your character's Range determines the maximum distance that he or she can cast spells. Just like Movement and Action Points, this characteristic can be modified using spells and/or equipment. Range is very important, especially for classes that fight better from a distance, such as Cras.

Initiative

The fighter with the highest Initiative will play first in a fight. If two of them have an equal amount of Initiative, their starting order will be decided at random. Your Initiative remains the same for the whole fight.

Prospecting

Prospecting increases your ability to pick up items at the end of fights. You start the game with 100 Prospecting points (120 for Enutrofs) and you can gain more by equipping items that carry Prospecting bonuses. Increasing your Chance characteristic will also aid your Prospecting skills (+1 Prospecting point for 10 Chance points).

EP – Energy Points

When your character loses a fight, he or she loses all of their HP and some of their Energy. They will also return automatically to their last saved position (a Zaap, for example, or to Incarnam or Astrub, if they didn't have a saved position).

Victory and Defeat

Death

When you lose a fight and your Energy drops to zero, you join the ghost world. It's now up to you to find a Phoenix to come back to life and regain a little Energy.

When a player joins the ghost world, the Phoenixes that he or she can go to are all shown by red markers on the general map. If this happens to you, you can either wait to be resuscitated by a player who is able to do so, or go and find the nearest Phoenix.

Winning Fights

Winning fights against monsters allows you to gain experience, pick up items, and even earn a few kamas. All this will help you on your way to buying new equipment and spells that you think are the best choice, which is the best way to develop your character... and that's where DOFUS starts to get tactical! You can also sell the items you find by rummaging through the remains of defeated monsters to earn some more kamas, the currency in the World of DOFUS.

Elements and Characteristics

Each element corresponds to a characteristic. Spells and certain items of equipment are influenced by the elements: mastering these element will increase their spells' and equipment's effects (inflicting more damage, healing more HP, parrying, etc.).

Earth and Neutral correspond to Strength

Water corresponds to Chance

Air corresponds to Agility

Fire corresponds to Intelligence

Other Characteristics

Vitality determines how many HP your character has.

Wisdom enables you to gain experience more easily, parry AP and MP losses, and reduce enemies' AP and MP more easily – as well as increasing the power of rebound spells (such as Xelors' Counter spell).

Spells

Spells have various effects that you must learn to control for them to be effective: healing, summoning creatures, reducing an enemy's MP, increasing an ally's AP... There are many different combinations! Some spells also inflict damage or increase your damage output. Like weapons, each spell has its own range and an area of effect.

Note: if a spell is Neutral, its effects can be strengthened by the Earth characteristic.

Bonuses and Damage Reduction

Damage can be increased (boosted by damage bonuses) or reduced (by resistance bonuses) depending on the element of your weapon (or of your spells, if you have chosen attack spells) and your items.

You should choose damage and resistance bonuses to match the element of your weapon and/or spells.

For instance, let's take a Sacrier fighter equipped with:

- a cloak that increases EARTH damage by 10,

- headgear that increases EARTH damage by 15, and

- the Sacrier's Foot spell (an EARTH spell that inflicts between 10 and 18 damage).

Each time the Sacrier hits, they inflict between 35 and 43 damage on their opponent, if the opponent has no resistances.

If the spell Sacrier's Foot is replaced by the Raziel (a sword that inflicts between 26 and 40 Neutral damage), each of the Sacrier's blows will inflict as much damage on an opponent, minus any resistances.

Critical Hits and Critical Failures

Each blow struck and spell cast is subject to Critical Hits (CH) and Critical Failures (CF). The difference or increase in effects caused by a Critical Hit is indicated in the description of each weapon and spell.

A Critical Failure always inflicts zero damage, whereas a Critical Hit will considerably increase your chances of inflicting much more damage than usual.

Equipment

The items that your character can equip are divided into a number of categories:

- Pets and mounts

- Dofus

- Clothes (cloaks, hats, boots, etc.)

- Jewellery (amulets, rings, etc.)

- Weapons

- Shields

- Other

Each equippable item can grant you stat bonuses, damage and/or resistance bonuses, Range/AP/MP bonuses, etc. Discover them all!

Special Case: Sets

A full outfit of equippable items (boots, cloak, headgear, etc.) – often all dropped by the same monster – is known as a set. Sets give special effects to whoever wears them. These vary from set to set (Gobball, Prespic, Boar, Moskito, etc.), but they are usually well worth the effort (bonuses for stats, HP, etc.). The more parts of a set you have, the higher the overall bonus, so get collecting now! So if you're missing part of a set, make sure you find it so you can get the highest bonus possible!

In the same series and by the same author:

Beginner's Manual

How to Become the Perfect Recruit

How to Make Friends and Keep Them
