178.subTitleId: Extract from the Aybeeceedarius Daemonica of Trisboulis. 544 Edition.
178.contentId:
Djaul: Reader, beware! You are about to find out more about one of the most powerful and vile demons that ever did live. Make sure you don't say his name out loud seven times, or you'll look like an idiot. Also, make sure you don't say his name under your breath seven times, or you'll be mistaken for a mystic and shops will shut their doors when they see you coming, young children will throw wotten cawwots at you and you won't ever get invited to parties... trust me, I know from experience.

In the year zero of our era, Djaul was chosen to be the Protector of Descendre with a vote of 11 to 1. The eleven being against. But it's difficult to say no to Rushu when he makes those eyes at you, which means he's reserving you a place in the demonic plane, with a nail on the chair and a cauldron filled with boiling lava balancing precariously above your head.

From this day on, Djaul has been desperately trying to encroach upon the other months. At the end of the year 10, he enjoyed one of his proudest moments when he crushed Solar, the Protector of Javian, and sent him to join his ancestors. That year, that winter was longer and harsher than ever. Silvosse at last managed to bring it to an end with liberal use of his hammer.

Jiva took Solar's place and became Djaul's fiercest enemy.

Every year, the two Protectors give their all in a merciless tug of war, and there's a lot at stake: if the demon succeeds, the world will be plunged into an eternal winter. Luckily, Javian's Protector has almost always managed to get the better of him. Almost always, for one, during that dark era when the two great cities were warring, she was captured by Djaul. If Ulgrude of Thunder had not intervened, she would certainly have gone the same way as poor Solar...

Let us hope that Jiva will never be involved in such an event again! She watches over us all and will never betray us. So our bright and sunny days have a bright and sunny future ahead of them.

180.titleId: Let's go a-beating in the woods
180.contentId:
When I was still a nappy-wearing Iop, my mum used to tell me lots of stories about the Mystified forest. I remember the one about Snow Quiet, who was captured by seven dwarfen mushrooms, or the one about Tom Plum, who got lost in the woods. In these tales, there were always joking spirits, mysterious creatures and enchanted trees more ferocious than Treechnids... They scared me, but it was also fascinating.

That's how I fell in love with the Forest and how I became a lumberjack. Well, a lumberjack... It's not really the case, since really I never touched the trees! This place is much too sacred. I would never have risked offending the local spirits! No one, not even a Iop is dumb enough for that! No, I was only picking up the dead wood that the Forest was leaving for me. I was a kind of Forest guardian, in the end.

Anyway, this is all to say that in my line of work, I've seen and heard all sorts of weird things in this wood. But I never thought I'd witness a fight between two Protectors of the months!

All this started on a day in Descendre, just before the Ice Age. I was going on my usual round, and had gathered quite a lot of dead branches, when I head an infernal racket coming from the depths of the forest. It sounded like nothing I knew of. Like giant Cracklers having a jumping contest on the mossy forest floor.

I'm a naturally curious man. And I don't flee in the face of the unknown. I'd rather just head straight on. It's often worked against me... But sometimes, it pays off. So I headed into the forest to make some sense of it all.

As I moved forward, the sounds were getting louder and I could hear the ground vibrating. I'll admit, I was a bit scared, but I wanted to see what was happening.

That's when I saw her, coming around a copse. She was beautiful and blue, unreal, captivating. She was as tall as a Trool, as light as a Tofu feather, as gracious as a Bulbush. A frozen beauty. For a second, I though she was the snow queen from my childhood tales. But no, she wasn't a queen! Or a goddess! Or even a mirage! She was Jiva, Guardian of the Month of Javian!

It didn't take me long to realise she wasn't alone. Across from her stood a massive demon who was struggling to stay on his feet. It was Djaul, Descendre's protector... When I saw this colossus, straight out of the Tartar, I felt so small! For a second, I thought of leaving without making a sound, but I was too scared they would see me. So I stayed there, dead still. And I watched them fight.

Oh, but it was incredible! A battle of titans! Djaul threw himself at Jiva and pulled her hair. Jiva countered by kicking him violently in the elbows. So, he started slapping her! She flicked his nose! Bang! They both fell to the floor, taking the trees down with them!

I had no idea how they were ever going to be stopped. It was like two Crackers fighting in a Tofu House. The blows rained down, fists destroying everything in their path, feathers flying... And everything around them was being pulverised. Luckily, I was far enough away to not get smashed to smithereens. Though there were a few times when I wondered how much longer I was going to last!

I'd been watching for quite a while when I saw Djaul hit Jiva below the belt. Scratch! A violent claw strike! In an instant, Jiva's leg was slashed. Then, blood began to pour from the wound, a deep blue blood that dripped down her leg. It sprayed the ground and was absorbed by the earth, so quickly that it was unreal. And after only a few seconds, the nearby vegetation started to change. I saw curious shiny, icy blue veins appear around stems and trunks. Petals were frozen, leaves were paralysed and barks were petrified, all at an incredible speed.

Jiva's frozen blood had contaminated the entire forest.

After seeing that, I packed up my courage and decided it was time to get out of there. Pronto! The Protectors resumed their fight, and I made the most of it! I was so panicked that it took me only a few minutes to reach my cabin and lock myself inside!

That was a good move. As soon as I was sheltered, a horrific blizzard started raging outside. The Ice Age had begun.

Even today, I still thank the gods for sparing me. If I'd have stayed outside, I would have frozen to death for sure!

As for the forest, it became covered by a thick layer of ice. Already frozen by Jiva's blood, it was now forever petrified...

181.subTitleId: The Origins of a glacial warrior
181.contentId:
My name's Missiz Freezz. People see me as an insensitive woman, devoid of all sentiment. They're not completely wrong either. I don't feel pity. Other people's misery leaves me cold. What they don't know, though, is that I wasn't always like that. I was married, once...



My husband was a genius alchemist, a Xelor called Victor Freezz. And I loved him madly. He made my heart beat as strong as a Dofus' pulse. But he was a cold and harsh man. He was obsessed by his research and spent most of his time in his workshop, carrying out experiments, I don't know what on. He never touched me, he would look me up and down with an icy stare, as if I were disturbing him every time I wanted some of his attention. Eventually, I came to my senses. I told myself he was married to his work, and that there wasn't any room for a woman in his heart of ice.



I was wrong...

One night, when I went down to his workshop unexpectedly, I caught him with another woman. It was an Enutrof! And she was as bald as a coot! Judging from the Tormentator poking out of her sack, she must have been one of those slightly unstable people who occasionally put on the Dark Knight's costume. When I saw this bald woman, smiling, in her black tights and scruffy cape, with her arms around my husband, my heart stopped beating and my blood froze.



A deathly, devastating cold, which took hold of me and made me lose all sense and reason. Without thinking, I left my hiding place and invoked a hoard of Homing Hands which attacked the couple. Busy as they were, the two perpetrators didn't even see them coming and the hands ripped them to shreds. It was quick, violent and cold. Just like it always was with Victor.

Initially exhausted by the pain of having been betrayed, I soon began to notice that I was actually feeling a strange sense of relief. As if I'd just been freed from a burden I'd been dragging around with me forever. So, I decided to wipe the slate clean and leave the place where I'd been blinded by love for far too long. As I was packing my bags, I came across some precious documents belonging to my late dear and tender husband. That's how I discovered the subject of his research, the thing which he had been so obsessed about all these years: the formula for a low temperature soaking liquid, destined for forging a revolutionary steel!



Armed with this precious discovery, I left and never looked back, deciding to rebuild my life from scratch and never show weakness again. Looking to make some profit from my ex-husband's formula, I set off for Pandala to meet Hotari Honza, the great master forger. I spent several months with him, as his disciple. I learnt to make formidable weapons according to ancient martial arts techniques.

Together, we experimented with the properties of the soaking liquid and its astonishing ability to freeze steel in such a way it became stronger than diamond. Thanks to this research, I was able to forge a needle so strong and sharp that it would be able to cut the Xelor god himself down to size!



Alas, just as I was adding the final touches to my deadly weapon, Hotari Hanza accidentally slipped on a Larva Skin and spilled some of the precious liquid. It splashed in my face and my left eye frosted over. Blind in one eye, I decided it was time for me to move on once more and I hurriedly killed my great master.

I learned, later on, that a noble stranger by the name of Harebourg was looking for innovative artisans for his project. I had nothing to lose and I needed a change of scene. It might have been my chance to finally become somebody! With a bit of common sense, I'd be able to make myself indispensable to the Count and secure myself a place in the highest spheres of aristocracy! I'd become a real lady! An Ice Lady!



Frigost was calling me. Frigost was waiting for me. All I had to do was get there...

183.contentId:
When I arrived at Boundwons Village – as it was called at the time, before the avalanche – the houses still smelled of fresh paint. Artisans and qualified labourers were rushing in from all over the island to join Count Harebourg's big project. Each one had been provided with their own house, as well as the tools necessary for them to be able to work under the best possible conditions. As for me, I'd been given a comfortable little chalet and a set of very high quality gears.



Count Harebourg financed the construction of the village and all its facilities. He made sure everything was perfect. He believed that ensuring his workers were comfortable would increase their productivity. But I think the real reason was that this great man was a philanthropist, and the well-being of those around him was fundamental in his eyes. Whatever it was, the artisans repaid him for his hospitality a hundred times over. You should have seen them at work on that building site! It was like a swarm of Moskitos on a Jullier night. They were buzzing about in all directions. For my part, I was feeling more motivated than ever. I had some experience in clock-making, but I'd never worked on anything this big before. It was very exciting!

The village was built at the foot of Mount Scauldron. In this respect, it was ideally located between the building site and the raw material supply points. Nothing had been left to chance and we were able to focus our efforts entirely on the success of the project. The count used to come down to supervise the construction himself. It was the same routine every day: he visited the workshops, gave his instructions and used the opportunity to warmly congratulate us. From the forger to the carpenter, to the clockwork installer, everyone was entitled to their own compliment and pat on the shoulder. It was always gratifying! We felt useful and appreciated. We got the feeling we were part of something extraordinary, something that was going to change the world!



Alas! Frigost was the only thing that changed... and not in the way we hoped. When Descendre's cold hit the island, enormous quantities of snow accumulated on the slopes of Mount Scauldron, just above the village. They built up so quickly that it wasn't long before they threatened to come crashing down upon us.

Just a few minutes after the start of the Big Freeze, we heard a deafening and monstrous sound far away, a roar that sounded like it had escaped from the depths of the Tartar. It was like an earthquake, a typhoon on the sea, a big crash of thunder that would destroy everything... The tremor was so violent it upset the fragile balance that was the only thing protecting us from the inevitable: an avalanche.



In an instant, a flood of frozen powder poured down on us, covering all that lay in its path. Instead of lava, the volcano seemed to be spewing out fountains of snow, which transformed into a relentless blizzard as they hurtled down the side of the mountain. In the blink of an eye, men were swept away, everything we owned was pulverised and our houses were blocked in by thick layers of ice.

The avalanche was brief. Violent. Merciless. And it had buried Boundwons Village forever.



It takes time to recover from a tragedy like this. People had lost everything. It only took a couple of minutes to destroy our hopes, swept away by tonnes of snow. But the biting cold of Descendre forced us to into survival mode. We needed to react immediately if we didn't want to freeze to death.

The most cowardly among us ran away. They left the place that had welcomed them with open arms, and didn't look back. They preferred the warmth and comfort of the village to dealing with the consequences of their work. They were the ones who accused the count of being responsible for their unhappiness. The hypocrites!



The rest, on the other hand, set to work clearing the roofs of the houses and repairing what they could. They had been seriously shaken, but they remained loyal to the count. After all, Harebourg wasn't the only one responsible for what had happened. We'd all taken part in the project. And who could have foreseen the nasty turn events would take?

184.contentId:
Kay Vine had explored every nook and cranny of the World of Twelve, forwards, backwards, and even hopping on one foot, from the Tainela to Tofu Corner, and from the outskirts of the forest to the Astrub Rocky Inlet. His obsession with Dofus was slowly eating away at his sanity. He needed all of them! Not just the six linked to the elements, but all the Dofus that the dragons had ever laid! Well, and because he wasn't really high-level enough to get the six.

At the moment, he's only got one (Dofus, not level), but not just any one: the Ebony Dofus. He bought it from the market at Astrub for 10,000 kamas. What a stroke of luck! He couldn't help but laugh at the poor salesman who had no idea what this relic was worth.

It looked like fate had finally smiled down on him for the first time: in a few minutes he would also be in possession of the precious Ice Dofus. He reminded himself of the Enutrof's words. "It's like I was telling you! A big egg, all cold at the end of the corridor, and beating like... like a Gobball's heart freshly pulled from its body. You mustn't leave that there, it's going to bring bad luck to the mine, a thing like that! As you're interested, I could tell you where it is, in exchange for a few kamas. That suits you and we get rid of it. Everyone's a winner."

Kay Vine was just a few feet away from the place the mad old fool had told him about. Armed with his Twiggy Sword, he'd managed to put an end to all the sick Tofus who were blocking his path, but he could feel his strength draining away... weakened, exhausted, numb from cold, he was just seconds from collapsing when suddenly, he saw it...

Stuck between the stalagmites (which go up) and the stalactites (which go down), the Ice Dofus was lighting up the cavern with its aura. The frozen fruit of Aguabrial's entrails was there, within his grasp, and just one hideous eight-legged, four-headed, two-tentacled monster was there to defend it.

When he swaggered out of the mine, Kay Vine was another Iop altogether. You could tell from two hundred kametres away that he was the new boss of Astrub, the one who managed to collect not one, but two Dofus... Proud of his exploits, he strutted up and down the city streets for hours, and the more he strutted, the more people paid attention to him. The men frowned when they saw him, the women burst out laughing behind their hands. They were finally admiring Kay Vine for what he was! At least, that's what he thought, but they were really looking at the brown, wet stain that could be seen growing on his trousers.

It was only in touching his pocket to make sure his treasures were still there that Kay Vine realised the extent of his Iopery. The so-called Ice Dofus had melted like snow in the sun. In fact, it had been sculpted from snow, and it had been unusually warm for Aperirel. The unfortunate consequence of this being that the Boo mud from which the Ebony Dofus was made had also started to soften when it came into contact with the water. There was not a trace left of either of the two eggs, just a puddle.

For his part, the Enutrof thought he'd had a very good week indeed. Two false Dofus sold to the very same client, now that's what you call a master stroke. Who said there was no money in art?

185.titleId: Extract from the details of the Agricultural Competition, Frauguctor 5, 550.
185.contentId: A Xelor by the name of Count Harebourg won an agricultural competition organised by the Mayor of Frigost in 550. The contest was to find a way to compete with the continent, particularly in regard to trading in agricultural resources.

186.titleId: Extracts from the Hungry Planet Guide
186.contentId: An island known for its harsh winter, from which it takes its cold-sounding name. Located in the Antinau Sea.

187.contentId:
Oh that precious liquor, that precious juice!


Jiva's promise that Count Harebourg kept!


No more cold winter to freeze the barrel, more and more crops pushing up from the bosom of the earth...



(The rest of the page is torn.)

188.titleId: Extracts from Brouce Boulgoure, a star's life
188.contentId:
Frigost Island owes its current topology to Brouce Boulgoure. Who hasn't heard about the famous duel – uprooting elm trees with one's bare hands – that he challenged the famous Lorko to?


The two lumberjacks pulled up more trees than the clearing of Liroye Merline could boast, but the jury could not decide which of them was the stronger.


Brouce and Lorko continued to send Elms flying without stopping for three days and three nights. On the morning of the fourth, the two lumberjacks, drunk with fatigue, had just enough strength to slap their palms together, in a "high five, buddy!" kind of way. They were on Frigost, and no elms had ever grown on the island, which put an end to the contest.


How had the two lumberjacks gotten there? It's a mystery.

189.titleId: Mission orders, for the attention of Captain Ronan.
189.contentId:
The King of Bonta asked Jiva, Protector of the month of Javian, to attend meetings of the High Council of Bonta several times between Septangel 551 and Frauguctor 552. Jiva told the envoys that as she was on duty for the god Xelor himself, she could not attend the Council. Flushed with authority, and suspecting that some renewed activity in the city of darkness was keeping Jiva busy, the king commissioned several of his best soldiers to follow the Protector and find out what she was up to.



The Protector of Javian was spotted many times leaving the city of Bonta and heading west.


Some ship captains said they saw the Protector hurtling westwards, the most likely destination being Frigost Island.



Your mission, should you choose to accept it (and you have no choice) is to shed some light on the behaviour of Jiva, Protector of Javian, and loyal and devoted ally of Bonta.

190.titleId: The Notes of Captain Ronan, Bonta Militia
190.contentId:
We arrived on the 26 Descendre, during the night. We landed at a bend in the coast. The place was deserted, perfect for a discreet arrival. Contrary to what is being said about this island, where the winter is allegedly one of the most rigorous in the world, the night was clear and the air was quite mild. After leaving our snowshoes and furs on the boat, we made our way towards the interior of the island.


Our first objective is to infiltrate Frigost Village and gather information about what is going off on this island, either in books or from the mouths of the Frigostians themselves. We leave today, the 26 Descendre.

191.titleId: The Notes of Mitsu, Bontarian Scout
191.contentId:
(Remarks heard during various conversations.)



...Those damned Amaknians! We'll cut their wheat from under their feet, let me tell you. They'll have Frigost to reckon with. The year 552 will mark a milestone in the annals of commerce!




...An ingenious Xelor, enamoured by beautiful, mechanical watches. But he spends too much time with commoners and riff-raff...




...If he hadn't been there, all of Frigost would still have frozen fingers and runny noses. And that's not good for trade...




...When do we eat?

192.contentId:
Wakfu is perpetual life flow, which passes through all forms to give them substance. Everything is Wakfu; everything returns to Wakfu, in an eternal, unbreakable cycle.


Or does it? We have long believed that nothing can get in the way of the cycle of life, but numerous researchers have proven that it is possible to solidify Wakfu, as crystals or even as chewing gum. It seems absurd to say that something so free-flowing can be made to stop, but the proof is undeniable: some rocks and other surfaces with absorbent properties are capable of retaining a flow of Wakfu.


It is claimed that this retention can have dire consequences on the immediate environment, commonly known as Stasis. Yes, Stasis, the mysterious energy that some people believe is the evil opposite of Wakfu, is not a different energy at all, but rather a state of Wakfu itself: arrested Wakfu.

Without going into detail, since the inventory of formed crystals still needs to be done, what we know by the name of Stasis is made up of radiation emitted by arrested Wakfu.


Let's try, for a moment, to imagine Wakfu as a liquid made up of small, smiling blue circles. My hand is the receptacle, and the property of my hand is its ability to close and catch the fluid. Once it's trapped in my hand, a portion of the Wakfu cannot flow anymore. The blue circles start freaking out, getting worked up. The more a blue circle gets worked up, the more square and angular it becomes, and it gets redder and redder. When it's bright red, it's very, very angry.

Angry Wakfu emits radiation, red radiation that slowly "contaminates" the receptacle's surroundings. But contamination isn't really the right word, because this radiation, which we have named Stasis, feeds off Wakfu by eating any that is available and converting it into Stasis.


So, what happens if I open my hand? If I do it quickly, before the radiation becomes too powerful, the Wakfu becomes round again, and happily returns to its dance. If I wait too long, the charge from the build-up of hatred will create a Stasis explosion the minute I open my hand – a deflagration – then the Wakfu will, once again, become Wakfu.

The question is this: if Wakfu is everywhere, and if only a small amount of Stasis radiation is capable of exponentially eating the Wakfu, why hasn't all the Wakfu already been assimilated, since quite a large amount of Stasis has already been produced?


The first experiments carried out by Otomai's disciples concluded that, once its source has been removed, Stasis has an expiration date. So, if my fist remains closed, the radiation emitted will continue to spread, but, if I open my fist, eventually the time will come when this Stasis runs out of energy, loses its density and, eventually, ceases to exist.


Far from being purely lethal, Stasis radiation can be harnessed and used to run generators and machines, or can even be used to cure certain ailments. But in too great a quantity, Stasis can be destructive. Just like Wakfu, uncontrolled, destroying everything in its path. Neither Good nor Evil, ultimately. Everything in moderation, therefore, is the key to equilibrium.

Thanks to the excavation of Astrub's foundations, the remains of Vili Valley, the home of the first Eliatrope colony, have been discovered. Our archaeologists have found what's left behind of a vast initiation ground, a giant playing field where young Eliatropes would have learned the ritual acts that would mark their passage into adulthood. These acts, these Mysteries, involve a meticulous imitation of the initial reaction of the prophet Chibi when he first discovered the existence of the reality of Wakfu.


The reality of Wakfu. These words ring like a death sentence to our ears, accustomed only to hearing the rational. But the Eliatropes lived their lives by way of Mysteries, and these days, we know next to nothing about these delicate, myriad prophecies. The very taste of the unknown has deserted our desensitised palates.

Mystery. The word seems to come from far away, at least as far as the horizon. You'll never catch it; it's a gap, a line of demarcation between mankind and the invisible kingdom. A mystery that, if we stick to our modern definitions, is a secret, enveloped in an enigma, played out in a game of charades.


But for our ancestors, a Mystery was a ritual, an instant passage to a revelation that, confronted with the abstraction of a deity, gave the individual the strength to brave the shadows. The mystic had to remove the veils of a mortal existence from their eyes to contemplate the movement of a free soul. The veils were the successive complexities of the Goddess, the intimate Mystery of her presence in the world. In order to reveal it, the Mystic had to learn to see.

The tablets of glyphs tell us there are three veils. Three layers of understanding to shed like the used skins of a truth, worn out by the successive interpretations of a people in peril. Faced with the Void, a young Eliatrope had to learn to look between the threads to discover, tentatively, the Great Goddess's body. Her hands, her face, her hair. Each veil more difficult than the last to remove, requiring discipline and concentration.


To see the Goddess, Chibi crossed Vili on foot, like a tightrope walker, and it was these steps, these tense hands, that the Eliatropes must faithfully recreate. Conditioned by weeks of training, by rigorous fasting, their bodies learned to produce a meaning, timelessness, a divine out-of-worldliness, before once again being able to step out into the daylight.

"The universe is an egg, created by the Great Dragon to prove his love to the Goddess. At the centre of the egg is the source of all life, the egg blue, an ocean of Wakfu swept by winds of change. Somewhere in this ocean journeys a whale, the Wakfu whale, a huge blue leviathan. When it exhales, the whale ejects a violent jet of Wakfu filled with fragments of worlds. We gave a name to these fragments: we call them the islands. Legend has it that by climbing to the very top of these islands, you can reach the egg blue, a vast tornado where it is said you can reach other universes, other timelines, or even discover the secret room where the Goddess comes to rest from her dance with the Great Dragon."

The myths are not literal truths, even if they sometimes surprise us with their extreme details. Before the poets assembled them as one, disregarding certain paradoxes, the myths were the fragments of a continuous story, a maze of possibilities, where everything existed along with its opposite.


The Zinit petroglyphs are our main reference to the world before the time of gods. This patchwork allows us to weave a more ambitious and vast cultural context so we may place the Eliatrope civilisation in the evolution of the World of Twelve, and in the cosmos. We now know that the Eliatropes thought of the afterlife as an eternity spent alongside the Goddess. This eternity would take place in the contemplation of an amazing world that was constantly being renewed.

204.contentId:
I met Emilk when he first arrived in Frigost. At that time, I was still a novice shoemaker, but I already had a few avant-garde ideas. I had, for example, created a pair of boots filled with holes, to limit how much a Sadida's feet would sweat. My slogan was simple: "Detox, the boot that breathes".


As a master shoemaker, Emilk was instantly interested in my work... and in me! We hit it off straight away and, as he'd only just arrived on the island and hadn't found anywhere to stay yet, I invited him to stay at my house that night. The night turned into weeks, weeks into months and then, one day, we got married. I'd finally found the shoe that fit!

I didn't really know anything about him, but it didn't matter. Our days were full of happiness and new experiences. We exchanged belts, and worked on our respective leathers; we offered each other our feet to try out our creations...


Occasionally, when he had too much to do, I would lovingly polish his magnificent purses before displaying them proudly in the window. Our little business was flourishing and it didn't take long for word of our work to go beyond the borders of Frigost...

One night, when Emilk was out getting us a new supply of Gobbly leather, a stranger came into the shop. His face was covered by a large hood and he spoke with a heavy Amaknian accent. He perused our different articles and seemed particularly interested in the boots made by my husband. He asked me some questions about Emilk, his work, and his past...


I thought it was odd, but I had nothing to hide. After a few minutes, my husband came back with his arms full of freshly tanned hides. As soon as he saw the stranger, he froze, rooted to the spot, and dropped his load. The two men stared at each other for a moment, and then they threw themselves at each other with enormous violence. It was mad! I'd never seen anyone fight like that before. The kicks were flying in all directions; they were constantly tripping one another up and stepping on one another's heels. Anyone would have thought it was a type of dance where the aim was to turn the partner around to give them a kick up the bum.

All of a sudden, the stranger carried out a formidable piqué arabesque, knocking Emilk to the ground. But while he was preparing to deal my husband a fatal blow, the latter got out his secret boot. It's a leather boot with a lead heel that he always keeps up his sleeve. He was back on his feet in a flash and hit the stranger over the head with his deadly weapon. Too horrified to think or protest, I helped him to throw the body out to sea. But it didn't take me long to come back to my senses! Who was this stranger we'd just turned into Snapper food? And what did he want from us? What horrible nightmare had Emilk got himself embroiled in? Who was the man I'd married?

"I'm not who you think I am," he told me. "My real name is Klime. And the man you saw... the man I killed... was Arthur Luthuthu. We both belonged to a brotherhood of shoemakers. A discreet brotherhood, specialised in martial arts and saving the world.


"But maybe we should start at the very beginning: Our Grand Master, Hogmeiser, founded the Order of the Kicked Ass about ten years ago. He was the one who recruited us: Arthur Luthuthu, Bowisse and myself. At the beginning, there were four of us, just like the sacred Elements. That wasn't an accident: we had actually set ourselves the objective of studying the properties of the Quadramental Breeze. We were carrying out loads of experiments on leathers and hides, in order to sublimate the virtues and create very powerful magical objects. We were all very gifted, but I was, without any doubt, the best of the four! So, of course, the others became jealous of my talent...

One day, I managed to create a pair of super-powerful boots, brimming with elemental magic. It was the culmination of all my work. I was so proud that I felt I ought to make more pairs and put them up for sale. But when the members of the Order learned of it, they were very quick to protest. They said these boots were too powerful to be distributed to mere mortals. That if they got into the wrong hands, they could be very dangerous! Pff! Bunkum! They were just jealous, that's all! They couldn't fool me!

When they started talking about getting back the boots I'd already sold, I wanted to stop them! They wanted to destroy them and replace them with inoffensive copies! I couldn't be having that! It was my work! The greatest success of my career! And I wanted the whole world to know what an exceptional craftsman I was! Seeing that I was going to ruin his plans, Hogmeiser decided he was going to take preventative measures. He ordered them to lock me in the basement of our workshop to shut me up. While I was locked up, the members of the Order could quietly steal the boots I'd sold and replace them.

I later learned they'd completely disassociated me from the Order and had erased all trace of my membership. They told anyone that would listen that the boots were faulty and it was the fault of a shoemaker called L. Lee Vatorchains, or something like that. Even worse, they had even gone as far as staging my death, in case anyone ever asked what had become of me. As if they hadn't already humiliated me enough, they made up some grotesque story about an accident with a Jelly. Well, the Order always had been the masters of obfuscation. I've lost count of the number of times we lied about our dates of birth or our identities!

But I wasn't going to let them bury me that easily! I'd kept a pair of boots, which I'd hidden not far from the shoemakers' shop. All I had to do was find a way to free myself and get them. Luckily, Bowisse, who had tied me up, hadn't thought to look under my belt. That was where I kept my tools. My leather cutter! I managed to cut myself free and get out of there. I found my precious boots right where I'd left them and I decided to lie low for a while. But I hadn't forgotten that Hogmeiser and I had some business to settle! He'd locked me up! He'd let people think I was dead! He'd taken away my life! And now it was my turn to take his!

One day, I followed one of his hunting parties. He quite often went Gobball hunting to restock his leather supply. I waited until he had his back turned, busy cleaning some slobber off his shoe, and bam! With one blow of my boot to his elbow, he was eliminated! So as not to arouse suspicion, I dragged his body to the centre of the ruminants and let the War Chiefs do the rest. It was an almost perfect crime! Now I'd gotten my revenge, there was nothing to keep me in Amakna anymore. I decided to head off to a faraway country, where the remaining members of the Order wouldn't think to look for me: Frigost. That's when I met you. You already know the rest. Bowisse must be in charge now instead of Hogmeiser, and he obviously sent Arthur to look for me. But any threat has been thwarted, for now..."

When Emilk... erm Klime, I mean, finished his story, I was completely gobsmacked. The person I'd loved and cherished was a traitor. A murderer. A fugitive! And all I wanted was a quiet, uncomplicated life! I couldn't bring myself to stay with this monster! I remained impassive. I pretended that I understood, and that I supported him. But inside, I was horrified. I waited until he was asleep, then I grabbed one of his purses and quickly packed my bags. I fled. For a little while, I hid at my aunt's house and, once I'd cried every tear in my body, I decided to leave Frigost.


At the time of writing, I am getting ready to board a ship to Amakna. I haven't seen Klime since that fateful night, a few weeks ago. The last I heard of him, he'd been approached by Count Harebourg, the nobleman who lives at the top of Mount Scauldron. Apparently, he's been recruited to work on a special project. I don't know any more than that. And I don't want to.


I'm leaving Frigost, and it's the right thing to do.

205.contentId:
25th Maysial 549


I have just discovered a very fascinating treatise! I found it when I was browsing through the Amakna library archives. It's a paper on alchemy which discusses the question of immortality! If what's written is true, it should be possible to create a sort of life-extending elixir! Unfortunately, some of the pages are missing and, without a list of ingredients, I don't think it will be possible for me to recreate the recipe...


9th Junssidor 549


I've read the book from cover to cover, but I've still found no trace of the recipe! I did manage to decipher the names of some of the ingredients, but the list is incomplete. And without the quantities, there's nothing I can do anyway! I think I'm just going to have to forget about it...


17th Junssidor 549


I'm obsessed by this theory. I'm going to try a few experiments, basing them on the list of ingredients I've managed to compile. If I add other resources, I might end up figuring out the recipe! We'll see... I've already ordered a big piece of Dark Treechnid Bark. I hope it will work! I'm really going into this blind, but nothing ventured, nothing gained!

12th Jullier 549


It's a catastrophe! A real catastrophe! The consequences of my experiment have been disastrous! I think the Dark Treechnid Bark reacted badly during the process and the potion blew up my workshop! It must be the dark side of the Bark... I don't think I'll ever dare to leave the house again. The explosion's left me completely disfigured! My face is so badly burned I could almost be mistaken for a Bwork! I think I'm going to have to find myself an apprentice. At the very least, they'll be able to help me fix everything that was destroyed...


5th Septangel 549


It really was a good idea to take on an apprentice! Thanks to him, I'm progressing much more quickly than I thought! I send him to get supplies in my place and I've asked him to pretend he's me, so that no one comes looking to meet me. I don't want them to see me like this, with my hideous face... So, my name's now associated with my disciple's young face! It's better like that. I've ordered a hood that will cover my whole head. Then I won't scare anyone anymore. And I'm going to be able to restart my experiments without having to worry about any danger.

21st Novamaire 549


Today is a great day! The first step towards success! I've finally managed to get a result. Ok, it's not really what I had hoped for, but it's a beginning! I've christened this first bottle Longevity Potion. I hope this is an auspicious sign of things to come!


28th Novamaire 549


Last night, my apprentice died. He wanted to test my Longevity Potion, but he took the wrong bottle. He took poisoned Unikron Blood instead. I knew I shouldn't have left it lying round on the shelf! I don't know what I'm going to do without him. I feel like I'm not far off the goal! But without help, I might have trouble making the progress I'd like. Hmm... I think I need to give it some thought. I think I'll go for a walk around the Isle O'Anstitch to clear my head a bit. Apparently the ice never melts over there, so it should be refreshing at least!


13th Descendre 549


Something amazing has just happened! The potion sample I had in my pocket seems to react to lower temperatures. I'd hardly arrived on the Isle O'Anstitch when it started to bubble and transform! I wanted to test the effects of the reaction straight away, but I thought it would be better not to take useless risks... So, I went looking for a guinea pig. I convinced a passing adventurer that it was a health potion, and he drank it. The poor guy didn't last very long! But I'm convinced I'm on the right track! Haha!


6th Javian 550


I've just returned home, but everything's been turned upside down! Someone must have discovered the body of my apprentice and thought it was me. I've almost certainly been declared dead by now. Hmm... I think it's time for me to leave. There's nothing left for me to do here. I've heard inventors and alchemists are welcome on Frigost. I'll try my luck there. Apparently, the winters there are very harsh. It's perfect! I'll be able to study the effects of the cold on my potion more closely!

206.subTitleId: The Incredible Adventures of Captain Amakna - Volume 26
206.contentId:
For the attention of Mister S.

Dear Sir,

Following your order of the 26th Septangel 550, we are sending you the latest volume of the Incredible Adventures of Captain Amakna, as agreed.

Regards,

Toy Stole, Head Librarian, Amakna Library.

P.S. The library refuses all responsibility for any damage the book may have suffered in transit. For compensation claims, please contact Amakna-Frigost intercontinental transport.

Having just dealt a crushing defeat to the ignoble Pink Skull, his sworn enemy, and taken him to the King's militia, Captain Amakna decided it was time to take a holiday. He did deserve a rest, after all. So, he took the cannon to Moon Island and poof! In a flash of lightning, he found himself on a sandy beach, sipping Kokoko milk.

But this break didn't last for very long. A new threat was on its way to cause trouble in the relative calm of the World of Eleven. A mysterious serial thief was spreading panic in the Imp Village. And, according to the King's spies, they were now heading straight for Amakna!

Faster than the wind, more tanned than a Cawwot fried in palm oil, Captain Amakna set off back to his proud country and started to investigate. He headed for the Cania Plains straight away and climbed to the top of one of the centenarian trees to reach the Imp's fortified castle. What he saw there left him speechless: someone had horribly mutilated the village's Mace and Rickshaw Robots! They had removed all their limbs and had even taken away their parts, and they'd even stolen their joints! It was unacceptable! The imps were unrivalled builders and these wooden machines were once their pride and joy, as well as their main defence weapons. The Captain couldn't let this horrible crime go unpunished! But how could he find the culprit? He didn't seem to have left a single clue behind! That's when our defender of justice noticed an inscription on one of the village platforms. Someone had written a message there, in elbow grease: "Save the dear breeder, save the world...- Sylargh"

All this was very mysterious indeed. Captain Amakna didn't really understand what Sylargh meant by that. What was the point of stripping down all those Imp Robots? And who was this "dear breeder" that had to be saved? Was the world in that much danger? Armed with his legendary intuition, Captain Amakna decided to continue his investigation in Astrub. The rumours were flying in the City of Mercenaries, and he was sure he'd find what he was looking for there. He also hoped to find out more about this famous breeder from the message. They're talking about a mysterious breeder, recently arrived in the town, and already known for their exorbitant prices. If the Captain was looking for a very "dear" breeder, that was probably the one he was looking for! It was said he kept a farm near the Amakna mines. But, of course, no one could say anything for sure.

Not that it matters! These small snippets of information were more than enough for our glorious Captain! Without a moment's thought, he headed straight for the mine in question in the hope of shedding some light on the mystery. Alas! He'd realised his error as soon as he'd entered the mine: He played right into the paws of the Boowolf. In less time than it takes for an Enutrof to grab a coin that's fallen on the floor, Sylargh had thrown himself on him and knocked him out. When he came back to his senses, the Captain was tied to an abandoned chariot, deep inside the mine. He squinted in the dark and could make out bits of wood and metal stacked up around him. They were the parts stolen from the Imp Robots! He had been brought here... but why? Our valiant hero hardly had time to think about it. Sylargh was coming towards him, snickering, half hidden by the dark. His eyes were shining with hatred, he was smiling evilly and he was the same height as a Xelor dwarf... because he was an Imp! Oh, yes! A measly, little Imp! The Captain couldn't believe his eyes. This vulgar shrimp, no bigger than a baby Tofu, had managed to put him out of harm's way!

"Mwa ha ha ha!", laughed Sylargh with a voice from beyond the grave. "So, here's the famous Captain Amakna, trapped in an abandoned mine! It's funny, don't you think? The call of the poor breeder in distress, the world to save, all that... you couldn't resist, could you? Haha!" Heroes these days are so predictable! It's almost becoming tiresome. I knew you wouldn't think twice about rushing into these tunnels. You see, I know how these things work! It's a sort of gift! I'm a very special person! Just like you... But you must be wondering why I wanted you here! Well, I'm going to tell you! I know from experience that the best evil geniuses shouldn't unveil their plans before they carry them out, but I like to boast about my exploits! So, here's my story:

I'm one of the best builders in my village. THE best, some say. And they're right. No need for false modesty, is there? I am the most gifted, that's indisputable! Well, not so long ago I drew some plans for a new prototype of the Mace Robot. It was a real marvel! The problem was that I didn't have enough materials to build it. I could have asked my Imp brothers to help me find some, but I don't like begging. So, I helped myself! The scraps you see around you are the ones I stole from my village's Robots. But I'm sure you'd already figured that out... What you don't know, though, is that to finish my invention, I need a metal that is both very light and extremely resistant. I've tried all the known minerals in Amakna, but none of them have worked. I need something else. Something like your famous shield, for example! Mwa ha ha! It's said it's been forged out of a rare and precious metal. That's true, isn't it? Hmm... I see I wasn't wrong about you! What would you say to me taking it off your hands and melting it down to forge the pieces I need? It could be fun, no?"

At these words, Captain Amakna felt fear for the first time in his incredible life. The idea that his magnificent shield might be taken away terrorised him. If such a dreadful thing were to happen, he might never get over it. He couldn't let that happen! So, listening just to his courage, the Captain decided to act... and reveal his secret! His shield was unique, of course. But the metal it was made of wasn't that rare. It was only unknown in Amakna. The Captain had had it secretly imported from far away Frigost, so he could keep his monopoly on ultra-powerful shields. Apparently, the Frigostians had a little island with rich mineral resources. That was where the famous mineral his shield had been forged with came from. But that was all he knew about it. All he could say was that his shield was nothing compared to the vast quantity of minerals Sylargh would find on Frigost. There was no point in destroying it!

Upon hearing this, Sylargh seemed to hesitate. He didn't know whether or not to believe the Captain. He thought about it, and then approached our hero, menacingly. He seized the shield, held it in the air, above the forge he'd just built and... He suddenly turned around and hit the Captain over the head with it. Knocked out once more, our hero sunk into the meanderings of his unconscious.

When he came round again, our illustrious Captain was alone in the mine. Sylargh had disappeared, leaving the hero's shield at his feet. No one knew where he'd gone, but he was never again heard of in Amakna. It's said that a Pandawa saw him getting on a ship headed for Frigost. But, as everyone knows, Pandawa hallucinations are very common. And it's very rare one of their accounts forms the basis of an investigation. Whatever happened, Captain Amakna had other fish to fry. The King's militia had just announced the escape of Pink Skull, his old enemy...
