274.subTitleId: The Beauty, the Brave and the Dragon
274.contentId:
Young ladies and gentlemen who pay me the honour of reading these lines, I would like to propose an interlude whereby I tell you an old legend... For those of you who can read between the lines, it should tell you a lot about the history of the world...

Once upon a time, long after the pact between gods and demons was sealed, a dragon named Bolgrot arrived in the Eternal Amakna. The young Rykke Errel, a fearless Iop, was the only one courageous enough to face the creature.

Instead of reducing it to dust (and "dust" is an understatement), as he could easily have done, the dragon bowed down before the young knight and swore loyalty to him.

Months went by. The two friends strolled across the fields, frolicked through the land of Amakna making jokes, drank ice-cold beer in the sunshine – it was a curious sight to most people's eyes. After all, dragons and knights would usually be seen fighting to the death over a young lady (and, to be more precise, whether the lady should be pure, as the knight preferred, or char broiled, as the dragon preferred).

As is often the case in myths and tales, Rykke was not only young but also very handsome. Legend knows not whether he was rich or poor, but we can probably assume that he was anything but a lowly beggar. Anyway, one day he met Helsephine, a sorceress who also happened to be young and beautiful, and he fell madly in love with her.

Yet, they didn't live happily ever! Is there any justice in this world? Read on!

Rykke was very happy to be able to introduce his lady-love to his friend Bolgrot. There was no way he could have guessed what was going to happen. The dragon, mad with jealous rage, killed sweet Helsephine and flew far away, destroying everything in his path – quite disruptive for the neighbours! Rykke set off after the dragon. When he found him, the old friends confronted one another in a titanic fight. Rykke's magic and weapons succeeded in bringing Bolgrot down, but the young hero was fatally injured in the battle, and died shortly afterwards.

That's when the story took a rather odd twist... Looking for an explanation for Bolgrot's rage, Amakna's wise men discovered six strangely coloured eggs within the beast's entrails: they were genuine dragon eggs! The wise men had a feeling that these eggs would provide their bearer with a power that would make them the gods' equal... They took the decision to hide these terrible relics from the eyes of the world.

As the centuries rolled by, the secret was so well-guarded that, in the end, it was completely forgotten... almost...

275.contentId:
The World of Twelve was plunged into an era of darkness. No one knew it yet but the soft, harmonious aura of the Dofus in which the World had previously bathed had been tainted. The disorder which started creeping its way across the territories was to continue until war burst out between Bonta and Brakmar, the two cities born from the endeavours of the protectors of the months.

The story of the knights of the Order of the Valiant Heart should have been part of History with a capital H – the one written about in books, the one for which statues are erected. Guided by Menalt the centaur, their tragic destiny should have been narrated by all the heralds and bards of the World of Eleven, and set in stone to travel on through the ages... But nay! This was not to be, such was the fear their fate inspired in those who heard about it. If their story has survived long enough to reach our ears, it is only because it was recounted secretly, in low voices during late-night gatherings... a warning to foolhardy and careless youths.

Besides these whispered night-time stories, there is no proof to be found, as all the knights disappeared, body and soul, on one cold night in Septangel. It was at the beginning of the World...

Rushu had crushed a piece of Xelor's Clock and imposed Djaul as the protector of Descendre. Since then, the World had lived in the fearful shadow of Rushu's henchman, who had killed the great Solar with his own hands. And though his attempt at stealing the Dofus guarded by Aguabrial had been unsuccessful, it had led to the birth of a quick-tempered and unpredictable dragon named Bolgrot. Something told Djaul that, sooner or later, he would be able to use the dragon to his advantage. All of this created a sense of instability across the World, and the protective aura of the Dofus became sullied by such intense greed...

Despite this, Rushu remained unsatisfied. The lord of the demons wanted to become a god too, to be venerated by followers made in his image. But he had been refused! And a goddess called Sacrier had snatched his place in the pantheon for herself! By way of compensation, Rushu had asked Djaul to build a whole city in his honour. This city would become his temple, and he would have his followers! For Rushu intended to convert the other gods' disciples to worship him: they would sport red wings and would look like demons! And that's how the city of Brakmar, built in one night by Rushu himself, was devoted to the demon lord's sect...

Xelor, meanwhile, had decided that Jiva was worthy of succeeding Solar. He had also asked Menalt, centaur warrior and commander of the Order of the Valiant Heart, to be the protector of Martalo, the month of storms and showers. Menalt accepted. Just like Jiva and Pouchecot, the protectors of Javian and Frauguctor respectively, he had moved into the brand new city of Bonta. One month had been long enough for the three protectors to build the city, with the help of the ten gods. The city was built to counter the rise of Brakmar and the cult of Rushu. A year passed before it faced its first battle.

Septangel 12 of the year 26. The dawn was cold, and light could barely penetrate the morning gloom. The Bontarian outposts, held by the knights of the Order, were white with the first signs of frost, the sentinels numb from the early onset of winter. They huddled around the braziers, trying in vain to warm up. The forest, whose multitude of little noises usually started rustling to life at this hour of the morning, was completely silent, but for a cry that had been heard several times during the night. At first, the sentinels had paid it no heed, but now they squinted into the distance towards its apparent source in the south. The cry – surely produced by some completely ordinary creature, they told themselves – was getting closer.

The faction captain suspected some kind of ruse from the enemy. The Brakmarians had been very quiet lately, probably too quiet. He sent a messenger to Bonta. Suddenly, the dark stillness before them started to toss restlessly; there was something moving, just out of view of the sentinels! After a few astonished seconds, they rushed to the alarm bells... but it was too late! A wild clamour drowned out the ringing. The knights heard the echo of drumbeats. They were under attack! Troops piled up on both sides of the mounts of Sidimote and streamed down towards them. The commotion shook the very earth. And still, dawn did not break.

In Bonta, Jiva had raised the alarm and was preparing the militia: if the attack reached the city, they would have to face the enemy. She urged the defenders on, stationing archers at arrow slits and infantrymen behind the doors. They could hear the muffled pounding of the marching troops from beyond the outer walls. The enemy was gaining ground, and fast! This was not a good sign... Now Menalt and Pouchecot were at Jiva's side. After a quick exchange, the three of them reached an agreement. Jiva would be in charge of the city's defence. By common accord, Menalt and Pouchecot each took the head of a squad composed of fifty knights of the Order of the Valiant Heart, a good half of whom were centaurs obeying Menalt's orders, and the rest of whom were ferociously armed infantry.

Swords drawn, they rushed out to help their comrades, bellowing "Bonta shall triumph!" Alas! Far away in the distance, the outposts had been swallowed up the by horde of goblins. No fewer than forty knights had perished, engulfed by their numbers. Reinforcements had arrived too late. The Bontarian troops sped up and the centaurs galloped faster than ever. The goblins were no doubt just the start of the attack being launched against Bonta.

Enemies swarmed before them. Dawn seemed to be suspended, the night never-ending. Suddenly, a jet of pale grey flames blazed over the goblin troops, casting a weak light over the battle. That sinister cry sounded once more. The Brakmarians had swept away the Bontarian outposts. In front of him, Menalt watched in dismay as the last knights were chased and finished off by Karne Riders. They were commanded by a Brakmarian captain, a dark Iop who himself stayed back from the front line.

"Brakmar's forces are considerable but not invincible!" said Pouchecot. "Your centaurs must smash into the sides of the enemy troops. The goblins will be closed in from both sides. Then I'll crush them and we can take on the Brakmarian war chiefs with our full force! You know as well as I that most creatures under Brakmarian command are unruly, brainless brutes. They'll flee if their command structure is beheaded. Then we'll deal with whatever's producing that devilish cry!" Thus spoke Pouchecot, and Menalt nodded solemnly.

The knights surged in to attack the goblin troops... Slaughter! Carnage! Massacre! The Bontarian heroes brandished their blades and their breastplates were spattered with fresh blood with each blow! They finally stopped to catch their breath. The knights gathered around Menalt and Pouchecot. They hadn't borne any losses, just a few surface wounds. Menalt took a look around him to size up the extent of the battle's damage. The attack had gone well. Very well. Too well. The centaur scanned the surroundings for the dark Iop he had spotted earlier. The warrior had joined the rest of the Brakmarian troops and now appeared to be harnessing the troops' thirst for violence. Why hadn't this army of Chafer skeletons come to save the goblins...? Menalt realised they had made a mistake. A deafening cry split the darkness, accompanied by another flash of grey lightning. The goblins had been a trap! The worst was yet to come...

276.contentId:
There was a warrior, a single, enormous warrior wearing black armour approaching them now. He came alone, and the Brakmarians parted to let him pass. He roared and the Bontarians around him crumpled and fell to the ground. Angered at seeing his knights recoil like this, Menalt urged them to fight. He raised his spear above his head and hurled himself into the attack. Pouchecot shouted at him to wait but the centaurs were already on their way to attack the first enemy lines. The collision was terrible, metal clashed against metal, the horns of war were blown and the drums beaten loudly. Cutting and thrusting, Menalt forced his way through towards the Brakmarian war chief. If he fell, victory would be Bonta's! Menalt could see the warrior fighting. With each of his blows, a knight collapsed, his armour slashed open by the black sword. The tip of his blade curved and circled smoothly through the air; it was as though two dark wings were whipping to and fro around him. The black warrior had the same intention as Menalt.

"I am Menalt, commander of the Order of the Valiant Heart, Protector of Martalo! Whoever you are, your hours are numbered!" shouted Menalt over the commotion. Battle was raging all around them. Menalt had taken his armour off – far from protecting him, it was hindering his movements before his fearsome adversary.

"I'm going to take back your ill-gotten gains, centaur! Pray to your god, that he open the gates to the kingdom of the dead for you and for your knights! And tell him that Hyrkul will bring Bonta down today!" Streams of black smoke were billowing from his helmet. Menalt, who was seeing him up close for the first time, was stunned to see that his enemy was able to use black fire as a weapon. "Sacrilege!" he exclaimed. "You sully the fire of Ouronigride and you will be cursed for it!"

"My name is Hyrkul and it'll follow you into the other world, centaur!" screamed the other, and both of them rushed forward to strike. In less than a second, everything was over. Menalt brandished his spear, whose point glowed with white fire. He lunged forward, aiming at the hollow of the throat where the plates of the black armour were spaced out enough for his blow to be lethal. But the warrior dodged and the spear jabbed uselessly into the darkness. Hyrkul's wide, shadowy wings swirled to lash and blind the centaur. Before the centaur could launch a second attack, Hyrkul grabbed his spear in one hand, and his throat in the other. They both bellowed, one in rage and the other in pain. A blaze of lightning sprang from the black helmet, hitting Menalt in the face for a few seconds that seemed like an eternity. Then the warrior pushed the stunned and twitching centaur back to deliver the deathblow. He twirled his sword; the blade spun with a whistling sound and cut swiftly downwards. Menalt dropped noiselessly into the dust.

The warrior kept on spinning his sword and bellowing. An intense burst of fire shot from the back of his throat and set his blade alight. The flame caught and spread, growing ever wider and more dangerous. The knights had seen their chief fall and had started to retreat in horror. Then, a dragon of black lightning materialised from the end of Hyrkul's sword. The beast reared up to its full height, towering over them all, and then dove downwards through the Bontarian troops, who caught fire instantly. Knights fell one after the other, and the other Bontarian warriors were blown away by the explosion. Pouchecot only survived thanks to his magic. He shot roots deep down into the earth, like a hundred-year-old tree. The battlefield was strewn with the cracked armour of fallen knights. A freezing rain started to pour down. The Brakmarian troops started to make their way towards Bonta. Hyrkul turned to face the gigantic tree that Pouchecot had become. His transformation protected him from danger, but prevented him from moving. The black giant roared with spine-chilling laughter.

"I shall carve your coffin in your own wood, Pouchecot! But first... I want to see Jiva's head hanging in your branches!" He spat and strode away to join his army. The fortified walls of Bonta stood out in the distance, as pale as chalk.

The knights of the Order of the Valiant Heart had all perished...

It seemed to the defenders of Bonta that day would never break again. Was this night the last they would ever live to see? Jiva was not the only one staring up at the sky, trying to penetrate the mysteries of the curse bearing down upon them. Raval, the protector of Septangel, had climbed to the top of the Sidimote hills to study the battlefield and the persistent, jinxed darkness. Five hours! The sun should have been out for five hours already! These hours were precious to him, the protector of Septangel. Five hours had been stolen from the month he was supposed to protect... He would have to explain this to Xelor!

The black warrior was extremely powerful. Exterminating a hundred knights was one thing. Annihilating Menalt was another. But rendering Pouchecot powerless... Was there no limit to the warrior's power?

"If I try to stand between him and Bonta to reclaim my stolen hours, I risk being killed... As for Bonta, my dear Jiva, you're dead meat... But if Bonta falls, this night might last for eternity... and that will be the end of Septangel." Raval could not bear to imagine that. He went down to the battlefield. The goblins that had survived the battle were forming a hobbling rear guard. There, amidst goblin corpses and empty armour, Raval had the idea that was to save Septangel. The same man who strove to suck the life out of every plant and flower as soon as Frauguctor's back was turned was about to breathe life back into the souls of the dead knights. He had that power...

At his command, the ghosts of the knights of the Order of the Valiant Heart rose. Their discarded armour hit the ground with metallic thuds. Burnt, flayed and cut, they all bore gaping wounds. Raval walked through the ranks in silence, then pointed towards the Brakmarian army. Hyrkul's troops had reached the gates of Bonta. Any minute now, they were going to give way to the Trools' steady hammering. Militia men, gathered by Jiva, had formed a wall of armour. But goblins were already trying to sneak in through the gaps in the door, which were widening with each passing second. Hyrkul had put his sword back in its sheath and was striking with his mace. All of a sudden, he paused mid-motion, and turned back as though someone had called out to him...

Cries of distress were coming from the back. The huge warrior, taken aback, listened carefully. It was not the cries of fear that worried him. He had cast his eyes to the south. And there he saw his troops being overcome by the knights of the Order – the very same knights he had killed with his black lightning! This white tide rolled slowly over the Brakmarians. Just then, Bonta's horns rang out. Jiva had opened up the doors and the militia was moving forward to take on the Brakmarian troops, taking back the ground that had been conquered, metre by metre.

Hyrkul had not foreseen such a reversal of fortune. The Brakmarian troops were caught in a stranglehold. He watched as the ghostly knights, immune to blows, hacked his army to pieces. The confusion was total. His captain was beating a retreat. Goblins and Chafers tried to flee but were killed on the spot by ghost knights. He struggled to extricate himself from the fray, and, knowing the battle was lost, Hyrkul glanced one last time at Bonta, so close, before fleeing towards the Treechnid Forest. He may not have been victorious, but now he knew for sure that Bonta did not have any Dofus. Jiva and Pouchecot would not have hesitated to brandish them at the battle's most critical moment, to show their power and scare the Brakmarian troops away... This simple detail was worth all the losses the troops of Brakmar had borne... Hyrkul disappeared into the dark forest.

A cry of victory went up throughout Bonta. The survivors could finally see daybreak. Raval climbed back up the Sidimote hills to watch Brakmar's retreat. The dawn was crimson. And this colour was to lend its name to this historic battle in the tales later told of it. "The Crimson Dawn" was the first battle in which Bonta and Brakmar had fought one another, and one of the bloodiest in the period that came to be known as "the war of the cities".

277.subTitleId: How a shepherd became king of Amakna
277.contentId:
Four Rings in the Sky: p. 3

The Broken Pact: p. 5

Devastation and Desolation: p. 6

Amakna Subjugated by Demons: p. 7

Allister's Guild: p. 8

The Ruse: p. 10

Allister's Triumph: p. 11

Four Rings in the Sky

One cursed day, the wise men discovered that the Bolgrot the dragon's eggs had disappeared. Their search, though done as discreetly as possible, soon drew the attention of vagabonds and other petty thieves... One word was oft repeated during evening gatherings – a word at first whispered in hushed tones, a foreign word full of strange sounds, a word that people did not trust... And the old storytellers, those elders who spoke the ancient dragon language, were suddenly the centre of kind attention. They knew that in dragon language, the word "Dofus" meant "dragon egg". They knew of Rykke Errel's adventures... And in truth, since people would buy them drinks just to hear the tale, they weren't about to miss an opportunity to tell it to anyone who cared to listen! And with each round of drinks, the legend of the Dofus grew, for in those days, truth was less of a concern than a good story. In other words, storytellers exaggerated more than was reasonable...

The most insane rumours were quick to spread, inspiring fear and covetousness well beyond the province. It didn't take long for adventurers to flood into Amakna. And demons. Demons? Yes, demons straight from the neighbouring world – dark and corrupt, hairy (the demons, of course, not the world), and with muscles to make a paladin pale.

In less time than it took to write of it, Esra'Ruoy'Dnim had taken control of a squad of demons, and they were flooding into Amakna.

That day, Allister, still just a young shepherd, was grazing his flock of Gobballs and staring at the sky. The sun had barely risen above the Cania mountains. And strange cloudy rings seemed engraved in the sky...

The Broken Pact

By the time the wise men decided to mark the year 505 with a black stone, it was already too late... I remember the Aerophagus' crushed hopes and my master's bitterness. How could the wise men have been so blind? How could they have believed that the demons had come through space by clumsy accident, as if slipping on a slimy larva skin? That they'd leave the way they came, after eating a few Gobballs and fewer than a dozen lords... At the time, the wise men thought that the Demons of the Hours were just playing a trick. In truth, they didn't want to face facts. Worse, even: they were scared!

Devastation and Desolation

When the demons roasted Amakna's garrison and kept the cooking juices to season Tofu gizzards, the wise men knew for sure what to expect. And many a brave man polished their blades to kill those evil creatures... only to find themselves seasoned with herbs and fermented drinks. Trisboulis, the demon expert, has acknowledged that warriors of fighting age made considerable contributions to demonic culinary arts during this period.

Esra'Ruoy'Dnim had thus denounced the pact signed long ago by his kind! The wise men's worst fears were well-founded: the demon coveted the Dofus!

The gods seemed to have forgotten Amakna... and remained strangely silent, as did the Protectors of the Months. Were they busy showering other worlds with their favours? Were they trying to appease the demons, and notably the most powerful of all, Rushu? Were they fighting him? No one could be sure...

Amakna Subjugated by Demons

Seven black stones were lined up before my master's eyes, and seven years had passed since the demons had invaded Amakna. I remember the events as if it were yesterday... Terror and desolation reigned. The 512th year of the Xelor calendar was beginning, but no one was thinking about celebrations.

Esra'Ruoy'Dnim had reduced the population to slavery. All were forced to scour the earth for Amakna's treasures: gold and precious stones, of course, and, above all, the priceless Dofus! Of the old storytellers, only one had kept his wits (and tongue). And before Esra' and a dozen pincers of all sizes, he asserted that once all six Dofus were united, the gods themselves would welcome the demon as one of their own...

Allister's Guild

But let's get back to Allister and his Gobballs. The young boy had grown into a fine Feca known for his daring. He was the shepherd of the largest flock of Gobballs in Amakna. The invaders, for their part, saw Amakna as a vast playground. They never guessed that those who would later come to be called "Allister's Guild" – for now a group of inexperienced youths and old men – would be their downfall.

One morning, while leading his flock to the fields, Allister met a Feca Lady wearing a horned crown upon her head. A Feca from the upper classes? A princess? Or a queen? The goddess herself? With a gesture, she interrupted his questions and, without opening her mouth, she told him that he, Allister, could bring about the demons' downfall... provided he used neither force nor weapons. But Allister still needed to figure out how to put the Lady's revelation to good use.

If you have read this far, dear Reader, you should know that Allister was the youngest of a long line of Feca shepherds. And if the goddess Feca had chosen him – as indeed she had – it was for a reason. His family was renowned for its famous boiled Gobball black pudding (nonetheless, that is not why he was chosen). His father, and his father's father before him, used a magical object to fatten their beasts: a fetter made of four metallic heads. A snap of the jaws of two of these heads would clamp metal bracelets around a beast's legs, and the other two would open them when it was time to release the beast. This curious object called the "Trip Trap Shackles", which until then had served only to shackle Gobballs, would imprison the cruellest creature that Amakna had ever seen.

The Ruse

Allister decided to sacrifice his entire flock of Gobballs in honour of Esra'Ruoy'Dnim. Ignoring the crowd of Amaknians who booed and whistled, he bled his beasts and offered the demon hundreds of barrels full of Gobball haemoglobin. The gods alone knew that demons were fond of Gobball blood. An ecstatic Esra'Ruoy'Dnim held an orgy with his henchmen, drinking more and more blood until the very last barrel was empty. Then all the demons fell asleep on their bloated stomachs...

While Esra'Ruoy'Dnim slept, Allister placed the Trip Trap Shackles on the demon's wrists. The jaws snapped shut with a loud clack, and Esra' was caught. The fetter did not merely immobilise those who wear it; it also prevented the wearer's digestion. Esra', trapped in his own body and unable to free himself, was thrown into the Amakna prison. Seeing the most powerful of their kind thus defeated, his henchmen fled...

Allister's Triumph

Venerated as Amakna's saviour, Allister was named king. The task of putting as much distance as possible between Esra' and the fetters fell to Fallanster, Allister's brother. He headed north, in secret. Only Allister knew Fallanster's destination: Astrub, City of Mercenaries. And time rolled by...

278.contentId:
One day, as she walked through the forest of Incarnam with a young soul, the Great Huntress heard a thunderous voice calling her name. The god Iop rose up from nowhere amidst the trees. He was on his way back from battle and seemed in a belligerent mood, as usual. He proposed a friendly fight, the winner of which would earn the unconditional devotion of the soul who was walking with the goddess. Cra had no desire at all to test her strength against this brute, whose stench of blood and sweat was unnerving to say the least. All the same, she wasn't one to turn down a challenge. She picked up an Api which had fallen from a tree and asked Iop to put it anywhere he liked. If the goddess manage to hit the Api with an arrow, she would win the young soul's devotion.

Iop knew how accurately Cra could handle her bow. So he decided to complicate matters by placing the Api on the young soul's head, thus testing her courage. If the arrow missed its target, the young soul would be reborn as a disciple of Iop.

The bearded god took up position on a little island right at the north of Incarnam, which is where he placed the Api.

The eagle-eyed goddess then shot four arrows all at once, one for each of Incarnam's winds.

So, did Cra win the battle? Did Iop cheat at the last moment? What became of the young soul? Relics are the only proof we have that the challenge ever took place... but everyone knows that the Great Huntress's arrows never miss their target.

279.contentId:
An old tale tells the story of three brothers who were incarnated on the sacred lands of the celestial archipelago. Their souls were as black as coal, and their intentions blacker still – more like a Bwork's underpants. They pilfered from young, innocent souls, filling their pockets with plunder and paying no heed to authority. The Kerubs tried to arrest them, but the three highwaymen were experts in dishonesty and disguise.

The brothers formed a band made up of all sorts of wild souls that had been led astray.

One day, when they were prowling around in the south of Incarnam, they spotted two easy targets: an old man who was taking a rest at the edge of the canal, and a frail being who seemed to be all skin and bones and was clothed in a dark cloak. Between the two of them there sat a chest with its lid open just enough to show that there was something golden sparkling inside.

The three brothers attacked all at once, greedy and anxious to get their hands on whatever was in the chest. Unfortunately for them, their targets were none other than Sram and Enutrof, who had stopped off in Incarnam to recruit new disciples.

Needless to say, the three ne'er-do-wells were killed almost immediately. All of their accomplices were transformed into Chafers, as a warning to other lost souls. Sram himself placed three ghoulish stones to remind passers-by of the three highwaymen's fate.

The moral of the story is that if you want to do wrong, you'd better do it right. Oh, and don't judge a book by its cover.

280.contentId:
Legend has it that one dark night, as the winds of the Krosmoz blew ferociously, a horde of demons escaped from the infernal dimension to invade the celestial archipelago of Incarnam. The god Iop, who'd never miss an occasion to smash some skulls together, left his fortress in Ingloriom to put a stop to this unacceptable intrusion.

The Lord of the Brave stood alone against the demon army. He whipped, sliced, crushed and skewered the diabolical creatures into tiny little pieces and then into pulp, all with a disconcerting ease. The battle wasn't fair at all! Wanting to smother his boredom and give his enemies at least a bit of a chance, Iop threw his sword to the ground. But this action didn't produce the desired effect: faced with such a demonstration of force, the demons fled without pausing to pick up old friends or lost arms.

Iop was disappointed. He returned to Ingloriom without even picking his sword up. The weapon remained wedged in the earth of Incarnam, and has become a symbol of courage to all the souls that pass.

281.contentId:
Chance, luck, karma or destiny: Ecaflip rules over all these mysteries.

Inside his chambers in Ingloriom, the King of Fortune spends his time playing strange games, placing completely reckless bets and challenging the other gods to tournaments with lengthy, complicated rules.

They say that one evening, when the divine nectar had been flowing freely, Ecaflip started a long game of cards with the Big Foamy Bear, the goddess Pandawa. There wasn't just any old thing at stake: the loser would have to complete a task of the winner's choosing. For beings with godly powers, a favour is an invaluable thing, worth far more than mere jewels or precious items.

The game was nearing its end and the two adversaries were neck and neck. The last round would decide everything.

Once the cards had been dealt out, Ecaflip and Pandawa examined their hands, their faces remaining expressionless. Then the goddess laid her cards out on the table, revealing three identical cards – queens. Ecaflip smoothed his whiskers, appearing to hesitate. He rolled a die, murmuring, "evens I lose, odds she wins." The die rolled off the table and disappeared in the thick curls of smoke shrouding the room. Ecaflip's face was impassive for a moment, and then he announced that he had lost. He threw his cards up in the air. A 5 of clubs and a 2 of spades landed face up on the table, but the other three vanished.

Did the Big Tease really lose the game that night? The only people who can answer that question are those who found the missing cards...

282.contentId:
Long, long ago, when Incarnam was still young, Enutrof spent his days lounging on a pile of gold at the edge of the celestial archipelago. Light from the solar star above glinted off his scales and off the precious metal all around him, filling him with lazy happiness.

One sunny day, the Miser's nap was interrupted: there was an insistent clamour sailing across the Krosmoz. These prayers were not meant for Enutrof; they were calling out fervently to Eniripsa, the Divine Practitioner. Young souls in distress were begging the goddess for help.

Flying to her disciples' aid, the Miracle Fairy appeared, all grace and light. At her side hung a flask filled with an elixir which shone like a thousand iridescent fireflies. The Miser's eyes were captivated by this glow, and an irrepressible desire was born within him: he must add this crystalline flask to his treasures!

Enutrof offered a handful of gold pieces minted with his special mark in exchange for the flask, but the goddess refused.

Enutrof offered the power to talk to stones and to understand their gravelly replies, but the goddess refused.

Enutrof offered a procession of souls which would pay homage to Eniripsa until the end of time, but the goddess refused.

Enutrof offered a river of diamonds, a mine of silver, and a mountain of rubies, but the goddess refused.

Lingering on this flask which he could not obtain, the Miser lost his appetite, stopped sleeping and couldn't think straight. He was consumed by greed. His scales grew dull and soon he was but a shadow of his former self.

Then the goddess spread her wings benevolently and placed the flask between Enutrof's clawed hands: by drinking its contents, he would be able to become what he had been once again, healing the damage he had done himself. Soothing pain was Eniripsa's gift, and you could not put a price on it.

Standing before the flask, which has remained empty, abandoned on this rock ever since that distant past when Incarnam was still young, young souls understand that no man, god or dragon can afford Eniripsa's flask.

283.contentId:
Once upon a time, there was an artist who lived in Incarnam. One day, as he was sketching the clouds around the celestial archipelago, the goddess Feca passed by. Curious, she looked over the painter's shoulder, and complimented his work.

"I really like your work. Could you draw me a Gobball, please? I'll frame it and hang it above the door at my divine sheep barn."

Painting animals wasn't really the artists speciality, he preferred still lifes and pastoral landscapes. But since he didn't want to upset Feca, he did as she asked.

The goddess studied the result carefully.

"Your Gobball looks very ill, I don't think he'll survive the winter. Draw another one."

The artist drew another one.

"That's not a Gobball, that's a Mastogob. His tusks are huge..."

Once again, the artist redid his drawing. But, just like all the others, it wasn't right:

"That one's even older than an Enutrof. I want a Gobball with a long life ahead of him."

At the end of his patience, the artist scribbled one last drawing and showed it to the goddess:

"That's the box. The Gobball you want is inside it."

The painter grinned and waited to see Feca's face light up before such a revolutionary approach to art.

Instead, the High Shepherdess frowned, put down her aegis, stuck her crook in the ground and rolled up her pure virgin wool sleeves. Then she gave the vile crook who dared to mock a goddess the beating of his life.

The story doesn't say what became of the disrespectful artist. But Feca's rage was such that she forgot to take her things with her when she left... unless she left her staff and her shield there as a warning to others.

284.contentId:
There was a time when a Iop dragon hunter travelled throughout Incarnam. Armed with a sword seven feet long and wearing a helmet that blocked both his view and his common sense, he claimed he was a descendant of the late Rykke Errel (although everyone assured him that the paladin died childless). He set upon anything scaly that happened to cross his path: even the Gudgeons weren't safe from his irrational prosecution.

They say that, one foggy night, the hunter ran into a dragon. Was it a real dragon, or some overgrown reptile? Nobody knows for sure. The Iop stumbled across the creature when it was asleep. Listening only to his relative courage, he decided to slay it. But the beast woke up and dodged the attack: the blow cut clean through its multiple forked tails.

Since bad things always come in pairs, it turned out the monster was actually a favourite of the god Osamodas. The Great Conjurer didn't waste any time showing up. He immediately punished this attack on his pet: he turned the unfortunate Iop into a trembling larva, then swallowed him whole, with just a bit of garlic to add flavour.

285.contentId:
At the Incarnam tavern, the landlord offers a drink to any passing souls. Some clients are surprised to discover he doesn't serve beer. The reason for this is simple: his barrels have been condemned to emptiness since the Bamboo Lady visited his establishment!

One hot summer's day, Pandawa herself entered the pub, much to the owner's surprise. The goddess approached the bar with an unsteady gait, and ordered "beer until my thirst is quenched", holding out an enormous tankard.

Once she'd gulped down all the beer in the barrel in just a few chugs, Pandawa ordered the landlord to serve her everything he had in his cellar. Astounded by the turn of events, the owner agreed. Once the stocks had been emptied, the goddess decided to drain the future reserves: she drank all the beer that was supposed to be served to his clients for the next thousand years.

Her thirst was temporarily quenched, so Pandawa burped loudly, thanked the dumbfounded innkeeper, then left just as she had come: zigzagging. She left her tankard behind her.

Since that day, the only drinks served in Incarnam have been lemonade and Mimilk.

286.contentId:
Long, long ago, the celestial archipelago of Incarnam was ruled by a perfect harmony. Such bliss greatly annoyed the devilish creatures that haunted the infernal Shustuft Crust. The demons prepared an invasion, hoping to create a bit of disorder.

One night, they unleashed themselves on Incarnam and started to wreak chaos. The gobbled all the Gobballs, pulled the girls' hair and the boys' nose hair. They let off a multitude of fetid gases and thought it was funny. They urinated on the tavern walls and in the customers' pints. Thousands suffered at the hands (and other body parts) of the demons.

The young souls' cries reached the ears of the goddess Sacrier. The Scarlet Lady's blood began to boil: she ran all the way to Incarnam to allow her vengeful anger to flow free.

At the goddess's will, the earth covered itself with jagged spikes and razor-sharp stones. It was as if the spine of the stone dragon who supports the archipelago was standing on end to chase off the intruders.

Soon, there was nowhere for the demons to put their feet, paws or hooves down without feeling a thousand shots of pain. Incarnam was just as inhospitable as the Shustuft Crust! They decided to head home.

Thanks to the goddess Sacrier's intervention, the archipelago was once again a calm and peaceful place... but its original harmony had been lost forever. Today, some of these rocky spikes still stick up from the ground, like pale thorns, silent witnesses to the great tumult that once shook the ground in Incarnam.

287.contentId:
The petrified brambles that grow in this area were once guilty of terrible savagery: they tore Incarnam's only living puppet to shreds.

How did such a being ever see the light of day? Most stories agree that it was the god Sadida, who had spent a particularly alcohol-fuelled evening in the company of Pandawa and Ecaflip before going to dance under the full moon with one of the training scarecrows at the Kerub tower. One dance with the Doll Master can lead to some unexpected effects: they say that after this taste of the joys of moving, the dummy left his job as a target so he could go on long, peaceful walks through Incarnam's fields. He carved a wooden mask to serve as his face and, faithful to his first role, helped young adventurers succeed in their training.

However fluid his movements were, though, the puppet lacked one thing: a soul. As the years passed by, he became dry, hard and breakable. His lovable character gave way to a sorrowful and envious bitterness. He started hitting out at anyone and everyone, seemingly taking great delight in doing to others as they had done to him.

One night, word of the creation's evil doings reached Sadida, and he decided to intervene. He interrupted one of his daily naps and surprised the puppet as he was preparing yet another misdeed. His punishment was brutal: the Leafy God summoned the brambles, which tore the scarecrow to shreds. The clumps of hay and scraps of material were scattered by the wind. As for the wooden mask, no one knows what became of it...

288.contentId:
Xelor may well be the Master of Time, but that doesn't mean he can take as much of it as he likes. That's why he hates to waste it. So, imagine his surprise when, as a mortal, he noticed that one of his precious sandglasses was missing!

One might have thought it had been borrowed, or worse, stolen, by some dishonest scamp. A passing guest, perhaps? Unless it was another dodgy trick by Sram... but the truth was something else altogether.

Xelor knew the real truth. You see, time isn't just a greedy player like Enutrof, who wins all his hands the same way Ecaflip does. No, time also has a habit of running away from you if you don't keep your eye on it.

The Great Timekeeper searched the Krosmoz far and wide. And he finally found his missing sandglass in Incarnam. He was just getting ready to go and get it when he changed his mind. He decided it might not be a bad idea to remind the young souls that time stops for no man, after all...

289.contentId:
There is a spot in Incarnam where all Enutrofs like to pray: the Rock of Fortune. It is here that the god with the golden scales is thought to have buried a small part of his fortune with his pick, as suggested by the presence of the divine tool.

Everyone knows that the great Miser had managed to accumulate limitless wealth: a small part of this would be more than enough to make any mortal rich for the rest of his days. The pilgrims and their talent with a pick are proof of these high hopes.

It is said that one particularly tenacious Enutrof dug so deep he went from one side of Incarnam to the other. Once he'd arrived at the dragon's tail, he fell through the Krosmoz and finally landed in the World of Twelve. Once down there, he shook the dust from his beard, then carried on digging.

Some miners claim that this odd character is behind all the galleries that link the mines of the world. At certain times of the year, when the ground stops cracking, you can even hear the metallic sounds of his shovel and pick rise up from the depths.

Presentation

First and foremost, to take good care of your petsmount, you must love it, otherwise your petsmount will not love you.

This book doesn't provide any tips or advice on how to love your petsmount, however, as that cannot be learned. Instead, we're going to look at the second most important condition: proper feeding.

This guide tells you how to feed Slayhounds, fearsome soul-eating critters!

Petsmounts

Slayhounds aren't pets, they're petsmounts – faithful companions that you can count on in any situation, but that you can also ride!

Seated on your Slayhound's back, your hair blowing in the wind and the reins between your teeth, you'll no longer have to cross the wide World of Twelve all alone. You'll be able to flounce around Astrub's little squares smiling haughtily amidst the envious gazes of your observers. Not everybody is talented enough to have a petsmount, y'know!

You've probably grasped by now that your petsmount is a very special creature. You'll need to feed it, cherish it and treat it properly if you want it to stay in good health.

Feeding Your Petsmount

Soul-eating petsmounts are quite unique, to say the least. They generally harbour an impressive amount of ill will for certain creatures, and they can only feed on vengeance.

And so, to gain nourishment, soul-eaters need only to accompany you when you kill these monsters, at which point they will feed on the souls you've freed.

Soul-eaters will gladly consume the souls of creatures at any time of day or night. They can fast for long periods, and are also able to devour large numbers of souls in a very short amount of time. It is impossible to make a soul-eater overweight or underweight.

After eating a certain number of souls, your Slayhound will see their characteristics increase.

Treating Injuries

When injured, your Slayhound will need to follow a special diet of Eniripsa Powder, which can be used to heal petsmounts. You can purchase this powder from the Bow Kennel.

If you haven't located Eniripsa Powder yet, you can bring your wounded petsmount to the Bow Kennel to keep its condition from worsening.

Your Slayhound's Diet

The Slayhound's diet is composed of the souls of other creatures who live on Kwismas Island.

This diet enables it to be more powerful.

Here are a few examples the creatures whose souls Slayhounds can eat:

Kwismas Whitish Fang

Prickies

Kwismas Dragoturkeys

Wintry Kanigers

Snowmen

Ice Cracklers

Nefarious Goblimps

Mini Inuits

Father Kwismas

Some souls are richer than others, allowing your Slayhound to develop more quickly.

Using Your Petsmount in Combat

Your petsmount will typically assist you in combat by defending you or helping to make your attacks more effective.

Be sure to keep a close eye on your petsmount, though, because it will be injured every time you lose a fight against a creature.

If you don't heal it after each loss, it will eventually die, and you'll have to find a way to revive your petsmount.

In general, the only way to heal a petsmount after losing a battle is to feed it Eniripsa Powder.

Customarily, when adventurers fight one another, petsmounts are never targeted. Therefore, they cannot be injured, even in the event of a defeat.

If you want to be sure your petsmount doesn't get injured, simply keep it in your inventory rather than having it by your side during combat.

Favourite Area

All petsmounts have a favourite area.

Whenever a petsmount is in its favourite area, all the benefits it gives its master receive a bonus. The bonus changes from petsmount to petsmount, but it can be very large, so don't forget to take advantage of it by fighting in the area!

The Slayhound's favourite area is Kwismas Island.

About the Bow Kennel

The Bow Kennel is a place generally reserved for raising petsmounts.

You can leave your petsmount there so it's safe and well-fed while you are away. However, your petsmount will not improve while in the Bow Kennel, as it is away from its master.

You typically have to pay a fee to drop off your petsmount, and then another fee when you pick it up later.

The amount you have to pay will depend on how long you're gone for. The longer your petsmount stays in the Bow Kennel, the steeper the fee.

The Bow Kennel is also where you can buy Eniripsa Powder to heal your petsmount.

The most well-known Bow Kennel is usually marked on adventurers' maps. It can be found next to Sufokia Gate.

In conclusion, we must point out a physical limit to your Slayhound's constitution.

Once its growth is complete, its capacities will have reached their maximum and it will be difficult to improve it further.

Good luck to you and your soul-chomping petsmount!

299.contentId: I've arrived, safe and sound. It's frightfully chilly here, not like on our little island! And all this snow is quite disorientating! The Goblimps remind me of Jykel. I do hope they're less oafish than he, or else Nicholas Kwismas and his family are sure to have a hard time.

300.contentId: Today, I succeeded in obtaining the key to the loft after paying a handsome sum to an Enutrof who I suspect was more interested in my kamas than in my quest for knowledge. 303.contentId:
A long time ago, in a hidden corner of Frigost, where the earth was frozen solid by Djaul's curse, lived the family of Nicholas Kwismas. Nicholas was an Enutrof toymaker, and without doubt the best on all Frigost. He was also very generous, and once a year, in the month of Descendre, he tried to warm the chilly hearts of good children by giving them a toy he had crafted in his workshop.

The small family business was growing by the day. To keep up with demand, Nicholas went into partnership with another Enutrof called Scooger, a fussy accountant with a strong practical side. Scooger set about dealing with the business side of things. He took on a group of Goblimps to increase production: these extremely skilled workers only wanted a few Iced Chestnuts as payment - which suited the miserly old Scooger no end - as well as the right to play a practical joke every now and again.

Nicholas Kwismas was so popular that all of the children on Frigost talked about him day and night. His fame travelled quickly across the island, reaching the ears of certain unsavoury creatures.

One such creature, a child-eating monster that rampaged around a remote, dark forest, had an unpronounceable name and an empty belly. Struggling to find anything to satisfy his raging hunger, the unspeakable fiend hatched a Machiavellian plan. Why not use the toymaker's fame to attract children with gifts?

Busy in his lair, the monster wrapped anything and everything in shiny paper, then placed gifts all over the forest. Most of the time, the colourful parcels were taken by wild creatures, but sadly, a few children fell blindly into the trap.

These few morsels served only to increase the ogre's hunger. To expand his hunting ground, he resolved to leave the forest and come out into the open - but he would never have dared to had he not had the heaven-sent help of an unscrupulous businessman.

Bound by a deep hatred of Nicholas Kwismas and of joyful sentiment in general, this terrible twosome set up a toyshop in direct competition with Nicholas Kwismas. Their gifts were labelled "from the real Father Kwismas".

In a few short years, their business prospered, thanks largely to misleading advertising, bribes and various underhand tactics. After all, when someone is threatening to eat you, you tend to do what they say.

Nicholas Kwismas and Scooger tried to react, but couldn't compete with such dishonest practices. The production of toys at the factory slowed right down, then ground to a halt.

Riddled with debt, Nicholas Kwismas had to make the Goblimps redundant. He had to sell his business and his house... which, inevitably, were bought by the twosome who brought about his downfall.

They say that it never rains, but it pours. Nicholas Kwismas had just left his home when an earthquake shook the region. The frozen tip of land on which the Kwismas house stood was torn from Frigost Island and drifted slowly out to sea. There was nothing natural about this disaster, for it was the work of the demon Djaul, who hoped to use the curse on Frigost to freeze Amakna as well, and attempt once more to defeat Jiva, his eternal rival.

And so, Nicholas Kwismas, his son Hector, his niece Carol, his associate Scooger and the Goblimp workers (who had stayed on despite being made redundant, for their stock of Iced Chestnuts had not yet run out) found themselves trapped on a tiny chunk of floating island, lost on the ocean. After a while, it became apparent that the imposter Father Kwismas was also part of this unexpected journey...

304.contentId:
The end of the year 639 was special, not just for the inhabitants of Kwismas Island, but for the people living on the continent as well.

In Descendre of that year, the keeper of the lighthouse at the edge of the world could see no sign of frozen land off the coast. The village of Amakna, however, was completely covered in snow - a sign of the island's influence on the weather.

Harry and Mary Kwismas, two Enutrofs who had recently set up camp to the west of the port of Madrestam, revealed the strange events that led to this unusual situation to an incredulous public.

The two former adventurers, distant cousins of Nicholas Kwismas, had taken up residence on the frozen island to study it at the request of the scholars Khopen and Hagen. Well, that was the explanation they gave when asked about the reason for their presence on the island. In reality, the Enutrof couple had wanted to go into business selling toys from Father Kwismas's workshop.

Mary and Harry then announced that they had noticed the climate changing over the past few months. The water temperature seemed to have risen, due largely to the growing number of adventurers, the rapid development of Dragoturkey breeding, and the large-scale, incessant deforestation. The underwater currents had been disrupted, and they had kept the island away from the continent.

As if that were not worrying enough, the two Enutrofs told the public that a disaster had occurred. Chased from the Dreggon Peninsula in Novamaire by a group of bellicose heroes, the terrible Grozilla and Grasmera had escaped by sea, taking the last living Sauroshells with them. The two dragons had swum until they reached Kwismas Island. No sooner had they set their terrible claws on their new playground than they began to wreak havoc, massacring the indigenous Itztings and Mini Inuits.

While all of the creatures on Kwismas Island were cowering in fear, something unexpected happened. The Sauroshells that Grozilla and Grasmera had stored in a cave for their protection reached maturity, and exploded all at once!

The explosion was so powerful that it propelled a chunk of Kwismas Island high into the air. This lump of snow and ice rose high into the sky, before falling and crashing straight into the village of Amakna.

It was on this piece of ice that the Kwismas couple had made their camp, where they stored the gifts taken from the island's creatures, as well as sheltering a small group of Goblimp pranksters. Everything had miraculously survived the fall! However, once they had recovered from their initial shock, the Goblimps were eager to steal the presents from the Kwismases, and they ran off with them.

And so, every year since the events of 639, Harry and Mary make an appeal to adventurers to help them to recover the gifts that the Goblimps stole. As the missing crates invariably end up in the hands of the guardians that rule the dungeons (no one ever takes them any gifts, after all, so they're forced to take them themselves without asking), they aren't easily recovered. But you'd do anything to bring joy to the good children of the World of Twelve... right?

305.contentId:
The monster mentioned in the first Kwismas Carol wasn't the only one to have caused Nicholas Kwismas such trouble. You'll have heard about the terrible Father Whupper several times already, of course.

This creature was of the same ilk as Father Kwismas, and had a huge appetite and an inversely proportional brain. He had tried several times to attack the children who regularly came to visit Nicholas's workshop. Father Whupper hid under the stairs or in the dark corners of the toy factory, or behind the gift machines. He was most often spotted by the Goblimps, who didn't like him at all, for he didn't have even the slightest hint of a sense of humour.

Nicholas tried to reason with the ogre, but it was like talking to a Iop. The treats he offered in exchange for a little restraint seemed to have no effect. Despite repeated warnings, Father Whupper always returned, drawn to the fresh meat.

A worker called Blimpanzee, who like all Goblimps was a vegetarian, had the bright idea of changing the monster's diet. He tried everything: cabbage soup, onion soup, potato soup and stone soup; beetroot salad, turnip salad, Waldorf salad and cawwot salad; mushrooms stuffed à la Lykhen, stuffed with croutons, stuffed with stuffing, and stuffed with particularly salty almonds. Nothing worked, and things turned sour for Blimpanzee when one morning he did not appear for work. Many believed he had been eaten by Father Whupper. Others were more optimistic, and claimed that as a result of spending so much time in the ogre's company, he must have taken a liking to minced meat, and so moved to the Trool Fair to spend his days guzzling down almost nutritionally balanced meals at Maxim's.

As every attempt to calm the monster failed, Nicholas resolved to use a firmer hand. With the help of a passing hunter who feared nothing but Arachnees, he prepared a trap to capture the beast. But nets alone were not enough to keep Father Whupper from escaping, and so Nicholas ended up locking the ugly beast in his cellar, where he remained for many years... until the house changed hands.

The new owner, who was none other than the sinister Father Kwismas, was shocked to find this cumbersome tenant when he moved into Nicholas's former home. It turned out that Father Whupper was the more wicked of the two monsters. He mercilessly threw his opponent out of the house, and took possession of it himself.

Beaten and humiliated, Father Kwismas took up residence in the depths of an ice cavern, plotting his revenge, and vowing to avenge the terrible affront he had suffered. But it takes energy to plot in such a fashion, and so the ogre set about filling his stomach, which isn't easy when one is exiled to an island in the middle of the ocean.

As for Father Whupper, he redecorated the house to his taste, and, for fun, started torturing the poor cuddly toys abandoned by the Goblimps.

306.contentId:
The first Kwismas Carol tells of Nicholas the toymaker, ruined by an unscrupulous businessman, whose dark dealings led to the collapse of the Goblimps' workshop and who drove Nicholas out of his own house. But who was this businessman with dark designs, and what became of him?

John Pesterton was an unbearable alchemist who had made his fortune by creating an allegedly miraculous beverage: Cocalane, "the drink that makes everything fly by." This elixir, whose qualities were as questionable as they were numerous, was regularly imbibed by many Frigostians. It was served on the rocks, which was fortunate, given the island's climate.

Always seeking to expand his vast pile of kamas, Pesterton spoke to Nicholas Kwismas, suggesting they went into partnership together. If he could get all of the children on Frigost to drink Cocalane, it would be extremely profitable!

But Nicholas already had a partner - Scooger, the taciturn accountant. He quickly recognised Pesterton as being even more miserly than Scooger and flatly refused the wealthy alchemist's offer.

Furious at having been turned down so brusquely, Pesterton decided to take revenge. Having heard several rumours that Kwismas was planning to open a subsidiary in a dark forest, he made his way into the snowy depths... and found himself face to face - or rather face to teeth - with a horrible creature.

After what must have been a rather tense discussion, the child-eating monster and Pesterton discovered they had something in common: a profound disdain for Nicholas Kwismas and joyful sentiment. That was all that was needed for an agreement to be reached between the two dreadful characters.

Pesterton decided to invest part of his fortune in starting an anonymous enterprise to compete with Kwismas. Emphasising quantity over quality, he distributed gifts to everyone, including ne'er-do-wells, wandering monsters and crooks of the worst kind. Even the brainless bots would have received something had they been on Frigost. The presents were labelled "from the real Father Kwismas".

The role of Father Kwismas was given to the monster, who was delighted with the scheme: with such a clever disguise, he could assume the false identity and finally leave the forest.

The evil plan worked. Nicholas Kwismas's tiny business could not compete with Pesterton's underhand methods. The old craftsman had to put his keys under the door and sell his house. To top it all, Djaul's evil intervention tore him from his homeland, sending him wandering on an icy sea, far from the children of Frigost who gradually forgot about him...

With Nicholas off on a very long cruise, Pesterton's vengeance was assuaged. There was no point carrying on distributing gifts, and besides, it was no longer profitable. So Pesterton put an end to his activity as a manufacturer of low-end toys. With Father Kwismas no longer there to terrorise reluctant clients, Pesterton's business failed. Cocalane sales stagnated and then collapsed. Pesterton decided to sneak away into the night, leaving with a bag full of kamas, and nothing more was heard of him. Some say he tried to contact Count Harebourg and offer him a fantastic deal...

About the Bow Kennel: p. 11

Preface

Unfortunately, as happens every year, a new type of Black Plague ravaged Amakna. But the one that struck in Aperirel of 463 was quite surprising: the plague did not affect people but rather their pets.

The symptoms were terrible. It would first manifest as a bodily imbalance. Some pets would grow huge but their skin would burn. Others became quick as the wind yet extremely sensitive to cold... But they all inevitably died.

Silouate, the guardian of Aperirel, attempted to cast a spell to save the poor beasts. Any pet stricken with the disease, no matter the severity, experienced a sort of rebirth. It was the only way to stop the plague, which had been killing them off one by one.

But Silouate didn't stop there. To prevent a similar catastrophe from happening in the future, he decided to partially link these small creatures' disease resistance to that of the people of Amakna, which was much higher and more resilient.

What Silouate didn't foresee was that his spell would strengthen the bonds between pets and people. Within two weeks, pets had become completely dependent on their owners...

That is why, to this day, pets have little chance of surviving if they don't receive the special care described in this book.

Introduction

First and foremost, to take good care of your pet, you must love it, otherwise your pet will not love you.

This book doesn't provide any tips or advice on how to love your pet, however, as that cannot be learned. Instead, we're going to look at the second most important condition: proper feeding.

This guide tells you how to feed Krolimeas, fearsome soul-eating critters!

Feeding Your Pet

Soul-eating pets are quite unique, to say the least. They generally harbour an impressive amount of ill will for their own, and they can only feed on vengeance.

And so, to gain nourishment, soul-eaters need only to accompany you when you kill monsters of their ilk, at which point they will feed on the souls you've freed.

Soul-eaters will gladly consume the souls of their own species at any time of day or night. They can fast for long periods, and are also able to devour large numbers of souls in a very short amount of time. It is impossible to make a soul-eater overweight or underweight.

After eating a certain number of souls, your Krolimea will see their characteristics increase.

Treating Injuries

When injured, your Krolimea will need to follow a special diet of Eniripsa Powder, which can be used to heal pets. You can purchase this powder from the Bow Kennel.

If your pet is injured, you can also bring it to the Bow Kennel to keep its condition from worsening until you can get Eniripsa Powder for it.

Your Krolimea's Diet

The Krolimea's diet consists of the souls of creatures of its kind.

This diet enables it to become more powerful.

Here is a list of the creatures whose souls Krolimeas can eat:

Any kind of Sauroshell

Grozilla, in any state

Grasmera, in any state

Some souls are richer than others, allowing your Krolimea to develop more quickly.

Using Your Pet in Combat

Your pet will typically help you in combat by defending you or helping to make your attacks more effective.

Be sure to keep a close eye on your pet, though, because it will be injured every time you lose a fight against a creature.

If you don't heal it after each loss, it will eventually die, and you'll have to find a way to revive your pet.

In general, the only way to heal a pet after losing a battle is to feed it Eniripsa Powder.

Customarily, when adventurers fight one another, pets are never targeted and therefore cannot be injured, even in the event of defeat.

If you want to be sure your pet doesn't get injured, simply keep it in your inventory rather than having it by your side during combat.

About the Bow Kennel

The Bow Kennel is a place generally reserved for raising pets.

You can leave your pet there so it's safe and well-fed while you are away. However, your pet will not improve while in the Bow Kennel, as it is away from its master.

You typically have to pay a fee to drop off your pet, and then another fee when you pick it up later.

The amount you have to pay will depend on how long you're gone for. The longer your pet stays in the Bow Kennel, the steeper the fee.

The Bow Kennel is also where you can buy Eniripsa Powder to heal your pet.

The most well-known Bow Kennel is usually marked on adventurers' maps. It can be found next to Sufokia Gate.

In conclusion, we must point out a physical limit to your Krolimea's constitution.

Once its growth is complete, its capacities will have reached their maximum and it will be difficult to improve it further.

But be advised: if you stop caring for your Krolimea properly once it has reached this state, its health will suffer greatly. You therefore need to continue to feed it the souls of its own kind regularly so it doesn't wither away.

Good luck to you and your soul-chomping pet!

317.contentId:
Information Sheet: p. 3

Introduction: p. 4

The Worship of Oktapodas: p. 6

Typical Expressions: p. 8

The Foggernaut's Profile

Specialty: tactician and technomage

Strong points: healing, positioning, hitting hard

Key characteristics: Strength, Intelligence, Chance

First spells: Harpooner, Pilfer, Anchor

Favourite tactics:

  1. placing turrets to control the battlefield

  2. using technology to alter the way battles play out

  3. moving fighters around with the Tacturret

  4. healing with the Lifesaver

  5. wearing enemies down with the Harpooner

Introduction

Ridin' the waves; rollin' out the machines

The Foggernauts' two great loves are technomagic and the sea! In fact, they use the first to become more at one with the second, which is why so many Foggers are known as marine inventors. The ingenious systems that they rustle up use steam as their main power source - after all, there's plenty of water where they're from!

Get a Foggernaut started on the ocean, and he'll never stop. A lot of his stories might appear to be based on sea monsters dreamt up to scare the living daylights out of you, but he also knows tons of mysterious legends passed down by his ancestors. You'll often find a Fogger surrounded by a wide-eyed crowd in the tavern, talking of extraordinary machines, expeditions through the murky depths, sunken treasure and long-lost underwater civilisations... If it's all just made up, nobody can blame you for falling for them hook, line and sinker, but who knows? Some of their stories might just hold water!

Technomagic tricks

The Foggernauts aren't the type to rush headlong into battle. They prefer to study the field, pick out strategic positions and then summon their machines of war to the battlefield. They have two main objectives: to wear enemies down with consistent damage, and to offer effective support to their allies. If the lines get a little tangled, then it's not their fault - only a Iop would stumble into an attack turret's line of fire!

Capable of thinking clearly even when things aren't quite shipshape, Foggernauts are not easy to sink. Even when everything seems to be going wrong, their quick reactions and fortifications are often enough to save the day.

The Worship of Oktapodas

The Great Oktapodas, or the god Osamodas

Known across the World of Twelve as the Krosmoz's greatest breeder and trainer, it should be no surprise that the god Osamodas is known under all sorts of guises. For some, he'll always be a ferocious conqueror who takes pride in his trophy collection. For others, he's a reassuring, generous and benevolent force.

Osamodas can disguise himself as he wishes. One moment he might be a Dragon; the next, a Mufafah or a Giant Kralove. This last form is the one that the sea people took as their own in ancient times. His worshippers started to call him the Great Oktapodas, protector of the oceans and of the sea's creatures.

When the temple dedicated to Oktapodas was discovered, his name bubbled up from the past once again. The Celestial Tamer is only too happy to have a few more disciples to his name!

The Temple of Oktapodas

The Sacred Kralove's sanctuary lay forgotten by all for centuries. Then, one stormy night, some fishermen found their way to a rocky shore not far from the Bay of Sufokia. Desperately seeking shelter, they stumbled into a stony crevice. Just imagine their surprise when they discovered that they had chanced upon a room dominated by a huge stone statue! And that wasn't the half of it... as they made their way from room to room, they discovered the sea people's relics, each one more marvellous than the last.

The new converts decorated the sacred rock as it was supposed to be - covered in seaweed and shells. Now, it stands proud for all to sea, like an ancient obelisk floating on the ocean's surface.

The temple's most precious relic is the Vessel of the Ancients, a submarine that seems to be based on technomagic hitherto unknown. So far, nobody has managed to pilot it, but it has been used as a model for the submarines used in Sufokia.

Typical expressions - How to speak Foggernaut

Fogg!: a general exclamation used alone or in combination with other words to express a wide range of emotions. "Fogg yes!"

To tighten up the screws: to roll up one's sleeves and get to work.

To have misty portholes: to become emotional.

Better to float without a lifesaver than to sink without a scuba suit: a proverb encouraging little Foggers to learn to swim.

Do the crab: making all sorts of crazy manoeuvres to avoid problems.

Diving straight in: taking risks and acting recklessly.

Full steam ahead!: the Foggernauts' battle-cry.

Having a Fogg in your throat refers to the scurvy sea dog that sleeps in all Foggernauts, ready to tell a (very) tall tale at the first sign of interest.

If someone has eaten a Kloon Snapper, it means they tell the same jokes again and again.

Tidal wave: a joke or event which triggers such hilarity that numerous people end up crying with laughter.
