367.contentId:
Despair has been with me for the past several nights... and now, several drinks later, this empty bottle is my last hope.

May it find a soul that values altruism more than drink, a soul willing to find my secret place...

My camp is located on the edge of the island on an isolated beach – one that cannot be reached by swimming. There is a cove in a cave-filled area of the island. From there, if you like, you can reach the sea to join me.

And if this bottle gets lost among the waves, I beg my faithful jailer, the sea, to never obliterate these words, and pray that the ink that flowed to write these lines never fades.

368.subTitleId: Excerpt from the "Book of Ghouls" by Count d'Ourlette
368.contentId: Contrary to what those old wives' tales claim, Ghouls are just as capable of feeling sympathy and affection for species other than their own, as mortal beings are. They generally do not have the capacity to express this other than with their intelligent babbling, signs of their undeniable genius, but one must sometimes dare hold out a hand to one of them and bite back the desire to yell.

369.subTitleId: Excerpt from the "Book of Ghouls" by Count d'Ourlette
369.contentId:
The old legends are full of alternative beliefs and information that has little to do with reality. Ghouls are depicted as cold-blooded, abject beings devoid of humanity (that said, the first bit is probably true, but not the rest). However, you must detach yourself from the myths and fallacious accounts that tarnish our beautiful beliefs and force your mind...


(A sizeable slobber stain has made a large portion of the text illegible.)


...without having a natural predisposition for it. In that, I invite you to open your minds to the natural perfection that has made Ghouls into beings superior to our simple fleeting flesh.

370.contentId:
Today, we have decided to inspect the area around the Ghoulden Palace on the island's high ground. A silent, monastic, almost soothing atmosphere reigns over this island. The sound of the waves crashing against the cliff almost makes me forget that a group of Ghouls has been following us for several hours. In addition to their babbling and deconstructed sentences, they have an almost endearing side, like faithful travelling companions. But of course, we've refrained from telling them that.


Early this afternoon, we were spending some time by the lake, when a somewhat clumsy Ghoul got stuck in the mud while threatening us with a cruel fate. We returned the courtesy and, bored, headed for the other part of the island.


Back at camp this evening, we feasted on tinned soup found on the island – a meal fit for a king! We sang and played guitar long into the night to make ourselves forget that the ruckus must be annoying the Ghouls and Skeletons nearby.

371.contentId:
I seem to have had a long conversation with a Ghoul trapped in the ruins. And even though I think I'd started to forge the bonds of friendship with her, I was forced to flee as fast as my legs could carry me when she decided to remove her own legs to come after me, growling and crawling.


I've decided to head out on an expedition alone tomorrow. While I greatly appreciate Nuck's presence, I am starting to enjoy the Ghouls' company. The sound of their gurgling has become agreeable, as has the abundant slobber that they can spill on the ground.

372.contentId:
A driving rain fell throughout the night. In the morning, we ate breakfast shivering in the most macabre of silence. Only the prospect of returning to the island filled me joy, making me forget our miserable condition.

The day passed without a hitch, until it was time to return to camp. The high tide had carried off my boat, and I was forced to wait for it to return in this cove, made cold and damp by the rain.

I heard the thud well before I understood what caused it. A Ghoul that initially seemed to have a lucid mind had fallen from the heights of the island following a rockslide on the cliffs brought about by the rain. Delighted to finally find myself face to face with one of these creatures, I attempted to strike up an acquaintance. Rapidly, I sensed that the meeting was bothersome when the Ghoul and its peers sliding in turn down the cliff turned and growled in my direction.


I am now in a quite unfortunate position. Fleeing by sea would be suicide. Trying to strike up a friendship with this new group seems to be the best solution. But if I do not succeed... I prefer not to think about that...

I was Will, I am Will, and I shall remain Will.

375.titleId: The Marquis of Lhambadda: A Curious Fellow
375.contentId:
For such a long time, I've sworn to keep the Marquis's existence secret - even though he's pretty good at making himself conspicuous, with or without my help - but it looks like his utter incompetence and his tendency to cause problems wherever he goes have taken things one step too far: he won't buy my silence this time! Besides, the fellow is so unbelievably outrageous that he'd make an excellent subject for a book. On that note, and without further delay, I shall do my best to describe him in full.

Banished from Pandala after being caught, twice in the same day, putting plants with laxative effects in the Drunken Pandawa Inn's casks of sacred brew; hated by Amayiro for having substituted all the Bontarian Militia's weapon stocks with foam shields the night before an important territory conquest; and hunted by Magus Ax ever since the day he punched holes in all the flasks used at a Young Alchemists' contest organised and overseen by the magus, the Marquis of Lhambadda is best known for his inimitable ability to make countless enemies in relatively short periods of time.

The Marquis happens to be rich. Disgustingly rich. He told me one day that he had inherited it all from a woman he had judged fit to become his wife at the ripe old age of fifty, and whom he had promptly bundled off for a honeymoon cruise to Moon Island. Alas, neither the boat nor the lovely bride ever reached their destination, as the Marquis thought it was a good idea to smash a hole in the ship's hull at first light and row away in a lifeboat. Why would he do that?! That's just what I asked him. "I thought it would be a good story to tell in the pub later," he replied. "And I wanted an inheritance worthy of a lady-killer as charismatic as I am." I'll never forget the way he grinned throughout the light-hearted confession, and how his eyes twinkled at the word 'lady-killer'. I may never know whether the whole story was a joke in bad taste or a fleeting window into the thoughts and doings of a callous breaker of perfectly good hearts and boats.

The Marquis has never shied away from dubious practices, and has never seen Good and Evil as guidelines on how to behave. He regards all emotions as equal in worth - happiness, sadness, scorn... They don't really matter, as long as the actions that caused them were worth it. He's a staunch fan of chaos; in fact, I'd be prepared to go as far as to say that our friend the Marquis has, his whole life long, suffered from an intense phobia of all that is dull. Terrified by the prospect of spending a single second of his life without something new and interesting to do, he'll tell anyone who'll listen all about his stance on 'leading a full and eventful life'. I firmly believe that he'd give Death himself a wedgie given the chance: for him, the opposite of life is boredom.

I know nothing of his childhood, although sometimes I wonder if he's ever grown up at all. His temperament is certainly that of a middle-aged man, characterised by a deep-rooted self-possession and a faultless nobility, and yet his mind is like a child's, jittering to and fro in perpetual motion. Nobody has ever channeled his energy, and nobody will ever force him to settle into a life of monotony; of that much I am sure. Should you ever meet this individual, hope and pray that you do not become the centre of his (malevolent) attention. This is a man who infiltrated a pirate bastion and set fire to all the gunpowder reserves before he was out of his pyjamas one morning. Just imagine what such a man could do to you! I learnt this the hard way, the day he decided to prove that a disciple of Sadida would have more fun capering around than taking naps. The singed hairs on my rump still haven't grown back! Curse you, Marquis of Lhambadda!

376.titleId: How the Marquis and Shariva Became Acquainted
376.contentId:
The Rogues left early on, taking with them their part of the spoils.

The heist at Astrub bank went without a hitch. Of course, the Marquis insisted on sharing the stolen money between two passers-by, not keeping a single kama for himself - but such is his way.

The Marquis had never sought to live luxuriously, never been drawn into the tireless quest for gold, never been known to go a little gaga for jewels or stately homes, and never been motivated in any way by material possessions. In fact, whenever he found himself with a cargo of illegitimately obtained kamas, he was quite unable to imagine spending them on anything at all. His sole pleasure and aim in life was to turn the humdrum of daily life on its head. So you can be sure that, when his cheeks flushed and his eyes twinkled as he looked back on the robbery, it was not the glint of coins that set his heart racing, but the memory of throwing the town into disorder, the adrenaline rush, the thrill of the unexpected, and the hilarious image of the bankers' tail-feathers dropping in fright from under their tousled uniforms. He had scooped up these same feathers as a souvenir, by the by, and has since stuffed them into his sofa to give it extra bounce.

Once the euphoria had subsided, it didn't take long for our little rabble-rouser to kick himself as he thought back on the swag he had so gaily distributed, and this led him to an interesting realisation. "Am I in my right mind, sharing my loot between two strangers? Surely I would have been better off throwing it on the ground between the two, so I could sit scoffing cashews and enjoying the show as they ripped one another to shreds for the prize!"

The Marquis swore there and then never to let such a chance slip away again. Rather than playing the diamond in the rough, he would always opt for the path of maximum destruction.

One evening, he was relaxing in the cool waters of Astrub Lake, feeling debonair and running over the events of the day in his mind, just as he did every evening. This was the paradox of his life: in constantly seeking new ways to beat boredom, he was settling into a new kind of monotony! However, this was not the thought on the good Marquis's mind that night. No, all he could think about as he gazed up at the starry vault was a question he had thus far never voiced out loud:

"For ten long years now, every day,

In all I do and all I say,

Where'er I go, whome'er I see,

I've pledged myself to novelty.

Far beyond the city's walls,

I've erred to answer nature's calls;

I've started fires, and scenes, and fights,

Brought danger to my days and nights...

From every ruse, I walk scot-free,

So now I ask: How can that be?

The gods above can see my crimes,

I must have sinned a thousand times,

Am I exempt from accusation...?

This can't be my imagination.

Gods, though this may sound conceited,

Why is it that I'm undefeated?"

This monologue, and the heavy silence which followed, had an unprecedented effect on the Marquis in that he suddenly felt uncharacteristically humble and contrite. Undefeated... Chosen by the gods, indeed! What a thought! Next I shall announce that I am immortal... And what if someone was to overhear? He was known far and wide for his devil-may-care attitude... What would an eavesdropper think of this helpless plea to the gods above?

To this day, nobody knows whether there was anyone crouching in the undergrowth to hear this speech and to witness the fateful encounter that ensued. The Marquis had just let out a long sigh, rolled up his scroll and decided to go home, when a tiny bubble rushed to the surface of the lake... followed by another, then another. Seeing this, the Marquis burst into an incomprehensible babble of prayers; the following instant, the sky over Astrub turned to black in a flash. The lake, usually troubled by no more than the comings and goings of curious fish, was whipped into a violent typhoon. In a matter of seconds, the quiet scene had become a whirlwind of agitation, from the depths of which there rose what was, unmistakably, a goddess of bad intent. Shariva!

"Your earnestness has touched my heart,

So in return, let me impart

The truth; for, O, my dear Marquis,

I've watched your pranks with mounting glee!

Oh, how I've laughed, bent over double...

'Tis I that kept you safe from trouble.

Today I pledge myself to you,

In all you say and all you do,

We dream the same dreams, through and through,

So let us remain forever true,

And raise mischief to the power of two!"

377.titleId: The Formation of the Council of Finkertons
377.contentId:
This first meeting of the Marquis and Shariva didn't give rise to anything in particular. It was not until later, when Shariva, who had started calling herself the goddess of Tumult, appeared again that the two decided to work together. Now, the mischievous pair certainly cut a fine figure, and the Marquis was over the moon to have acquired Shariva's divine protection as he carried out all his devilish pranks to ward off the heavy fog of boredom. The goddess, however, soon became restless. Granted, her first disciple was a relentless propagandist who won her many allies, but "Tumultu-Us", as the partisans of the cause liked to call themselves, remained a sparse and hopelessly disorganised collective. Each faction held its own events in its own region, robbing, killing, hunting, wreaking havoc, running amok, playing, writing and generally contributing to the spirit of raucous misbehaviour... but only for a certain time, before the members one by one thought better of their ways and turned back to their gods, praying for long hours and asking forgiveness.

Shariva's cult seemed to have reached the point of no return. The goddess of Perpetual Change's disciples were spending more and more time currying favour with people in high places in the hope of succeeding in their personal endeavours. Fewer and fewer people were devoted to the New World Disorder - the name given to the manifesto and philosophy by which the cult had hoped to turn Terra Amakna into a place of constant activity and excitement. With great sadness, Lady Shambles realised that she was going to have to take her retirement - for a time, at least. She was not, however, about to abandon her followers. Far from it. She was just changing her game plan. One night, she appeared to the Marquis to share her theory: although the members of Tumultu-Us were exceptionally useful in their own way, and although their nightly prayers provided enough mischievous energy to keep the goddess's schemes ticking over, wouldn't involving outside groups, whose members would not answer to her beck and call, enable them to start making a real impact?

The Marquis, lapping up the goddess's words as usual, agreed with enthusiasm and promptly tasked himself with finding all the individuals who, despite worshipping other gods, had proven themselves worthy by their acts. Without even knowing about Shariva, they had, in some way or another, contributed to the New World Disorder. The Marquis was to be in charge of this league of "trouble-makers"; Shariva would observe from the sidelines, only intervening for special occasions. And thus, the Council of Finkertons was born.

378.contentId:
The legend goes that Shariva arrived in the World of Twelve when a single drop of rain fell from the only cloud in the sky into a vast lake in the middle of the night, causing a terrible tempest, followed by an even more terrible earthquake.

Within a matter of seconds, the surface of the water, hitherto calm, was swelling and crashing with such turbulence that, when the waves reached the edges of the lake, they were propelled back towards their source at great speed. The impact of the resulting clash made an amazing thing happen: above the waves and the foam, there appeared a dazzling ball of pure energy.

And from deep within it, there came a voice...

If you're imagining a soft, breathy, ethereal voice, you've been reading too many children's stories. No, this was a whiny, nasal voice.

"Feel the chaos... Feel the crime... Watch your backs... It's Shariva time!"

And so it was.

Shariva had come, and the World of Twelve was about to learn the meaning of tumult.

The unearthly glow rose up towards the sky to put its plans into action, pulsing with energy and ideas for a world full of motion and emotion - a world of adventure...

There was only one thing left for Shariva to do. She had to find a disciple who would spread her teaching far and wide; beyond the frozen mountaintops of Frigost and beyond the stumbling idiocy of the average Astrubian citizen.

The light rose further and disappeared into the clouds. And the earth trembled.

381.contentId:
Martalo 13



Memories of palm trees, sun, and the sweet smell of kokokos were floating through my mind as the road to work stretched out in front of me again. All good things come to an end, it's true. But just a few more days away from the city and its gloomy weather would have been nice!


Events rarely stir up the ambient calm in the Milicluster. So, I felt real apprehension early this morning when, shortly before my shift was scheduled to start, I saw a procession (more like a herd) of guards and soldiers bustling about on the edge of the city. It was cool out and the morning dew was still clinging weakly to the high grass – yet another reason to miss the comforting heat of the seaside.


Yet, the temperature didn't seem to bother the curious crowd around what seemed at first to be a strange flat, dry patch. Some of the inhabitants, still in their nightclothes or wrapped in thick shawls, were leaning toward whatever everyone was staring at, asking those nearest them questions.


Curious and troubled, I too moved closer to the crowd, and that's when I discovered to my stupefaction what seemed to be a bottomless pit.


A large crack, big enough to contain a small home entirely in its embrace, was spread across a patch of hot, rocky ground. The fresh grass and white flowers that are so common in the region were gone, replaced by dry, brown dirt.


Thick reddish vapors giving off an indescribable odor were pouring steadily out of the steaming crevasse. The cold, the cool air, and the morning dew stopped there, at the doors of this strange gash.


Above the murmuring, a louder rumor was soon spreading rapidly among the crowd of villagers. They were milling around, agitated, asking and answering questions. Just as it reached its peak, the agitation suddenly stopped like a candle being blown out. A dull sound, a rough cry, like a heavy wail, echoed from the bottom of the rift, demanding silence. My entire body tightened, and a glacial shiver ran up my spine. A long, weighty silence followed by a relentless wait forced itself on us. Had that really been a cry?


The tension was palpable and I could feel it spread through the crowd as people exchanged glances. Terrified, worried or excited looks were exchanged in silence, as if to make sure that everyone had indeed heard, imagined or guessed the source of the cry. And just then, slithering and whimpering, a worm or huge larva was climbing, nearly rippling, to the surface of the rift. Its smooth and shiny skin was a shocking contrast with the dark edges of the earthen rift. I saw a giant insect, whose carapace seemed to have cracked loudly and painfully under the assault of some giant's boot.


A second cry sounded out and a second worm appeared in the reddish mist. Panic set in, and I tried in vain to push back the thick crowd around the dreadful beast climbing ever higher, accompanied in the distance by an entire host of its peers.


It wasn't long before the entire Amakna militia was called in to help and secure the edges of the rift.


Me, I spent the rest of the afternoon watching an adventurer escort a certain Sedierta Otel through the arid zone infested by the beasts. A renowned scientist, the tall brunette spent most of her time studying particles of sand left behind by the worms in their clumsy movements and the steaming worm carcasses left behind by the soldiers.


The most intriguing part of the story for me (other than the clearly impossible task of counting the teeth on some of the worms' jaws!) is the unbelievable source of these beasts. They apparently come from the deserts and most arid areas of this world, but how did these strange creatures find a way to dig through the ground all the way to Amakna's doors and cause such an uproar in our humble land?


Junssidor 26



A loud noise (commotion, more like!) stirred me from my dreams this morning. The gentle wind this fine morning was an early sign of the warm season, fast approaching. I took advantage of the breeze to go for a stroll. Truth be told, the last few weeks haven't been a picnic for this soldier!


First it was that strange chasm and the filthy, grotesque worms that spilled out, terrifying the entire Milicluster and then several nations on the continent. Even today, members of my own garrison are tasked with securing the area and (ceaselessly) repelling the foul creatures from the depths.


Then there was the curious round house that had seemingly tumbled down from the highlands of Cania. That mysterious cabin made of grass, wood and stone actually became everyone's main source of concern. The house, sure... but also the unfortunate little character, no doubt taken aback by his home suddenly plummeting, found buried and crushed beneath the debris.


This gave rise to a flood of questions and theories, some less credible than others, and interest in the uncharted hills of Cania has only grown. Some adventurers tried finding a way up to the higher plateaus, but the only path they could uncover was blocked by a massive stone, and I don't think it's liable to budge.


My walk this morning brought me to the ruins of that small structure, across from the stretch of liquid that appeared when the rubble did. A small waterfall has since flowed from the heights of Cania into the thick puddle. I wondered to myself if this strange new brook might be what produced the fallen rock. Suddenly, a loud noise rang out across the valley.


Briefly stunned, I looked around in every direction possible to find out where this racket came from. I spotted smoke in the distance and bolted toward it. Having reached the source of the smoke, I realized it was in fact a dense cloud of dust. All around me, what had happened with the Milicluster was repeating itself. Much of the Cania mountain had caved in, leaving an impressive rift in the ground. I could already imagine creepy things skittering up its walls. That's where my leisurely stroll ended.


Jullier 18



A Stubbyob once told me: "Living on Mount Neselite is nice, once we stop thinking about all the bad things that happen out of the blue!" Honestly, I'm starting to believe him. Yes, yes... Wait for me to recap the latest happenings for you. I seem to have lost a few pages. If you're a Twelvian (or any similar race), you've probably heard of the Stubbyobs and their village built up on the heights of Cania, known as Mount Neselite.


As it happens, the collapse that occurred a few weeks ago indeed created a fresh rift in the ground. The militia rushed over just as the first worms started to rear their... very, very ugly heads.


Although we were initially overwhelmed with fear, our terror was soon replaced by a strong sense of curiosity. Beneath the strange crack (now splitting the rocks of Cania in two, like a box of snappers ripped open), we discovered a whole little world completely hidden away.


Perched atop the highest point of Cania, the Stubbyobs of the Hard-Head clan live (mostly) in peace in their funny rounded homes. These diminutive humanoids love beer, crafting, and waging war; they hate salad, thieves, and the opposing tribe of Stubbyobs: the Freezammer clan. Stubbyobs wield magic just as well as their hammers, axes, and anvils.


Given the Stubbyobs' fiery temperament, we quickly realized it was best not to cause them any trouble. They've got enough trouble as it is. First they were exiled, decades past, from their precious Undersmithy constructed deep in the mountain, forcing them to settle on the hills of Cania instead of inside them; many Stubbyobs are nostalgic for that time. What's more, it's because of a complex mechanism located in the heart of the mountain that their dam, built above the village, is threatening the clan's safety.


Then there was the recent cave-in, which resulted in the theft of their "very precious ore". Don't ask... It's apparently "very, very precious". Since the avalanche revealed their existence to the world, the Stubbyobs have been quite wary of Twelvians. They accuse us, by turns, of stealing their ore, enlarging their doors when we enter their homes, and finally, not respecting the local customs for how to properly drink a beer.


Thankfully, a few of the Stubbyobs are prepared to negotiate with us, happy to secure some aid from the Twelvians. I'll let the adventurers deal with all that. As for me, I'm taking advantage of the Stubbyobs' mastery of beer. Doubledry Ale, made by the Zeesmithy house, is delightful, though some will call you a heretic and go on about how Grinness, from the Grodunk family, is the only beer worth drinking! I don't agree, but I think I'll go try another one anyway, just to be on the safe side...

383.contentId: If the emerald sea is calling to you, it's probably because the muddy, yellowish soil doesn't give you much reason to stay. You're likely to hear all kinds of incessant grunting from here.

384.contentId:
Flo Inghair was a student at the prestigious Worldbeard hairdressers' academy. Her extremely volatile temperament inspired her to all kinds of cleverly coiffed creations. Her wild sense of style earned her the respect of her peers many times over, but also gave rise to a growing sense of distrust.

One dark Descendre night, Flo Inghair fled from the academy after wreaking havoc on the beards and hairstyles of her professors and fellow students.

Now widely known for the many misdeeds she committed during her time on Mount Neselite, Flo Inghair has had the dubious honour of seeing her face plastered on every wall in the village after attacking King Hard-Head's beard.

Any dwarves out there with big bushy beards had better watch out!

In Summary

Several witnesses claim to have seen her lurking around the Hard-Head village.

Wanted for unauthorised beard chopping and first-degree bowl cuts.

Sentenced to imprisonment on Mount Neselite.

Can be captured by fairly experienced adventurers.

385.contentId:
Blacksmith Durandial,
Hard-Head Clan,
Southern Plateau, Mount Neselite

388.contentId:
A grey mist rose and enshrouded the City of Mercenaries. As dry as sand, it left the taste of metal and ash in the mouths of the soldiers crowding the ramparts. Coughing and spitting, Astrubians tried to catch their breath. Ratathrosk and the Autumn Knight were down, surrounded by assailing troops. Was the battle lost?

Queen Tressa rode forward on her ram with its impressive horns. The fog didn't seem to bother her: like the Crocodyls, she was used to breathing the noxious swamp vapours. She raised her rune-engraved hammer and loudly addressed her troops.

"The Seven are watching us, sons and daughters of the mountains! It is time for us to show them that the blood that runs in our veins is not made of mud, but of red copper as fiery as the coals of a blast furnace! We are the children of the Smith. Nothing can break us. Today, I will overthrow an empire. Are you with me?"

The Stubbyobs roared and pounded the ground with their lead soles. It didn't matter that the Crocodyls were greater in number: the ginger-bearded warriors were determined to send them back to the mire from whence they came, the mire they never should have left.

The artillery lit the wicks on their cast-iron cannons. Iron and fire rained down on the scaly ones, mowing them down like stalks of wheat at harvest time. The acrid odour of burnt flesh mingled with the smell of gunpowder; the smoke thickened the veil that covered the battlefield like a shroud over the bodies of the dying.

The Crocodyls fell back, throwing javelins with barbed spikes. Despite their armour no arrow could pierce, the Stubbyobs fell, victims of the acid able to eat through the thickest breastplates.

Trusting the protection his grithril hauberk provided him, General Flaxen-Mane charged without the slightest hint of hesitation; in his wake, the knights spurred their armoured Gobballs and bore down on the enemy. The lizards tried to withstand the Stubbyobs' attack, but they were stomped on, chopped to smithereens, sliced thin and reduced to mush under the weight of the studded maces. Panic filled their reptilian brains. Were they all going to die in the shadow of Astrub's walls?

On top of the ramparts, the mercenaries felt hope return. Determined to fight for their city, they headed down to the gates to attempt a sally. The city might not fall after all... Their long-bearded allies wouldn't let it!

On the top of a hill, the Jade Bloodlord watched the battle from his carriage mounted on the back of a mastodon with oversized tusks. Noting that his subjects were losing the advantage, he brandished the sword that had made him the uncontested master of the Crocodyls. The green blade shone with lightning. Its flashing bolts struck the Stubbyobs, blackening their breastplates in bursts of evil-coloured sparks.

General Flaxen-Mane screamed with rage and frustration when the evil fire hit him straight on. The old soldier fell to the ground, a grimace distorting his scarred face. His heart beat one last time then stopped. It was as good a day to die as any other... His eyes turned to his queen before closing forever.

Tressa fought against the wave of sadness that threatened to drown her. Her most loyal supporter had just left her. She prayed that his soul would join his ancestors in the eternal forges. The words of an ancient war song running through her mind, she raised her shield bearing the emblems of the Yerg clan. It was time for her adversaries to feel the full weight of her wrath... the wrath of a queen.

Tressa spun her hammer. The weapon crushed the skulls of the Crocodyls too stupid or too foolhardy to move out of the way. The royal ram rushed towards the hill. However could it hope to rival the imperial mastodon that towered above it? It looked like a Moumouse charging a Mufafah... but nothing seemed capable of stopping it.

The scaly ones who attempted to stand in the way were scattered like tufts of straw. The queen shouted the names of the gods protecting her people. Benjak, Tasmalin, Icleen! Pasqueoz, Ediva, Eruvel! Pierrock! They were all with her, of that Tressa had no doubt.

The emperor growled and snapped his long jaws. He pointed his sword at the queen of the Stubbyobs.

Two lightning bolts ripped through the fog. The first caused sparks to fly from the surface of the shield in the clan's colours. The second set the Gobball's thick fleece on fire. The animal didn't slow: it didn't feel the pain. It was one with its mistress, and would take her to the end of her road, no matter what it cost.

The Jade Bloodlord invoked the power of lightning again. And again. And again. And yet again.

The ram eventually fell before the mastodon. Its body was no more than smoking ash.

The queen rose. Coals crackled in her ruby hair. She screamed in rage, then struck the ground with her hammer, ignoring the massive feet of the monster threatening to crush her. A crack appeared. With a deafening crack, the crevasse widened. The mastodon lost its balance; its giant body tipped over, swallowed up by the earth opening at its feet like the jaws of a starving Boowolf.

The emperor jumped off to avoid being swallowed by the crevasse. He landed heavily in front of Tressa, who lifted her hammer again.

The Bloodlord avoided a blow strong enough to break an anvil.

Tressa pressed her opponent with attack after attack. The emperor stayed on the defensive, watching carefully for the opportunity to strike back, like a snake staring at its prey with cold eyes. Unlike the queen of the Stubbyobs, he wasn't consumed by anger. His actions were driven solely by his thirst for power; emotions had no sway over him.

The Crocodyls and Stubbyobs were holding their breath all around the two monarchs fighting to the death, as if transfixed by the scene. Behind the large portcullis of the Astrub gate, the mercenaries had gathered, waiting for their captain's signal to launch a counterattack against the enemy army. Posted on the ramparts, their leader couldn't tear his eyes away from the two figures fighting on the top of the hill shrouded in mist. The outcome of the battle – and most likely the war itself – would depend on this fight.

Tressa continued her attack, untiringly. Her hammer finally hit its target: it crashed forcefully into the spiky breastplate the emperor was wearing. The Bloodlord let out a puff when his bones broke; he ignored the pain and grabbed the handle of the heavy, rune-engraved mass with a clawed hand, preventing the queen from moving away. The jade sword swung in a bloody arc and cut deeply into Tressa's thigh. She let go to avoid a second attack. She staggered, feeling the venom from the blade burn her flesh. The Crocodyls had broken every rule of warfare since they set out to conquer the World of Twelve. It was no surprise, then, that their emperor had used poison – the weapon of cowards – to accomplish his goal.

Seeing their queen in difficulty, the Stubbyobs rushed to her aid. They were struck by the crackling fire invoked by the emperor.

Tressa struggled to stay standing. She raised her shield to protect herself from the lightning, and unhooked her axe from her belt. The Bloodlord turned slowly around his enemy, staying at a cautious distance. Victory was near... The queen was on her knees. With a cry of despair, she threw her axe. It spun and narrowly missed the crowned head of the emperor before planting itself in the chest of a scaly one who fell with a groan of agony.

The queen of the Stubbyobs was now weaponless. The master of the Crocodyls approached slowly. He raised the hammer he had taken from the queen and brought it down on Tressa's shield several times until her shield shattered.

The Bloodlord smiled cruelly. He tossed aside the hammer and took up his two-handed sword, ready to deliver the fatal blow.

The green blade was stopped in its tracks by another blade. An indistinct silhouette had suddenly appeared near the queen, like a ghost appearing out of nowhere. The emperor took a step back; he eventually identified the ghostly form, recognising the helm adorned with the crest of the Autumn Knight. He had killed the champion with his own hands. What was this sorcery?

The mist thickened. A growl not unlike an thunder shook the ground on the hill. The mercenaries, Stubbyobs and Crocodyls felt a supernatural fear seize their hearts.

Night fell on the battlefield. A night carried by two membranous wings, each flap of which filled the sky like thousands of cymbals sounding out in unison.

The Bloodlord looked up. The dragon Protector of Astrub had returned to keep its promise.

389.contentId:
...And the Smith gave birth to the First by striking the anvil of the gods. Still glowing from the creator's fire, the seven Stubbyobs rose, looked each other up and down, and then, by common agreement, scattered to found their own clans and reign over the sons and daughters of the mountains.

The Worldbeard clan settled under the massif east of Cania. From there, they expanded their borders and got lost in their dreams of conquest. Their motto is "Honourable, headstrong, hairy."

The Hard-Head clan elected to live in the depths of Mount Neselite, west of the rocky plains. They discovered the powers of Arkastone and became skilled crafters. Their motto is "Unity makes the smithy."

The Firebrand clan dug tunnels into the sides of the Sidimote volcanoes. They unearthed ore of exceptional quality, which allowed them to forge new alloys. Legend has it that they created grithril. Their motto is "From mine to mine."

The Stonestomach clan filled vast caves in Crackler Mountain. They made a pact with the stone giants, swearing to protect the jewels slumbering in the darkness. Their war with the Bworks and Goblins seems never-ending. Their motto is "Solid as stone."

The Freezammer clan crossed the Antinau Sea and set their anvils under Mount Scauldron. Skilled smiths, they never hesitated to brave the short but brutal Frigostian winter to create unique pieces. They laughed at the cold. Until Djaul's curse had them laughing out the other side of their faces. Their motto is "By ice and by fire."

The Yerg clan chose to live in Koalak Mountain. For thousands of years, they fought the hostile peoples of a wild region. They were the Stubbyobs' final rampart against the Jade Bloodlord's armies. After the battle of Astrub, they swore to protect Twelvians from the cruelty of the Crocodyls. Their motto is "Never sleep."

The Whitebeerds settled in the northern Lonesome Pine Trails area. Long considered to be the greatest of all Stubbyob brewers, they faced a tragic destiny: their clan was decimated during the war of the cities. The death of the King of Kings put an end to the Whitebeerds. Their motto is "Comfort is bitter."

390.contentId:
We have ruled beneath the mountains for over 7,000 years. Rulers of the underground world, we mine the rock to extract metals and use them as we see fit. Our pickaxes open paths through the darkness, like light breaking through the shadows; our hammers strike the anvil to the beat of the artisans' song. Our reward? To sculpt the stone, smelt the iron, polish the gemstones to create masterpieces to pass on to our heirs.

Don't be mistaken: we are not Rotceres. We're not hiding from the abovegrounders. The fire of war burns in our veins. We do not fear anything or anyone: it is our enemies that fear us. Cave-dwelling Trools soil themselves at the very mention of our name, Bworks pale in fear, Crocodyls call for their mothers. Even dragons sleep with one eye open, because these vile creatures, bereft of honour, know that we will show them no mercy if we catch them in their lairs.

We have gone into battle again and again over the millennia. Countless goblins have perished beneath the weight of our wrath (and our hammers). Disciples of Enutrof have been unceremoniously thrown out of our mines; servants of Cra have been asked to return to their forests on pain of ending up in the lava. Some feuds between the seven clans have been settled with axes, others with brimming tankards of beer. Long we waited for our rulers to crown a master of masters, a supreme leader, a king of kings: Skori Whitebeerd was the first. Unfortunately, he was also the last...

Skori's reign had, however, started under the best auspices. It took seven days to choose between the pretenders to the grithil throne. After a brawl for the ages, the king of the Whitebeerd clan was finally chosen.

The monarch's first task was to bring all the clans together under one banner: a thousand beers, one king. It was time to put an end to our many quarrels. The Bibles of Grudges and the Grudge Registry were purged of all existing disputes between the families. New alliances were made; pacts were sealed, beard hair was exchanged.

When Jade Bloodlord went forth to conquer the World of Twelve to spread wider the bounds of his empire, Skori rose up against him. The Hard-Heads and the Worldbeards made their stand to protect the Cania Plains; the Firebrands halted the invasion to the south of the Sidimote Moors. The Freezammers and the Whitebeerds crossed the Kantil Sea to join the troops fighting on the continent. The Stonestomachs defended the kingdom of Amakna. The Stubbyobs of the Koalak Mountains paid the heaviest price, suffering the full force of attacks from the Crocodyl legions. Queen Tressa Yerg distinguished herself during the final clash with the scaled enemy, on Astrub hill. Before the walls of the City of Mercenaries, the emperor fell, and his army was decimated. For the first time in history, the disciples of the Twelve fought at our side; our victory became legend.

Afterwards, the world changed. The Dofus brought hope for a better future, before it was stolen by a dragon. Xelor's Clock now marks the passage of time, an inescapable reminder of the weight of passing years that lie heavy on the shoulders of mortals.

The cities of Bonta and Brakmar divided us. Defiance, hypocrisy and lies shattered the promises of old. When the Crimson Dawn came, the sons and daughters of the mountains turned against one other. They were no longer allies united behind one flag; no more did they share the same table at banquets held by the king of kings. Skori Whitebeerd, the last symbol of union amongst his people, refused to take sides. This decision cost him his life: he and his followers were assassinated by demon-serving cowards. This loathsome massacre spelled the end of the great unified kingdom of the Stubbyobs.

Today, the great hall of the Whitebeerds lies empty, with only the wind blowing through it. The other clans have turned inwards, away from the each other and the outside world. The Freezammers are fighting against an eternal winter; the Hard-Heads were chased out of their smithy by unnatural beings. The Firebrands lost their king and the Worldbeards glory in their dreams of battle. The Stonestomachs will not leave their kingdom. Only the Yergs stay true to their vow: they make sure that the scaly ones are no longer a threat to the World of Twelve.

This is our story. Although our hearts are sometimes heavy, we feast whenever we have the chance, and we raise our tankards in honour of those who came before us. When our hammers strike red-hot metal, we hear the voices of our ancestors resounding once more in our majestic halls, like echoes of the past.

We are Stubbyobs, the children of the Great Smith.
For as long as there are mountains, we will reign.

This gigantic worm hides most of its body in the sand. Originally named Peb'Houlud by the inhabitants of Ohwymi, it is also believed to be a dominant male among the sand worms. No one knows how it came to be in Cania. This incredible creature fears moisture and has sharp, shiny teeth with a lustrous sheen which could be used to craft a beautiful tea set. Its skin is incredibly tough, as hard as stone. This is probably what gave it its name.

Its stomach can turn into a blazing furnace, and sometimes even secrete a very powerful acid. After a meal, Peb'Houlud's stomach fills up with a lukewarm liquid which is a lot less corrosive. It is therefore strongly recommended that when you fight the monster with valiant brothers in arms, you are swallowed last, in order to have a chance of surviving the digestive process.

In short

Met beside mysterious rifts.

Wanted for having eaten Stubbyobs for breakfast.

Sentenced to imprisonment by the Hard-Head militia.

Can only be captured by very experienced adventurers.

Warning:
Please note, this historical document contains words that could offend the sensitivity of the youngest Stubbyobs and is therefore restricted to a more mature audience. Stubbyobs under 77, please move on: nothing to see here.



Context
The B.E.A.R.D.Y. decree appeared in the year 44, 65 years after King Thud Ymero Hard-Head's coronation. Drafted by the "Bearded Elder Against Riffraff and Drunken Yobs" committee, the decree was strongly endorsed by King Thud Ymero, who was himself known for his aversion to beer.



Putting Into Force
The B.E.A.R.D.Y. decree was put into force seven days after its validation by King Thud Ymero, and imposed a ban on beer consumption (no matter where it came from) by Stubbyobs during the working day. A working day is defined by sunrise and sunset. Sanctions were applied for any Stubbyob seen drinking beer or found in a drunken stupor at their place of work.



Consequences
The implementation of this decree triggered one of the biggest Stubbyob strikes of all time. This strike lasted 77 years and ended in a massive bust-up at the heart of the Undersmithy, after which the decree was still in force. It never ceased to be contested during King Thud Ymero's entire reign, mainly because of unjustified and repeated sanctions and convictions.



Repeal
The B.E.A.R.D.Y decree was repealed in the year 152, being the first day after the coronation of King Rodrick Ymero, son of the late ruler Thud Ymero. The repeal of this decree contributed enormously to the confidence and respect accorded to the new king by the Hard-Head clan.

397.contentId:
The Ninth Smythposium



The blacksmiths' Smythposium is a grand contest for the creation of magical items, held in honour of the Great Smith, the first Stubbyob. Every 777 years, the best artisans compete to craft the most beautiful works of art. Winning the Smythposium is an immense honour, an acknowledgement of one's skill as well as a source of pride for the winner and their clan.

The last Smythposium that was recorded in the archives took place in the year -7 (according to the Twelvian calendar) under the patronage of the King of Kings, Skori Whitebeerd. For the ninth time, and over several weeks, the best artisans competed against each other in the heat of the furnaces and to the resounding clang of hammer striking anvil.


The champion tipped to win was the master smith Durandial, who had made a name for himself designing exceptional weapons for the warriors of the Hard-Head clan. He is mainly known for his automatic hammer, his sledgehelm and his macinator. He also invented some more surprising items such as the buzzer that buzzes until you buzz off and the foam-protector, which is very useful in the vicinity of clumsy people (or pranksters) who get food in the beer of the people they sit next to at feasts. Everyone was expecting Durandial to win the contest hands down.

During the first trial, the smith made a throwing axe that stunned the assembly. But a judge from the Freezammer clan found an irregularity; the artisan's beard was apparently too short... Accused of trimming his beard so it didn't get in his way while working, Durandial was disqualified.


This decision had serious consequences on the relationship between the Hard-Head and Freezammer clans; despite their family ties with the Freezammers, King Thud Ymero Hard-Head rejected the verdict and denounced it as a flagrant injustice. He caused a scandal in the banquet hall, sending participants' trays of shrimp in bacon and beer tankards flying.



He finally left the competition with Durandial and the rest of his clan. In spite of this regrettable incident, the Smythposium trials continued. The final saw the sons of Valdi Valiantsilver from the Firebrand clan face up against the sisters Brokkr and Eitri from the Freezammer clan. All of these finalists were smiths of great talent, and they knew they were going to have to surpass themselves.

The sons of Valdi crafted three extraordinary items: a golden headdress that shone like the sun, a boat that could fit in your pocket, and a grithril spear. But the two sisters did even better... Brokkr and Eitri forged a ring that gave you good fortune, a mount made of the seven sacred metals, and a hammer that could shatter any material, no matter how solid.


The hammer greatly impressed the judges by the quality of its manufacture, its modest size and because it was a hammer (no Stubbyob can resist a blunt weapon). After some short deliberations, the sisters from the Freezammer clan were unanimously declared the winners for their masterpiece.


The mount was given to young Prince Dazahk, who christened it Gullinburstyob, and the ring was to grace the finger of the King of Kings. The hammer was exhibited in the Freezammers' great forge so that all artisans could be inspired by the victory of their clan. Alas, it was stolen only a few months later...

398.contentId:
The Ymero Family



While many documents that recount the history of the Hard-Heads were destroyed or abandoned during the flight from the Undersmithy, through these pages, we will try to trace back the genealogy and reigns of the lords of the Ymero royal family who made their mark on Hard-Head history.


Gripus Ymero Hard-Head



The Hard-Head clan came into being with its very first ruler, Gripus Ymero Hard-Head, when Arkastone was first discovered on Mount Neselite.

Eager to exploit the mineral wealth of the mountain, the future Hard-Heads decided to settle in the depths of Mount Neselite and build the biggest forge anybody had ever seen right inside it.

Years passed by during which the very first Hard-Heads slowly but surely built the foundations for the Undersmithy. Research on Arkastone led to the creation of arms and armour that were unequalled among all of the Stubbyob clans, so much so that the Hard-Heads began to replace all their base materials with Arkastone, which was much tougher and more hard-wearing.

All the same, and against all expectations, the surrounding richness of Mount Neselite caused Gripus Ymero Hard-Head to lose his head and become greedy and covetous. He was ousted from the clan by Ragrul Ymero Hard-Head, his brother.

Ragrul Ymero Hard-Head



Ragrul Ymero was one of the most famous rulers in Hard-Head history, known both for his ambition and for being lousy-pig-headed. Under his reign, work on the Undersmithy continued unceasingly in line with the original vision of creating the greatest forge of any Stubbyob clan.

His desire to conquer the mountains led him to declare war on several races in the World of Twelve, especially the goblins, against whom he fought around thirty battles.

Ragrul was a haughty and obstinate ruler who constantly pushed his clan to outdo themselves and make their mark on history. Under his reign, there was a lot more bloodshed than wondrous discoveries, however. The date that his reign ended remains unknown to this day.

William Willbyforce Hard-Head



The third king of the Hard-Head clan was chosen by his peers after the years of Ragrul Ymero's turbulent reign.

A popular ruler due to the social reforms he prompted, which greatly improved everyday village life, William Willbyforce was a key player in the Hard-Head community. It is often said that this man and his ideas made great contributions to the clan's stability. During the reign of William Willbyforce, very few events troubled the clan's peaceful existence.

William Willbyforce was also one of the most respected rulers in all of Stubbyob history. Thus, after the traditional seven years of mourning following his death, the Stubbyobs from the Hard-Head clan decided to prolong their mourning by an additional seven years.

Einstone Ymero Hard-Head “the Clever”



Many long years of peace elapsed after William Willbyforce's reign, although it was sometimes still necessary to beat up the odd goblin now and then. Then King Einstone Ymero was crowned, famed for his exceptional intelligence among the Stubbyobs.

Under his reign, the Hard-Heads finished their development of the Undersmithy, and the result made a huge impression on the Stubbyob clans. Einstone built a colossal dam atop Mount Neselite in order to bring water from mountain springs to the depths of the smithy.

Although many Stubbyobs had little understanding of what the project was all about, the dam was impressive and fun to build, and so the Hard-Heads were proud of it. Today, many believe that the Stubbyob face on the dam represents Einstone Ymero, but this has never been proven. The nose of the stone face was broken many times and repaired with molten Arkastone.

Einstone Ymero proposed a truce with the goblins, but it was rejected, so the goblin-beating resumed.

After a time, however, tragedy struck. While the king was plumbing the still-unknown depths of Mount Neselite, a block of Arkastone fell on his head. This tragedy was long lamented by the Stubbyobs.

Ninha Ymero Hard-Head



Ninha Ymero, the great-great-granddaughter of Einstone Ymero, was a very popular ruler with the Hard-Head clan. Ninha Ymero fostered Hard-Head culture and encouraged the Stubbyobs to develop their trade and businesses.

It was during her reign that several breweries first emerged, most notably the Zeesmithy and Grodunk breweries, both opening on the same day, which marked the start of the long-running feud between the two establishments.

This sovereign commissioned the first school for Hard-Head weeyobs and sponsored works on Stubbyob history for an immense library in the depths of the Undersmithy. Many Stubbyobs did not see the point in collecting so many books, but seeing as it was Ninha Ymero, they didn't complain too much.



It was her reign that saw the appearance of one of the most legendary heroes the Hard-Head clan ever boasted: the valiant Tooth-Breaker, who drove back the goblins in a pitched battle. After he had broken the teeth of the goblin Zogiark the Terrifying and driven him out, Ninha Ymero Hard-Head married Tooth-Breaker. This grand wedding marked the beginning of long, prosperous years in the depths of the Undersmithy.


Guhk Ymero Hard-Head



While no major event transpired to disrupt the daily life of the Hard-Heads under Guhk Ymero's reign, this sovereign is well-known in the Hard-Head clan for his marriage to Eitri Forganvil, cousin of Alvise Forganvil, queen of the Freezammer clan.

Although the Freezammer clan had always been one of the Hard-Heads' biggest competitors in the art of the forge, real hostilities only broke out between the two clans after the Smythposium, held on 7 Jullier in the year -7, during the reign of Thud, son of Guhk Ymero.

One of the few significant events in the 400 years of Guhk Ymero's reign was the 777th victory against the goblins, which was celebrated with major festivities. After that, battles with the goblins happened less and less often.

Thud Ymero Hard-Head



The son of Guhk Ymero was another Ymero sovereign who made his mark on Hard-Head history. However, he was certainly one of the least-liked rulers in all of Stubbyob history. Thud Ymero was mainly known for his aversion to beer and the enforcement of his B.E.A.R.D.Y. decree banning the consumption of alcohol during the working day.

First cousin of the Freezammers, he was all the more criticised after the Smythposium in which the queen mother, Eitri Forganvil, competed against Durandial, the Hard-Head champion. Durandial was disqualified by a Freezammer judge, a disqualification that was highly contested by the Hard-Head clan... but not so much by their king.

Under the reign of Thud Ymero Hard-Head, there were more strikes and protests than all the other past reigns put together, up until Lord Cal Ymero, that is. Of special note is the Great 77-Day Strike, which took place after the B.E.A.R.D.Y. decree came into force, and ended in general brawling throughout the entire clan.

Luckily, the sovereign's reign was cut short by his tragic disappearance following an unfortunate incident with vegetables. The B.E.A.R.D.Y. decree was not enforced during the Stubbyobs' obligatory seven-year mourning period. His son, King Rodrick Ymero, had the decree repealed as soon as he was crowned.

Rodrick Ymero Hard-Head



Although the son of a ruler who was little-liked and badly regarded by his people, Rodrick Ymero was not branded with the same reputation as his father, luckily for him. On the contrary, following the abolition of the B.E.A.R.D.Y. Decree, king Rodrick Ymero was very popular amongst his people throughout his life. To this day, he is still seen as one of the best rulers the clan ever had. Rodrick Ymero enjoyed one of the longest reigns, and it was most notably marked by the sad episode of the Undersmithy Disaster.

Rodrick Ymero and his wife Thadad Ymero, née Stonebrewer, were very popular with their people because of the innovations and positive changes they brought about in the clan. Thadad Ymero was mainly known for popularising Stubbyob braiding, which became a popular fashion in the Undersmithy.

Rodrick, a peerless knight and impressive axe-wielder, but also a renowned smith in his free time, helped restore the Hard-Head clan's image, which had become somewhat tarnished since the reign of his father. The Ymero family were no longer reproached for their distant alliance with the Freezammer clan.
When the tragic events of the Undersmithy took place, it quickly became clear to the sovereign and his wife that the Hard-Heads would need to abandon the Undersmithy. During a particularly violent battle, while Rodrick Ymero was trying to contain the Stubbyobs who had been resurrected, he asked the survivors of the clan to flee alongside Queen Thadad Ymero and to seal off the Undersmithy without waiting for him.

Driven to despair, with a heavy heart weighed down by the anxious hope that her husband would rejoin them, Thadad Ymero could not allow her people to remain in danger. Reluctantly, she ordered the main gate to be sealed, and no one ever found out what became of their king.

Thadad Ymero guided the Hard-Heads in the construction of their new village on Mount Neselite. The queen was of great help to the clan who were undone by the catastrophe and in mourning. She helped them find their feet again, and inspired them not to be discouraged by the loss of their home.

Unfortunately, as she was already very old for a Stubbyob, Thadad Ymero passed away during the seven years of mourning for her husband, leaving the reins of the Hard-Head clan to her very young son, Cal Ymero.

Cal Ymero Hard-Head



Cal Ymero is the youngest ruler the Stubbyobs have ever had. Crowned at the age of 127, he succeeded his father, Rodrick Ymero, who was greatly loved by the Hard-Head clan.

Unfortunately for the young sovereign, he took the throne during a very difficult time for the Hard-Heads and had to learn how to rule while leading his people as they rebuilt the clan.

Like his grandfather before him, Cal Ymero is a contentious ruler due to his family ties to the Freezammers, and also for his lack of experience in ruling due to his youth.

Since the sad episode of the Undersmithy disaster which occurred during his father's reign, the doors of the Undersmithy have remained sealed, and no one has returned inside of the mountain.

Foreword



This book presents the rudiments of the language of an unknown people, the Pazteks.

Missing from most of the history books of Amakna, this insular people with quite unusual customs have a belief system that is very different from that of other Twelvians. Perhaps this is why they have sought to describe the world around them with their own words. Yet, it is said that they previously lived on the continent.

Why did they leave? A detailed study of their language, traditions, taboos, and ideals would perhaps provide answers to those who wish to know more.

For adventurers in a hurry, even basic knowledge of Paztek vocabulary will help them understand and be understood by these mysterious wearers of masks.

Principles of Grammar


Sentence Structure


The Paztek language is grounded in emotions. Indeed, in Paztek, every sentence is obligatorily grounded in an emotion, and this grounding is marked at the start of every sentence.



Grounding Emotion - (adjective) - DO/IO - Verb+Subject

This can be illustrated by translating the following sentence:
"I eat a red api."

In Paztek, this would be:
"Nalla rad pada madoufnass"


Nalla: Here, the grounding emotion is neutral as no specific emotion is being communicated. The marker "Nalla" indicates this neutrality and is placed at the start of the sentence.

Rad: red, an adjective. It is placed immediately before the object it describes.

Pada: Api

Madoufnass: "I eat". Here, "madouf" is the verb "to eat" and "nass" is the subject, "I". The subject is always attached to the verb at the end of the sentence.

Grounding: Emotions and Tones


Apissa = extreme politeness
Balla = romantic tone
Ballu = seductive tone
Bradu = bitterness
Chuba = fear
Delulla = mistrust
Galla = enthusiastic tone
Lulla = confusion, lack of understanding
Naballa = awe, reverence (often used when speaking of gods and religion)
Nalla = neutral tone
Niapu = disgust
Pravuk = pleading, entreaty
Tachuba = horror
Tatumu = deep sadness, pain
Tchala = very friendly tone
Teg = tiredness
Tsuma = surprise, astonishment
Tumu = sadness
Turtta = order, imperative tone
Varch = hostility
Vina = worry
Vizteg = exhaustion
Vurtag = determination

Emotion words may also be used alone to express a direct emotion or feeling.

For example:

Niapu: How horrible!
Vizteg: I'm exhausted.
Lulla: Why?
Turtta: Obey!
Balla: I love you.
Tchala: Hi!

Negation


Negation is expressed by adding "bor" to the very end of the sentence.

Example:

Nalla a kaspiknass = I understand you.

nalla: neutral tone
a: you
kaspik: to understand
nass: I

Lulla a kaspiknass bor = I don't understand you.

Lulla: confusion, lack of understanding
a: you
kaspik: to understand
nass: I
bor: negation

Interrogative Mood


When the speaker wishes to formulate a question, the word "Til" is added to the start of the sentence, before the grounding emotion. Question marks are not used in the Paztek language.

Example:

Til nalla tsé kazkoulnass = Do I kill him?

Til: question
nalla: neutral tone
tsé: he/she/it
kazkoul: to kill
nass: I

Conjugating Verbs



Conjugation is simple in Paztek. The past and future are expressed simply as suffixes.



Future Tense


When speaking in future tense, the prefix "tur-" is added before the verb.

Example:

Nalla a tur-madoufnass = I'm going to eat you.

Nalla: neutral tone
a: you
tur-: future
madouf: to eat
nass: I



Past Tense


When speaking in past tense, the prefix "jadi-" is added before the verb.

Example:

Nalla a jadi-madoufnass = I ate you

Nalla: neutral tone
a: you
jadi-: past
madouf: to eat
nass: I

Temporal Adverbs



Temporal adverbs are placed before the verb.

Example:

Galla Frigost tatchi tur-variganass = I will arrive in Frigost tomorrow.

Galla: enthusiasm
Tatchi: tomorrow
Tur-: future
Variga: arrive (in)
Nass: I

Subject Pronouns


Nass: I
A: you
Tsé (-sé): he/she/it (they)
Baldu (-aldu): we
Tsa (-sa): them
Ala: you (formal: used exclusively when speaking to one or more gods)



Possession


To correctly mark the possessive, the corresponding possessive adjective is placed before the noun in question.

Example:

Til nalla lek kakiba-a-patriak = Where are your people?

Til: question
nalla: neutral tone
lek: where
kakiba: to be located, to be somewhere
a: you/your
patriak: people

Use of a Different Subject


When the subject is a name, the name will be used in place of the subject in the sentence.

Example:

Nalla batchiz rida-Herdegrize = Herdegrize loves books.

Nalla: neutral tone
Batchi: book (plural: batchiz)
Rida: love



The Plural


To express a word in plural form, the suffix "-z" or "-ez" (after a consonant) is added to the end of the word.

Example:

Zofiau (Gupin) - Zofiauz (Gupins)
Omin (Koalak) - Ominez (Koalaks)

Directions


Nar = north
Sad = south
Etta = east
Otta = west

Naretta = northeast
Narotta = northwest
Sadotta = southwest
Sadetta = southeast


"Es" is generally placed before the direction one wishes to include in the sentence.

The Concept of Wind Among the Paztek


The Pazteks are deeply attached to the wind, the air, and the meanings that they can carry.
Therefore, when someone mentions the wind in a story or conversation, they are often expressing an emotion, a fear or a particular feeling.

Here are a few examples:

Jarku = wind of change
Jafunra = wind of rest, wind of mourning
Jarkazku = breath of death
Jaruba = wind of fear
Jarballa = wind of passion (romantic)

401.contentId:
The Pazteks: Customs and Anecdotes



Disciples of the goddess Cra are called Padaz. We don't know if it's due to their naivety or because of their strong taste for apisauce.

The Pazteks' major god is Kwetzakotlek. His fiery palace is at the top of a volcano. His link with Kilizab, the legendary king of the Quetsnakiatls, remains to be proven.

The hereditary enemies of the Pazteks are the Galidylez (Crocodyls). They believe that all Galidylez must die (and possibly be turned into handbags or bath mats).

Although they are enemies, both Pazteks and Galidylez seem to share a taste for sacrifices. The colour blue seems to be associated with this slightly barbaric practice. An ethnologist with a dubious reputation has claimed that this custom explains why there are no Smarfs on Paztek Island.



Most Pazteks are required to wear a mask. Putting on make-up is a minimum: going out without covering one's face is an abjection punishable by death by ingesting mushrooms. This prohibition is similar to the precepts of the Masqueraiders: scholars have, therefore, speculated that there is some kind of kinship between the two peoples.

In the Pazteks' religious rituals, gold is associated with Father Tikka (the sun), and silver with Mother Shibal (the moon).

The Pazteks' diet consists mainly of fish and fruit. The Galidylez' diet consists mainly of Pazteks and fruit. The Chaklaz' (Piraniaks') diet consists mainly of Pazteks and Galidylez.

The pazteka (watermelon) is a fruit that is sacred to Pazteks. According to certain beliefs, it is linked to a creature called Kagali Shibal (the Scaly Mother). Ingesting a large quantity of Paztekaz apparently makes it possible to have prophetic visions of the future (and causes a desperate urge to go and urinate behind a bush).



The Malavin (seagull) is a bird that it's best to avoid upsetting, unless you want trouble of the worst kind, from a simple dropping inadvertently landing on your head to chronic misfortune passed down from generation to generation. According to an age-old proverb, a fulfilled Malavin can change the world. Its "Caw!" is both dreaded and desired by all Paztek fisherman (and boat owners in general).

The Zofiau (Gupin) seems to be well-known to the Pazteks, although this cousin of the Pingwins comes from Frigost Island. According to legend, the Zofiau is able to "vina Krosmoz krousti" (break the Krosmoz) if left unattended. The source of this rather frightening myth remains unknown.

In general, Pazteks dislike the colour berk (green). This may be due to the many dangers that abound in the jungle covering part of their island. There is a rumour (albeit it unproven) that young Pazteks are allergic to green vegetables.



The Omin (Koalak) people have apparently helped the Pazteks during certain events throughout their history. The Jon Omin (Bloody Koalak) is famous for its ability to do the work of ten people, as well as for its intemperate love of hops-based drinks, Kazteks (a sort of visored headgear) and dubious puns.

Paztaga is a ritual drink that is the colour of the sun, consumed during hot weather. It seems to go hand in hand with a certain ball game with varying rules based on bad faith and the ability of participants to exaggerate reality.

For Pazteks, Dodu (Dough-Dough) feathers are more precious than gold. They are also more comfortable for filling mattresses.

There is a legend that a Pandawa explorer invented chocolate after having shared a bitter, spicy drink with a Paztek. The explorer was apparently an ancestor of Stayfun Bonnawa.



There is a myth that a city of roads paved with gold lies across the Antinau Sea, and that its inhabitants are Crocodyls wearing masks. It is said that the mere sight of this marvellous city could drive any Enutrof mad.

Pazteks hate Kakapikez (Moskitos), which they shamelessly squash whenever they get the chance. A Paztek alchemist apparently developed a gas capable of eradicating these harmful insects that is released into the air using an ingenious system that makes liquid boil at precise times throughout the night. There's no stopping progress.

Contrary to Moskitos, Araknaz (Arachnees) are spared by the Pazteks, who consider them to be useful creatures. Nonetheless, once they get larger than a certain size, reducing Araknaz to a pulp is acceptable.



It is said that Pazteks invented a complex cyclic calendar based on the movements of the planets in the Krosmoz, cardinal points and divinatory space-time. They eventually abandoned this dating system because it utterly confused them. Moreover, seeing the end of the world appear on the calendar every year became rather tiresome. Nobody knows if the goddess Mahiya might have had something to do with this.

If certain slightly fanciful scholars are to be believed, the Pazteks are the inventors of sweeteks, beefsteks, salamitek and slices of cakek.
