Welcome!

Ascension Island is a large, 50-storey competitive dungeon for players at levels 100 to 200. Climb as many floors as possible to earn maximum rewards!

Prizes

(Insert Fufu table here)

For each floor, you'll be given tokens when you complete the final threshold. A threshold completed in "Classic" difficulty will win you six tokens, whereas a threshold completed in "Nightmare" mode will win you 12.

These tokens serve as currency on Ascension Island. You can use them to purchase the resources necessary to craft new equipment from an NPC in one of the temple rooms.

Dofus fragments will allow you to obtain a Dofus. They can also be traded to the merchant NPC for a few tokens.

In addition to tokens and Dofus fragments, players at the top of the rankings can proudly bear an ornament depending on their ranking on their server. These ornaments will be unlocked for one rotation based on the ranking achieved during the previous rotation. So you mustn't rest on your laurels if you want to keep your title!

Scoring

The score you are able to achieve on Ascension Island depends mainly on two factors.

Progress

  • Each floor you complete in "Classic" mode will earn you 100 points.
  • Each floor you complete in "Nightmare" mode will earn you 150 points.
  • Completing the entire "Classic" mode will give you 200 extra points.
  • Completing the entire "Nightmare" mode will give you 300 extra points.

Challenges

  • Each fight will offer five challenges that you may choose to complete – or not.
  • Each completed challenge will give you a certain number of points.
  • For each challenge completed during a fight, a fixed "combo" bonus is added to the fight score according to the scale below.
1 challenge completed = 0 bonus points 2 challenges completed = 15 bonus points 3 challenges completed = 30 bonus points 4 challenges completed = 50 bonus points 5 challenges completed = 75 bonus points

Survival

  • Your score will suffer a penalty every time a teammate dies in a fight.
  • Resurrection effects cannot remove this penalty.
  • However, death after being resurrected will not raise the penalty (if a player dies, is revived, then dies again, the penalty will apply only once).
  • The score will be validated at the end of each threshold. Once all three fights in a threshold have been completed, the scores from the fights will be validated and saved.
  • If you don't manage to complete a threshold, the scores from the completed floors will not be saved.

Improving Your Score

  • With each new rotation, you'll receive 8 items that allow you to return to a previously completed threshold in order to improve your score there.
  • These items are available in limited quantities, so you'll only be able to improve certain thresholds. It's up to you to choose which ones to improve to get the best final score.
  • You can use them in both Classic and Nightmare mode.
  • As with initial score validation, you'll need to complete the entire threshold in order to validate the scores for the three floors.
  • Only the best overall score from the threshold is saved. This way, if your attempt at improvement turns out to be less satisfactory than the initial validation, your score will not be lowered.

How It Works

Progress

  • Ascension Island is divided into several parts called thresholds.
  • Each threshold is a group of three floors that's always structured in the same way: standard floor -> standard floor -> boss floor.
  • The island is divided into 16 thresholds of three floors each, plus two special boss floors.
  • Each threshold contains a monster family chosen at random, the level of which is determined by the floor number. The higher the floor number, the higher the level of the monsters you'll encounter.
  • Your goal is to complete as many floors as possible in order to collect the most rewards and get the highest score possible.
  • Losing a fight or exiting in the middle of a threshold will require you to start over from the first floor of the threshold the next time you attempt it.
  • 1 to 3 players can take part in Ascension Island fights together. The monster groups you'll face consist of four or five opponents.

Difficulty

Ascension Island is available in two difficulties:

  • Classic mode features monsters at levels 100 to 200.
  • Nightmare mode features monsters at levels 200 to 300.

In order to unlock "Nightmare" mode from the NPC at the entrance, you will first need to complete all 50 floors in Classic mode.

Once Nightmare mode is unlocked, you can enter Ascension Island again and try to work your way through the 50 floors.

Everything works the same way as it does in Classic mode, but the monster families you encounter are different and the rewards are greater.

Rotations

Roughly every two months, the content of Ascension Island is reset in order to change how the monster families are distributed across thresholds, and also how the combat area is laid out. However, for maps where you face bosses, the starting obstacles and placements remain the same for all rotations.

During a single rotation, all players encounter the same monsters on the same floors and at the same levels. The challenges are identical, as are the starting placement slots.

With each new rotation, your progress will be reset and your previous score will be saved.

405.contentId:
My people. My... dear, dear people.

Whatever acts and crimes I may have committed, please know that it has always been your safety that I've been fighting for. Day after day, I work the raw clay of our salvation, of our liberty, with my own dry hands. No one has the right to enslave us. No one has the right to ridicule our beliefs and trample our fervour. I will rise up against them all if I must. Against those who have always been my enemies, but also those yet to come. Against you, stranger, you who rise to face me, your vanity and your pride filled to bursting with a foul poison that devours you. And I rise to face you, my brother, who are ready to cast your convictions aside to don the mask of treachery.

I will fight. Even if I lose my mind and my senses along the way. If I must give my eyes and my flesh, my lungs and my body, I will fight. For if the life I have inherited is that of a fugitive, it is the life of a conqueror that I have chosen to earn. You can hate me for what I have done. Call me a criminal and point accusing fingers. Cover me in disdain and call me an oathbreaker. I've stopped believing in miracles. Stopped believing that somewhere far away, in the lands where those who have rejected us live their lives, there might be a solution to all of our suffering. And so, brothers and sisters, family and friends, extend your weapons to me, lend me your spells. Give me your trust and your blessing. I shall turn my body into a shield. For if my physical form is still standing, my true being died on the day we lost it all.

I will not play the loyal messiah of some fanatical people, nor even the martyr driven mad by years spent awash in an inexorable faith. Even here, I will be as I have always been: a priestess in service to her people, just as Mazin Lyn was before me. I hope that one day, I will again tread the soft earth of our home, be able to call a place "mako" once more, and feel free and strong, surrounded by those who are dear to me. I believe that this will one day be possible. Thanks to him. Him... he is the last person I want to chain myself to. He is the last one I want to give everything to.

My brother, you may reproach me for having gone too far. For having gone beyond the sensible life I was given. For having braved the seas to raise hurricanes. For having fought the heavens to draw down the lightning. I will agree that this is true. That I have done what others never could have done. That I have taken my own life in my hands, and those of the people I love, without asking their opinion. Did I really have a choice? For if I had not done it, who else could have? Would you have stood up, dear brother, to help our people? Would you have plunged yourself completely into suffering and pain to allay the evil that eats away at us? Would you have fought those savages and exposed your body, dripping with our enemies' blood and entrails, in order to scare them away? No... You were never the rebel of the family, were you? I don't think I am either.

406.titleId: Tales and Legends of the Bayou, Volume 1
406.contentId:
The Arachnee and the Mangrove Tree


It is said that long ago, long before the first Crocodyl had emerged from its egg, the primordial jungle and primordial ocean were locked in a merciless war. Each wanted to spread as wide as possible, overtaking the other. Trees grew to the sky, towering over the sea, becoming larger every day, tickling the clouds with their rustling leaves. The forest cast its shadow over the waters, confining them to chilly darkness. The waves tried incessantly to submerge the land... But they always withdrew because they would break against the woody bodies of the mangrove trees.


At the edge of the jungle, alone in front of the sea, the mangrove trees were the rainforest's rampart against the assaults of the tides. Their roots were manifold, deep, sinuous, and deeply anchored in the nourishing soil. Without their vigilance, the borders of the forest would have been devoured by the ocean's foamy maw.

One day, a small Arachnee spun her web in the tallest of the mangrove trees. Food was plentiful in the giant tree's branches; the wind from the ocean carried insects that would get caught in her silken webs, like fish in a fisherman's nets. The Arachnee was afraid of drowning and it terrified her to see young trees bend then break under the weight of the diluvial rains. The old mangrove tree provided certain shelter. He would never break.


The large tree was amused by the spinner's dancing with her agile, fragile, graceful feet. He developed a deep affection for the Arachnee. While she swung between his leaves, carefree, he told her forgotten stories that only the ancient trees could remember.


Time passed. The forest gained ground. The furious waters attempted in vain to uproot the old mangrove tree. High in his branches, the Arachnee danced, mocking the sea that couldn't reach her.

At the height of its anger, the ocean gave birth to an immense, gigantic wave whose foam reached the clouds. Towering over the highest treetops, the wave advanced, growling, and crashed into the large mangrove tree. He remained upright, while the trees around him were scattered like wisps of straw. He defied the ocean, resisting the weight of waters able to down a mountain... The Arachnee was not so lucky.


Swallowed by the wave, the spinner clung to her web. She attempted valiantly to hold on, but her silken threads eventually broke. The small creature was carried off, without a sound. She disappeared under the waters.


The old mangrove tree uprooted himself, lifting his roots, walking like the Arachnee who had kept him company. He moved slowly towards the ocean. The other mangrove trees rose up as well, then stopped. They were the children and guardians of the forest. They could not leave the primordial jungle without endangering it.

The large tree gestured goodbye to his brothers, and then the sea closed over him. Satisfied with this sacrifice, the ocean calmed.


And thus was born the mangrove, the barrier made of trees with long, salt-encrusted roots. And thus was born the bayou. And while the mangrove trees watch over the islands in the archipelago, forever sentinels eyeing the ocean, it is said that the oldest among them still walks the ocean floor in search of the Arachnee who once danced in his branches.

The Legend of Crocuzko


In the western part of the Archipelago of Scales, there is a very sinister island covered by eternal, starless night – Crocuzko. But while Crocuzko seems dark and sad now, it wasn't always the case.


Crocuzko and Orado have always been sister islands caressed by the same ocean breeze, the same rays of the sun, and the same starlight. Life was good for Ixchelonia, the moon-turtle goddess, and Kinichinti, the sun-lizard god, as they watched over their children living on both islands. Kinichinti caused the suns rays to glow in splendour over the archipelago, playing with making the light glow in every corner of the islands or piercing the shadows in the bayou with burst of sunlight. Then, every evening, he made way for his beloved Ixchelonia. She give birth to a gentle, calm night over the waves. And serene peace would fall slowly over the archipelago while Kinichinti would amuse his beloved by making the stars glimmer.

Years went by. Years of peace for the Crocodyls on the archipelago, years in which they enjoyed Kinichinti's daytime antics as much as they enjoyed Ixchelonia's starry softness. But one day, everything changed for the two divinities. One day, as Kinichinti was shining brightly throughout Crocuzko, he came across a Crocodyl sitting by the sea. Kinichinti took the shape of a golden lizard and moved softly over to the reptile. And there he saw the depths of the Crocodyl's azure eyes. They spoke for hours, until the very second Kinichinti had to give way to Ixchelonia. That night, the stars glimmered less brightly.


The next day, when Kinichinti's rays of sun appeared, the golden lizard slipped tenderly to Crocuzko beach, eager for the Crocodyl's return. When she emerged from the edges of the bayou, Kinichinti couldn't help but feel a wave of pleasure at the sight of her. The two reptiles spend the day together. As they did the next day. And the day after that. The days seemed to grow longer, the sun was bright and hot, and nights seemed shorter and shorter on the archipelago.

Ixchelonia felt more and more abandoned by her beloved, but didn't understand why he was so distant. One morning, after an especially short night, Ixchelonia decided to follow Kinichinti. In the form of a turtle with a white shell, she learned to her dismay that Kinichinti was smitten with the azure-eyed Crocodyl. Ixchelonia's sadness rapidly turned to anger, and the sky was suddenly covered with inexorable darkness, a darkness so dark that it was impossible to find one's bearings in the pitch black. Kinichinti, now unable to see the face of the beautiful Crocodyl, understood the sudden nature of the darkness.


So, the Sun Lizard went to his beloved, who was heading for Orado. Kinichinti pleaded with her. In vain. And, as Ixchelonia was preparing to bring the same eternal night down over Orado Island, she turned to the one she had always loved.

She threatened to plunge the Archipelago of Scales into darkest night, a night so black that the waves of the sea would swallow all the islands up without seeing them. When he asked the goddess what he could do to make up for his mistakes, she ordered him to shine the sun's rays into the Crocodyl's eyes until those very rays had burnt her eyes out.


Horrified by the fate awaiting the Archipelago of Scales if he didn't obey, Kinichinti obeyed and made the sun burn so bright in the Crocodyl's eyes that the heat burned them entirely. Before the bloody eyes of the beauty, Kinichinti was overcome with despair and his helplessness lead him to insanity. Then, he burned the eyes of all the Crocodyls on the Island of Crocuzko.

They say that Crocuzko's eternal night has never lifted, and the stars no longer shine over the island. A heavy, anxiety-filled silence has replaced the serenity of the nights there and, in the dark, the silhouettes of the red-eyed Crocodyls that still live on Crocuzko move about.

The Scarlet Lotus


For a century, the emperor Croctezuma left his sumptuous palace to visit a pond on the same day every year. He would sit among the rushes and reeds while the Prancing Chimeras ended their nightly symphony of croaks with a flourish and the yellow-crested Froggies sang in concert to celebrate the rising sun.


All day long, during the hours marking off Kinichinti's passage, the emperor would watch a lotus on the surface of the water – a scarlet lotus that stood out among the white flowers floating delicately on the mirror made of troubled waters. He stayed silent, mindless of the guards posted some ways away and the slaves ready to execute his slightest desires.

At dusk, finally, Croctezuma would rise and follow the road back to the imperial city in silence. His most attentive servants would sometimes see a tear pearl up in the corner of his eye, shimmering in the light of Ixchelonia's silver shell, but they never mentioned it to anyone because everyone knows that emperors never cry.


So, what was the purpose of this strange ceremony, repeated so many times over the years? The priests took it as a sign of devotion to Chaklaplok, the famished god of biting waters. Had the emperor sworn an oath, made a promise that he couldn't break? Had he sacrificed someone he cared about to the Piraniaks lurking in the depths, greedy for the flesh of a loved one? No one seemed to have any memory of it.

In the palace halls, courtesans hypocritically whispered that Croctezuma had failed, and that the blood-coloured flower was proof that he had committed some fault, a sacrilege, an unforgivable crime. It goes without saying that these disloyal subjects were punished in the most severe ways if they were ever uncovered. Their viper tongues hung out of their open maws as they agonised on the top of the pyramid of traitors, their eyes rolled back, their guts spilling out onto the floor to feed the famished varans.


Was the scarlet lotus the symbol of a lost love, or the signature of a bloody pact? Was it an offering to the Scaly Mother, or the cradle of a ruby born from the swamp mud? Every citizen in the empire had their own theory on the subject... but the only one who knew the truth was Croctezuma.

On the evening of the last day of his reign, in the dusk of his life, the emperor called his son Viracroca to his bedside. While the doctors attempted one last bleeding, applying a host of leeches to the weakened body of the old Crocodyl, Croctezuma revealed his secret to his heir. He spoke of a prophecy. He spoke of a major battle, and of a grey dragon. He spoke of the death of the one that would be called the Jade Bloodlord, and of the tragedy that would follow. He spoke of the Crocodyls' blood, which would flow like a river and stain the sacred flowers' petals red before drying up forever. Every year, as he stared at the scarlet lotus, Croctezuma prayed that the visions that haunted him would not come true... all the while knowing that his destiny was to work to make them possible.


That night, and for the very first time, the emperor's son cried. Not for his father, who breathed his last breath and joined the gods in their celestial city with streets paved in jade... No, he cried for his people as a whole.

407.contentId:
Our hero's story begins as many others do. It is the kind of story told among friends around a fire, or while relaxing with family in front of the fireplace in the living room. It's talked about down the pub, or even simply found between the pages of a nice book. After all, books are worlds open to all sorts of adventures, as they say. Perhaps this story will take you on a wonderful journey. Who knows?


In a land not far from your own, an inquisitive and learned hero was searching for an ancient recipe that he had caught wind of. It was for a potion that could bestow a great power: the ability to effortlessly understand every language in the world, thus providing unlimited access to all knowledge. Young and daring as he was, he set out to uncover the precious tome containing this highly prized recipe. He was advised to talk to the professors and scholars in the small town where he lived, but he soon realised no one could help him to any satisfactory degree.


After many moons, at last he found the object of his search in a village in Amakna. He had looked in nearly every place of learning in the area and his efforts had been rewarded – the rare tome was finally in his hands. He opened the beautiful leather-bound book and began to read.

408.contentId:
The chapters flew by his awestruck eyes, words speeding one after the other, pages being turned ever so quickly and precisely. Our hero was caught up in his reading as if trapped in the centre of a swirling tornado, unable to escape. His heart skipped a beat the moment he came to the section about the recipe for the potion. Shock and despair overwhelmed him as he discovered that the pages where the sought-after recipe should have been were either torn or missing. There was nothing left of it. Our hero, now filled with sorrow, set the book down, ready to abandon his quest... when he noticed a few words write themselves on a blank page in the volume. The words appeared and formed sentences, eventually becoming a series of hints.


"For many centuries, alchemists from all over the World of Twelve worked on this potion that would confer great renown. If grasping with ease the words of every dialect of every language is your wish, piece together this chapter by finding the missing pages in places where quiet and knowledge reign supreme. Your perseverance and courage will be your greatest allies in this quest."


Rereading these words, our hero carefully copied them down and then put the small piece of parchment in his satchel, ready to resume his journey, all starry-eyed. He didn't know when, but he knew that the recipe would be his someday. Our hero took great care in preparing for the long adventure before him. After dealing with a few formalities, he bade farewell to his family and friends, whom he expected not to see for at least a few years.

409.contentId:
He began his trek by crossing a bridge, soon after which he came upon an odd forest filled with plants and trees he had never seen before. The wildlife and architecture of this island so fascinated him that he took his time exploring it fully, but he never forgot his main purpose. In one village, he found a small, welcoming library. Our hero became acquainted with the regular patrons; though at first wary, they ultimately agreed to speak with the adventurer. He gleefully discovered his first piece of a page, the writing completely undecipherable to him. He supposed it must be part of the spell, carefully guarding the potion formula, only to reveal the full recipe once all pages were collected. With a saddened heart after two years of equally impressive and rewarding discoveries, he left the island on a small merchant ship, which brought him to a large port city.


It was not so much the way the ships moved or how the sea smelled that unsettled our adventurer. He had once come across a note about this town, and what he now found was nothing like the descriptions: it was much lovelier, sunnier and grander. He rented a small home there, expecting to make many new discoveries. As he explored the markets, taverns and places of learning, he made new acquaintances and learned to decipher a certain old language. While digging through the archives of a famed place of learning in the city, our hero uncovered a second page of the book containing the formula for the desired potion. Another year had passed, and it was time for our adventurer to set off once more in a new direction.


A few weeks after leaving the port city and traversing villages, moors, plains and various dangerous places, he entered a large and impressive city. Never had he seen one this size: the cobblestone streets, the hustle and bustle, all the townspeople and vendors – it was all new to him. To afford comfortable lodging, he needed to find a job, as rent was much higher here than elsewhere. He learned rudimentary hunting, how to sew clothes and his own shoes, as well as bartering and sales, before landing a modest job as an archivist at the main library. Just as imposing as the city it called home, the library stacks seemed to go on forever. But as exhausting as his work could be, our adventurer remained steadfast and had ample opportunity to continue his search. And so one night, before leaving the library, as he was shelving books, he found a third page. He immediately hid it in his bag and headed home to analyse it. Three years had passed since he left the port city, and his work was beginning to pay off. It was time to set off for new lands and look for the penultimate page of the recipe.


His journey north took a month, but it was full of discoveries. The adventurer arrived at a city just as big as the one before, and even brighter! It was a very pleasant, peaceful place. Our hero had tucked enough money away to live comfortably, which allowed him to spend his days idly wandering through the big library and strolling down the alleyways full of ever-cheerful passers-by. He discovered the fourth page wedged between two books sitting in a small cardboard box, where no one would have thought to look! His perseverance was as intact as it was that first day, and with another discovery under his belt, he packed his things and returned to his starting point, believing he had not searched very thoroughly the first time.


After seven years of travel, discoveries, encounters and adventure, he went back home.

410.contentId:
The village was the same as before, according to our adventurer. His friends had got older, as had he; and he was wiser and more knowledgeable. Returning to the library where his quest had begun, he searched in a spot known only to him: a little shelf devoted to ancient literature. Our hero's eyes fell upon the page he had so hoped and longed for.


His quest was complete, and the only thing left to do was a simple operation: assembling the pages and the book. It had hardly aged a day, looking just as beautiful and neat in its leather binding, awaiting the adventurer's return. He opened it to the missing section, and suddenly, sparkling brightly, the tome reconstituted itself and snapped shut. With trembling hands and a pounding heart, our hero sat down and pulled the book toward him. He opened it at the middle and turned the pages until reaching the recipe. He felt his heart stop as he discovered the pages were entirely blank. What had been undecipherable was now invisible.

411.contentId:
He experienced several different feelings then; having thought he had completed his quest and would be able to craft and taste the potion, he saw his work reduced to nothing. There was nothing left, and he thought he had nothing left either. But he was seriously mistaken, and the book made him realise it: such a formula had never existed, as it would serve no purpose. In searching, travelling and learning the tongues of the places he visited, the adventurer had learned more than he ever could have from a book. The only thing that can help knowledge seekers, learned people and the curious is their perseverance and desire to learn. The search for the formula was but a ploy for our hero to realise that life cannot be reduced to taking a simple potion, but that anything is possible with a little work.


A book is an entire universe allowing for the most wonderful adventures, and this story is proof of that. Never underestimate the power a story can impart to you, but also remember to never give up: you are the only one responsible for your own success. The tale of our hero has been told all over the world, so that now he is known only by the moniker "Pilgrim of Knowledge."

413.contentId:
7 Martalo 550


Today, I feel like writing in my journal again. For weeks, all I've done is write alchemy formulas! I'm starting a new journal because I can't find my first. Could I have left it in Amakna? If so, I hope no one has found it! It contains a few embarrassing details. The past two months have been very full. After I reached Frigost Island, I travelled to the slopes of Mount Scauldron in the dead of winter to set up my laboratory. Temperatures were very low... I nearly froze on site, but I only lost two toes in the ordeal. Nothing really! Alas, the extreme cold only lasted a very short time. Luckily, I concocted refrigerating elixirs and have stored a huge quantity of ice. I should be able to stock up on the cold for my experiments.

8 Aperirel 550


They say that you need to watch out for cold snaps in Aperirel, and I think I've brought the saying to life! I've managed to create a bank of freezing fog to cool the area around my laboratory. I am going to be able to continue my work without waiting for next winter. I'm considering building a greenhouse for some of my plants, but I'll need workers for that... I wonder if the hairy brutes that I've run into in the area on several occasions could help me. They don't seem to be aggressive if you don't provoke them.

19 Junssidor 550


The greenhouse is complete! Good work, done well. The Bearbarians have been rather friendly, and I was able to negotiate with their leader, a spiritual guide of sorts who spends a large part of his days gorging on honey. He gave me everything I needed in exchange for allowing his worker bees free access to my plants. I agreed. Especially since I've learned of the existence of a celestial nectar with highly interesting properties. I think I might add a few drops to the next version of my potion. I am very hopeful that I will make progress in my research!

15 Jullier 550


After several swarms were killed, poisoned by some of my plants, my relationship with the Bearbarians has deteriorated. They don't want to have anything to do with me. So, I stay away from their hive, and they stay away from my greenhouse. The Alchimeras that I've created from elemental fluids ensure my safety, but I have trouble sleeping. I feel like all progress has stalled, and like I'm trapped in my own mind. I wonder if the solitude is starting to get to me.

8 Frauguctor 550


A traveller on his way to the top of Mount Scauldron got lost and stumbled across my greenhouse. I offered him my hospitality. He filled me in on the news in the region: a village is being built at the base of the mountain, and all its inhabitants are working on a massive project. He would probably have told me more about it if he'd been able to withstand the cold better... I think his heart froze in his chest. I just couldn't pass up the opportunity to test my latest conservation elixir! He made an excellent guinea pig.

22 Frauguctor 550


I've decided! I'm going to Boundwons Village! I'll take advantage of my trip there to replenish my dwindling supplies of seeds, food and certain ingredients.

20 Septangel 550


The innkeeper gave me a message today, from an Amaknian called Kordis. He claims to have my journal, and wants to become my student. And he knows what happened to my previous apprentice... That makes me curious to meet him.

22 Septangel 550


My talk with Kordis was very productive! I agreed to take him on – on a trial basis. He seems fairly talented, especially when it comes to his knowledge of mushrooms. I'll probably send him to the Mystified Forest to collect a few samples for me. We are probably going to spend the autumn in the village and when winter starts showing its nose, we'll head for my laboratory.

414.contentId:
Dear Diary,


This is the first time I've ever been happy to have you in my bag. I haven't had anyone to talk to since Krikri, the last rat in the room, died. I was forced to sacrifice Krikri today because I didn't have anything else for afternoon tea. I hated having to do it, but Krikri is much happier dead than starving.
I've been here for several days now, and it's starting to get really hot in here. I wonder where all the water we used to have has gone to. Even if we couldn't drink it, at least it helped regulate the heat. My beer supplies are dwindling, and I don't want to think about what's in store for me when the barrels are empty.
That'll teach me to nod off while the others are working. My mum was always going on about that, and she's definitely going to give me a good scolding when I get home. Maybe it'd be better not to go home... What do you think, my paper friend? I don't know which scares me more – my mum yelling or the screams coming from the depths of the Undersmithy.


Dear Diary,


Today, I decided to try and grill the last piece of Krikri. Mum always grills other animals but I'm not sure how it's done. I'm afraid I'll burn myself, but given the taste of raw rat compared to cooked rat, it's a risk worth taking. P.S. My beard caught fire while I was cooking, but I think I managed to cook the meat a bit. It didn't taste as bad as usual.


Dear Diary,


I've been thinking, and I've decided I should try to get out of this room. I've been here for 12 days now, and no one has come looking for me, not even my mum. I think they don't want to come because they're afraid of the screams. But, if I leave, maybe my mum will be proud of me. She's always said that it's better I wait for someone to help me because it's safer for me that way. I think she's right. But I'm hungry. I'm going to try to open the wooden door at the top of the stairs just to see what's there. I hope there'll be beer.


Dear Diary,


My visit to the next room over was the best experience of my life. I was very scared, but I found beer and that's all that counts. I also met three new rats. I've only eaten two so far, because I've been talking to the third a lot. I can't wait to see my mum and tell her all about it. She's never going to believe me!


Dear Diary,


Last night, I heard scratching on the door. At first, I thought it was new rats coming for a visit, but when I went to open the door, I realised it was something much bigger. I heard a lot of growling and was very afraid. I don't know what it was exactly, but I couldn't sleep for a long time.


Dear Diary,


Today, I went back to the next rooms over to get beer. It was as dark as the first time. But this time, I decided to light a torch, and it was much easier to catch rats. I think I'll take a torch with me wherever I go from now on.


Dear Diary,


Today, I've decided to visit the Undersmithy furnaces! I've always wanted to see the smithy up close. But my mum would never let me go places I wasn't supposed to be. At work, we always took the same path so I haven't seen much of the inside of the Undersmithy in all these years.
I took my torch and went further than the last beer barrels I found. I found rooms filled with weapons and armour. I was able to find a few skewers to cook the remaining rats. I do wonder how they manage to find food here, though. The wrought iron pieces are really beautiful, and I'm proud to have contributed to them even just a little. I even found jewels that will probably be set into weapons and armour. I'd love to learn how to do that. My mum won't ever allow it, though... I wonder if maybe I shouldn't try all the same.


Dear Diary,


I heard scratching and growling at the door again last night. Now I'm sure that it's not coming from rats. I grabbed one of the weapons I found deep in the Undersmithy. I don't know how to use it, but I'm a Stubbyob so I'm sure it's in my blood. The growling didn't last long and I was able to sleep.


Dear Diary,


I tried to explore more of the Undersmithy today, but I ran into something bad. I was very scared and had to run and hide. I couldn't really see what it was, but it was huge and growled very loudly. I'd never heard anything like it before. And the stories my mum used to tell me didn't say anything about something like that either.


Dear Diary,


I heard steps in the next room this morning. I thought my mum had come to get me! So I ran to see, but I had to hide quickly behind the beer barrels because it wasn't my mum at all. The strange people walking around the Undersmithy were very scary. I really wonder where my mum and everyone else has gone.


Dear Diary,


All these days here have given me time to think about a lot of things. I accomplished my dream of visiting the depths of the Undersmithy! I think this experience has changed me a bit. I cooked for myself, and I've survived all this time without my mum's help. It's been hard, but I've learned a lot. Or maybe the hunger is getting to me and I'm starting to really lose my mind. But deep down, I don't think I regret it at all...


Dear Diary,


I didn't sleep at all last night because the growling at the door came back. Even the last remaining rat fled the room. I think the monsters outside know that I'm there, and I don't dare go out or move at all. I won't make any noise and maybe they'll go away soon. I hope.


Dear Diary,


The monsters outside have finally left. I'm very scared to leave, but I'm also very hungry. I think that all the rats are dead, because I haven't been able to find even one for several days. I'm really hungry... I'm going to go exploring again, despite the danger. I guess I don't really have much to lose. I'll be back tonight...

415.titleId: Tales and Legends of the Bayou, Volume 2
415.contentId:
The Hiss of Death


For most inhabitants of the Bayou, hearing the hiss of a viviper is a bad omen. As for crossing one's path... The few who are still alive rarely want to speak of it, out of fear that bad luck remembers that it forgot them along the way.


Yet, the viviper wasn't always associated with dark omens of death. The association dates back a time when the gods, arrogant and presumptuous, thought they could ignore the goddess of death.


Tikoltenak, the Crocodyl capital, often caught the attention of the divinities who enjoyed meeting there, prattling on and predicting their faithful followers' future battles and conquests. One evening, Ixchelonia, the goddess of the night, mused that the stars didn't have names and wondered why. The light of the stars would only shine fully once all the beings in the Archipelago of Scales could murmur their names.


Intrigued by this sudden declaration, the gods decided to meet the following month to make the stars into celestial bodies in their own right. They all received Ixchelonia's call. All of them, that is, except the Serpent Queen.


In the morning, a pensive Ixchelonia withdrew under a sun that was slow in rising, while in the dark depths of the Crocodyl city, a laughing Huascaraknas was spinning her web. She was laughing because she knew which of the gods hadn't been invited to the evening's meeting. Huascaraknas spun a thread down to the depths of the city where she found Tanatekutli curled up in the damp.


Goddess of death, Tanatekutli is the Serpent Queen of the underground realm. She slithers day and night through the depths of her sinister kingdom. She knows every corner of it, every trickle of water, and every lost soul haunting the cold walls.


Huascaraknas slid along until she reached the sleeping goddess and smoothly whispered to her. She mentioned the meeting the gods had planned to name the stars and expressed false surprise when the Serpent Queen said she hadn't been informed of it. Huascaraknas chuckled as she threaded her way back up to the city and a dark fury took root in the hollows of Tanatekutli's scales.


In the evening, the Serpent Queen left her underground kingdom and slid her reptilian body to the top of Crocabulia's temple. Unaware of Tanatekutli's approaching fury, the gods were gazing at the stars. They were taking turns drawing the constellations that illuminated the inhabitants of the Archipelago of Scales every night. They drew twelve constellations in the dark sky.


When Tanatekutli reached the top of the Scaly Mother's temple, she saw that none of the constellations bore her mark. The powerful Serpent Queen unleashed her wrath on the other gods and drew a thirteenth constellation in the immense sky. And thus, from the pointy shape of the stars, Tanatekutli's serpentine children emerged.


Powerful venomous spotted vivipers appeared throughout the Archipelago of Scales. The Serpent Queen cursed everyone pretentious enough to dare forget her ever again. She swore that the terrifying threat of the vivipers' poison would forever prevent anyone from wiping Tanatekutli's name from their minds.


The Fountain of Youth


The bayou is home to many strange and mysterious tales and legends. This story speaks of one of these mystical places.


There was once a cruel Crocodyl who spread fear and destruction in the bayou. For many long years, this Crocodyl terrorised creatures throughout the Archipelago of Scales. But old age is a relentless enemy that slowly caught up to the Crocodyl, who became aware of the physical limits imposed upon him by age.


One sad night, the Crocodyl was struggling through the imposing mangrove when he came across a well that he'd ignored for many years. The Crocodyl bent down over the well and brought the water up to his mouth.

It was a miracle! The Crocodyl's worn out and battered scales were replaced by solid, shiny scales. His teeth became sharp again, and little by little the Crocodyl recovered his past strength and vitality.


However, in his thirst for eternal youth, the Crocodyl drank the water from the spring throughout the night. In the morning, the Crocodyl bent over the endless spring and saw a strange reflection staring back at him. Realising that he'd shrunk to the size of a simple lizard, he became afraid and fled into the dark bayou. That horrid Crocodyl that had, for so many years, spread terror in the bayou was never heard from again.


Learn more.

Notice to all Frigostians! Today, 12 Maysial 550, Mayor Cantile, your humble servant, is honoured to announce the opening of Frigost's first agricultural innovation contest. As part of efforts to considerably increase agricultural production across the island and thus eliminate all competition with the Amaknian continent, the Frigost Village municipal council invites all residents of Frigost to present their innovative concepts.


Starting today and until 1 Jullier, all Frigostians may submit their ideas, sketches and blueprints directly at the reception desk in the Frigost Village town hall. An exhibit showcasing shortlisted projects well be held on 4 Jullier in front of the town hall.


The contest is open to anyone living on the continent of Frigost. The agricultural concepts must be doable. The Frigost Village municipal committee will study every submission in depth. For more information, please contact Lou Bricante directly.

417.contentId:
After having lived in several sewers and tunnels, earning the nickname "King of the Underworld" and being sentenced to life in Amakna prison, Mastigator is now rumoured to have reached the Archipelago of Scales. Closeness to the Scalies and their bloodthirsty activities has merely revived Mastigator's destructive impulses. Sentenced to imprisonment in Amakna Castle for slavery, trafficking in criminally bad literature, and assaulting peace officers with a hammer, he fled the continent to continue perpetrating his crimes.

In Summary

To escape incarceration, Mastigator is said to have fled to Orado Island where he is living among the Scalies in the City of Gold. He is said to be hiding among the Crocodyls and living on carnage and fresh blood in their company.
Can only be captured by very experienced mercenaries.

418.contentId:
The wise village elders and storytellers in the Archipelago of Scales often tell naughty children a dark tale whispered in the Bayou.


This tale tells of a cruel Crocodyl who spread fear and destruction in the bayou. Along his path, the Crocodyl left nothing but blood and chaos behind him. His victims' sad agony resonated long after he'd passed between the wide trunks of the mangrove trees.


He did his massacring in the night, and the Crocodyl took refuge in a corner of the bayou from which the few foolhardy souls who dared venture there never returned. It was said that there was a magical spring there that allowed the Crocodyl to preserve his vitality eternally. The water from this spring contained powerful properties, and the Crocodyl drank it every night.


The inhabitants, terrified by the legendary Crocodyl, went every day at dusk to deposit a Piraniak before the Crocodyl's lair. The Crocodyl was often content with the fish, ripped from the blood-red waters of the bayou, and when he was the inhabitants avoided a massacre.


One day, an intrepid villager declared that he was going to hunt the beast in its lair. When he returned to the village, he claimed to have found the magical spring. It was almost empty. In the centre of the basin, he found a lizard small enough to fit in the villager's hand. Terrified by the villager, the lizard ran off into the bayou.


Did the Crocodyl drink too deeply from the spring? Did fate turn against the Crocodyl? No one knows for sure, but the inhabitants have stopped leaving Piraniaks in the bayou... and the terrible Crocodyl has never been heard from since.

420.contentId:
19 Javian 551


I'm starting to lose hope. I've been on Frigost for a year now and my research is still at the same stage. My potions are reacting to the cold, but something's missing! Argh! I can't figure out what it is! I wonder if I shouldn't take a break and work on some other project for a while. Just to get some distance. Maybe then the solution will present itself to me on its own! A nobleman from Frigost, a certain Count Harebourg, has asked me to participate in the construction of a huge water clock. He wants me to supervise the creation of the liquid that will power it. I'm very flattered! I think I'll accept his offer.


My research can wait a few months! I'm sure immortality will be mine, eventually!

23 Javian 551


I'm leaving my plants and laboratory in the good hands of Kordis. The Count has offered to put me up in his castle on top of Mount Scauldron. I'll build a new, larger greenhouse there and I'll plant the seeds I'll bring with me. I'm eager to begin working on the famous water clock! With a little luck, I'll make interesting discoveries that will let me achieve my goal.

26 Javian 551


I reached the castle last night. Harebourg welcomed me warmly. Today, I met the three master craftsmen working on the project. Hazieff Taroun made a good impression, but he seems a bit naive and idealistic. The Imp was quite the dirty spoiled brat, but he seems very skilled at handiwork. As for the last, Klume, Klime or something like that... Well, I don't think I've ever met anyone that twisted. But... the Count approached him, so I'm sure he's very skilled in his field. Still, I'm going to keep my contact with him to a minimum and make sure I don't let him get behind me.

17 Flovor 551


A new recruit joined the team, a Xelor who goes by the name of Missiz Freezz. It seems she's quite skilled at smithmagic. Klime whistled admiringly when he met her, so I imagine he's not indifferent to her charms. He'd do better to focus on his work rather than wasting time organising play parties. In any case, the Xelor seems only to have eyes for Harebourg. Or rather, she can't keep her eye off him, I should say, since the cold froze part of her face and left her with just one eye. She doesn't seem to have been very affected by the mutilation... And it must be said that she doesn't need to wear a mask.

20 Flovor 551


During my morning walk, I ran into Stubbyobs inspecting the wall. The Count has reached some kind of agreement with them, and I think he wants to include them in our project. I hope they won't cause us any trouble. For my part, I find them noisy and rude... I just hope they don't start relieving themselves in my garden between two tankards of beer. But if they do, my Alchimeras will teach them proper respect for other people's property!

3 Aperirel 551


I found the frozen bodies of two labourers this morning. The idiots had tried to move a reservoir of cooling liquid without taking the necessary precautions... I'm going to have to cover up the incident if I don't want to be accused of being lax when it comes to safety protocols. I don't have time to waste on this foolishness. I've much too much work to do! With a bit of luck, no one will even notice they're gone.

15 Maysial 551


Hazieff Taroun was particularly enthusiastic at our weekly meeting. Apparently, he's found a way to tame the heat from the volcano to fuel the machine's cogs. We'll have to coordinate our work so that the water clock liquid is kept at low temperatures, but it seems to be possible. The project is making wonderful progress... Its completion is certain now!

27 Octolliard 551


It's been a long time since I wrote in my journal. I've been so busy! I've managed to stabilise the water clock liquid mixture. There are still a few details to sort out, but I'm optimistic. We should be able to turn the machine on at the end of the year at the start of winter. If everything works as planned, we're going to change the course of the seasons – and make history! A new era is dawning in Frigost. Very few Frigostians realise it; they're behaving like buffoons. Luckily, there are people like us – visionaries, geniuses, brilliant minds working to throw off the shackles of nature. Everything seems possible now. The secret of immortality... is within my grasp, I'm certain of it!

421.contentId:
"Kaytoplumes like this one are rare!" - Klay Kayton


Arrogant and proud, Domoizelle's favourite area is the Bayou. Her brightly coloured feathers have made her a frequent target for hunters. However, the unfortunate souls who dared approach her beauty are no longer here to tell of it. Poachers, adventurers, and even simple lost tourists have all faced the same fate: rolling on the floor laughing while being tickled to death! Domoizelle has earned a very grim reputation among travellers because of the insistence with which she puts her sumptuous feathers to work.

In Summary

Domoizelle is wanted for having tickled several adventurers to their premature deaths as they rolled on the floor laughing. Domoizelle can be found in the Bayou where she defends her territory ferociously.

How to Connect the Lever to the Explosives:


Each coloured slab with a number on it represents a stage with a choice to make.

The slabs with black symbols on them indicate a fuse direction that you may choose.

So, you must interact with 5 slabs with black symbols (matching a fuse direction) to properly connect the lever to the explosives.

Each slab with a black symbol can only be used once.


To reinitialise or confirm, use the lever.
